PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BJELKE-PETERSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 2,733 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are concerned that an increasing number of Australian families are facing financial burdens beyond their capacity to meet.
2. That we are concerned that the amount of financial assistance being afforded to families is inadequate.
3. That there has been no increase in family allowances for most families for some years.
4. That family allowances in all instances have declined in real value since 1976.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, will :
1. Ensure that there is an increase in family allowances in the 1982 Budget so that family allowances are at least restored to the real money value of their 1976 level;
2. Ensure that provision is made for the automatic and regular indexation of family allowances;
3. Introduce a Homemakers Allowance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 15 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that some television stations throughout Australia are taking advantage of the absence of ratings surveys during the Christmas-New Year holiday season to broadcast inferior quality programs and innumerable repeats.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will undertake and publish the results of ratings surveys during holiday periods to encourage the broadcasting of quality TV programs at those times.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BOLKUS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 3,114 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The successive promises of the Federal Government to introduce ethnic television into Australia have only been carried out in respect to Sydney and Melbourne, ignoring other centres with large ethnic populations such as Adelaide .
2. The large proportion of the population of Adelaide is denied certain cultural rights including the viewing of television programs broadcast in languages other than English.

3. The enormous benefits which arise from ethnic television in a multicultural society such as Australia, especially in respect to the exchange of ideas and exposing people to different views and cultures.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will request the Government to extend the operations of the Special Broadcasting Service's television service, Channel 0/28, to Adelaide without delay.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 46 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all; that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increases uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 20 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P.:

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 416 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania:
That the church was built by the Catholic parishoners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961, was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other Christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenent on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TATE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 55 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That reports continue to circulate in the community of a cruel and barbaric trade in the skins and furs of domestic cats and dogs.
That all decent citizens are outraged at this unscrupulous activity.
That the Federal Government, in consultation with the States, take strong action to outlaw and stamp out any commercial dealing, including export, in such skins and furs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MASON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 174 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support a Federal Inquiry into South West Tasmania as recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Deputy Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: University Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The students and staff of the University of Queensland express their dismay at the lack of adequate federal government funding to our University, which has resulted, inter alia, in the erosion of our Library facilities-we note that:
1. The opening hours of our main Library have been reduced from 93 1/2 hours a week in 1975 to 72 hours a week in 1982.
2. The number of new books purchased per year has fallen from over 50,000 in 1976 to under 23,000 in 1981.
3. The number of books in storage and inaccessible to students and staff has risen from none in 1977 to over 40,000 in 1981.
4. The number of books discarded in 1976 was over 6,000-by the end of 1981 over 70,000 had been discarded.

We believe this to be educationally retrograde and economically wasteful. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate urge the Government to increase funding to a level sufficient to allow the University to restore our previous Library facilities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Collard (from 62 citizens) and MacGibbon (from 60 citizens).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report:
Garden Island, New South Wales, modernisation, stage 2: Surface preparation and preservation facility and oily bilge waste treatment plant.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry: Has the Australian Dairy Corporation been making advances to dairy companies since 1975 to enable them to pay farmers for delivery of milk? How far back have checks on misuse of these funds been made? When will the Minister be in a position to make a full statement about the misuse of funds since the inception of the scheme some seven years ago?

—It is true that this scheme is long standing. I do not immediately recall whether 1975 was the starting date but I have no reason to dispute that. As I indicated yesterday the matter is still receiving the attention of the Australian Dairy Corporation. I have asked to be advised as any further information comes to hand. I will ask the Corporation to let me know how long it expects its investigations to take. I met some representatives of the Corporation yesterday and they assured me that these investigations were continuing but I will try to get an estimate of time from them to respond to the Leader of the Opposition. I have no further information today as to any other irregularities having been disclosed. I would expect to have heard if they had been. I will ensure that while the Senate is sitting I am kept up to date and in a position to advise the Senate of any further developments.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry and concerns the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory in Geelong. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether it is intended to import into Australia live exotic diseases, in particular live foot and mouth disease, for experimental purposes at that laboratory?

—Senator Lewis was good enough to advise me that he wished to raise this matter with me and I have sought advice from the relevant department. However, I have not had an answer to the question which he has put to me this morning. I will try to get it before the end of Question Time.
—I asked it a month ago.
—I note the interjection from the other side of the chamber. In any event, I will try to get an answer to that precise question. If I do not get it today, I will get it tomorrow.

—I ask the Attorney-General a question. He will agree, in view of the many and varied allegations of police corruption in several of the States of Australia and the occasional accusations of involvement of politicians in this corruption, that it would be disastrous if politicians abused these matters for party political purposes. In view of this, I ask the following question, in three parts: Firstly, was Senator Martyr's question yesterday based on information given to Senator Martyr by the Attorney or by anyone associated with the Attorney's office, with the knowledge of the Attorney, or did the information for the question emanate from the Liberal Party or Government sources according to the Attorney's knowledge? Secondly, did the Attorney have knowledge of the question?
—Ask Senator Martyr.
—I normally can get by asking questions without the assistance of Senator Teague. I ask him to desist. I do not need his assistance this morning.
—Senator Chipp, proceed with your question.
—Secondly, did the Attorney have notice of the question? Thirdly, if he did, did he try to dissuade Senator Martyr from asking it?

—Senator Chipp has asked whether Senator Martyr's question yesterday was based on information given to Senator Martyr by me. The answer to that is no. He asked whether it was given by anyone associated with the Attorney 's office. The answer is no. He asked whether the information emanated from Liberal Party or Government sources. I would have to say that that would have to be asked of Senator Martyr because all I can say is that it did not emanate from me or from my office.
—You know it was discussed at your Federal Council meeting.

—The question that was asked of me was whether the Allen papers had been received. That is all the knowledge I have of it as far as the Federal Council is concerned. The second question was whether I had notice of the question. I did receive yesterday morning notice of the question but I had not any opportunity, as honourable senators may have realised from the terms of my answer, of preparing any answer to it because I had not any great notice of it. Thirdly, Senator Chipp asked whether I tried to dissuade Senator Martyr from asking it. The answer is no.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noted an interview with Mr Laurie Carmichael of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM yesterday concerning the social wage concept that apparently has been adopted by the Australian Labor Party? Is she aware that in a package dealing with this subject Mr Carmichael advocated: First, cuts in personal income tax; secondly, tax indexation; thirdly , a universal health scheme paid out of government revenue or taxpayers' money; and, fourthly, reduced interest rates and increased social welfare and age pensions? They are all commendable objectives, I am sure, but can the Minister give an estimate of the likely cost of implementing this package? Does she recognise the implicit contradiction in the concept which on the one hand calls for less taxation and yet on the other hand demands greater and more costly government services? Will the Minister agree that this concept is not only impractical but also another example of irresponsible financial policies advocated by the Australian Labor Party and union leaders?

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not object in any way to the question but I point out that terminology is sometimes used very loosely in questions. Senator Jessop, with his customary flair for doing that, has asked Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to comment on the concept of the social wage which has been adopted by the Australian Labor Party. I hope the Minister will not be confused by that terminology because it is used, of course, in different circles and in different circumstances; the concept is used in different contexts. I ask the Minister, when answering the question, to deal with Mr Carmichael's concept and not with the hypothetical one which Senator Jessop attributes to the Australian Labor Party.
—There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A lot of assistance seems to be being given all around the chamber in regard to questions this morning. The question raised by Senator Jessop related to Mr Carmichael and his comments. I would not embark on a discussion about the social wage concept that the Australian Labor Party has in its mind, particularly after the statement of the Leader of the Opposition yesterday concerning $6,000m being available for tax cuts. Perhaps I should refer to the Treasurer's comments in relation to that matter. However, in response to Senator Jessop and the matters raised by Mr Carmichael, let me say that we all welcomed the most recent decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with regard to wages at present. The Government will be pursuing policies appropriate to wage moderation and the reduction of inflation in the period that lies ahead. That of course will include the framework of the forthcoming Budget to be presented in August. I think it is accepted that there is responsibility on all parts of the Australian community for wage restraint. The sorts of things included in Mr Carmichael's concept involve an equation that just does not work. He refers on the one hand to tax cuts and on the other hand to increased wages and other elements such as health systems, increases in social security payments and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: All these things may be desirable objectives if economic circumstances permitted. On the other hand, I think the outcry for reduction in personal and other income taxes and government charges leads me to say that what was sought by Mr Carmichael would not be welcomed by the Australian community in its present mood. However, as I have said, the Government is pursuing policies which will lead to wage moderation and co-operation from all sectors of the community and at the same time to the reduction of inflation and the management of the economy for growth and development. That will be the way in which we will proceed in the forthcoming Budget, and at an appropriate time we will probably be very happy to hear from Senator Button all about the social wage concept of his party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister been able to make an estimate of the likely cost of the items that I mentioned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — To talk about likely cost one would need to talk about what size of income tax cuts are envisaged, what growth in social security expenditure is envisaged, what contribution, if any, people would make to the health scheme that was outlined and all the other things that are contained in the vague concept that was put forward. To put a price tag on it would be impossible; to put a cost on it in real terms, I think, would be something that we would not be prepared to do in any Budget that we are drawing up at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Do the Bowen guidelines on ministerial conduct require the Prime Minister either to endorse explicitly the administrative action of any Minister which affects a company in which the Minister has an interest or to appoint another Minister to make the necessary decisions? Does he know that the conditions under which the Australian Dairy Corporation grants loans give it punitive powers over companies which misuse Reserve Bank of Australia funds transferred through the Corporation and that the Minister can influence and even direct the Corporation? Will the Prime Minister guarantee that this time the Bowen guidelines will be enforced and Mr Nixon will not be allowed, in isolation , to make decisions affecting the Murray Goulburn Co-op. Co. Ltd in which he is a shareholder?
—Of course I am aware of the Bowen guidelines and the debate that has taken place in this chamber from time to time in regard to them. I do not propose to repeat them. I am not fully aware of--
—Do you agree that I accurately summarised them?

—I think, in general terms, what the honourable senator has said is a summary of them, although there is some question as to the specific application of that rule to a particular case. The honourable senator is probably referring to what occurred in the case of Murray Goulburn and the Minister. That matter was dealt with by the Prime Minister at the time and he gave his interpretation of the guidelines which, I think, the honourable senator does not accept. So there is some room for interpretation. I do not see why we should be expected to accept Senator Walsh's interpretation of them in respect of that case. The conditions under which money is made available to the Australian Dairy Corporation are a matter which will need to be given consideration in order to answer that aspect of the question. I will draw it to the attention of the Prime Minister and ask him to give consideration to it.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology to an Age report of 20 May relating to claims by Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation researchers that almost all of Victoria is threatened by eucalyptus dieback. Will the Minister comment on this report and, in particular, the claim by CSIRO entomologist, Dr Phillip Carne, that the problem is approaching what could almost be termed a national disaster? In view of the increasing threat posed by dieback to Australia's eucalypts, I ask the Minister: First, what action has been taken by the Government and Government agencies in an effort to contain and eradicate the pests attacking our native trees? Secondly, will a campaign be instituted by the Government to alert farmers to the possible ways of helping trees survive against pasture pests as one way of containing the threat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article that is referred to by Senator Missen has drawn some information from the Department of Science and Technology. The evidence strongly suggests that a connection exists between tree clearing for livestock grazing and dieback which affects the remaining trees. The processes involved are complex and will require long term study. The death of trees affected with dieback is usually hastened by leaf-eating insects. Evidently these insects lived in ecological balance with the trees prior to land clearing and the establishment of livestock properties. At present there is no sure method of reversing or controlling dieback that is economic and acceptable to graziers. One approach that has been suggested is to fence off parts of farms from grazing to encourage large wood lots either of local species or of insect resistant species brought in from other regions.

ANSWER.PARA: At present the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is co-operating with the New South Wales Department of Agriculture at Armidale to determine the effects of various forms of grazing management on the control of eucalypt dieback by means of control of the soil-living stage of leaf-eating insects. The CSIRO has recently completed a review of its possible research role in this matter. The Executive has agreed that the Division of Entomology and the Division of Forest Research should hold discussions with other interested research bodies, particularly the University of New England because of its active dieback research, with a view to undertaking collaborative work which would make the best use of the skills in those divisions.

Senator Missen asked what action will be taken and whether we will have some sort of campaign. I will need to draw on the Minister for Science and Technology and his decisions with regard to further action that could be taken, given that the CSIRO is working on the problem. Perhaps the specific steps mentioned by Senator Missen are not yet being undertaken.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Mason as the honourable senator in charge of the Australian Democrats' Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1982. Is it a fact that that Bill proposes, amongst other things, a procedure for constitutional change which would allow the representation in this Parliament of a smaller State to be altered without the consent of that State, as is presently required; that is, by an affirmative vote by a two-thirds majority of all electors throughout Australia? In other words, could Tasmania's representation in this place be reduced from 10 senators to six senators or even four senators without the assent of a majority of electors in Tasmania? The same fate awaits Western Australia, Queensland and South Australia if the Democrats' proposal is carried through. Have the Democrats any other proposals drastically to diminish or impair the role of the outlying States in this Federation? Will the Democrats come clean and unveil all their proposals to secure their policy objective to replace State governments with regional assemblies?

—I must allay to a considerable extent Senator Tate's fears on behalf of his State. Yes, indeed, I have had advice from constitutional lawyers that it may well be possible that my proposed citizens' initiative Bill could overrule the provisions in the Constitution for its own reform. I regard it as a very valuable instrument for progress in many directions with which I am sure Senator Tate would agree. The question he raises is purely hypothetical. He is saying, in effect, that if that power is granted power will be taken from the smaller States. I think this is a matter of the intent of the Australian population at large, rather than of any other intent. My answer is that all we are offering in the Bill is a power which would allow the people of this country to make law independent of Parliament and possibly-I stress that this is a matter that would have to be tested-to alter the Constitution of this country through the right of citizens' initiative. As to Senator Tate's second question, the Democrats certainly do not have any proposals that I am aware of-certainly I am not sponsoring any-which would diminish the rights of any State of this Commonwealth. In general the whole issue of representation and any future changes in the electoral system of this country or the Constitution is a matter for the people of this country. All the Australian Democrats are doing is trying to provide for them a right through which they can make their voice heard.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Mason avoided the final part of my question, which required some assent to the proposition that the Democrats have a policy objective to destroy State governments and to replace them with regional assemblies.

—It is correct that long term Democrat policy would foresee over a considerable period regional governments in this country rather like the French departments. I have no doubt that these would apply--

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to rule on whether that question is in order. Can Senator Tate ask an honourable senator who is not a Minister what is that honourable senator's policy or his party's policy about any matter? It does not seem to me to relate to the Bill which the honourable senator has brought before the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Standing Order 98 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: After Notices have been given Questions may be put to Ministers of the Crown relating to public affairs; and to other Senators, relating to any Bill, Motion, or other public matter connected with the business on the Notice Paper, of which such Senators may have charge.
The point of order taken by Senator Lewis is upheld because I think Senator Tate 's supplementary question is wide of the matter on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Working on the premise that tax and social security measures should be structured to assist the family unit and taking into account the fact that, whilst the Australian tax system is based on the individual, tax relief has always been designed to give assistance to the family, can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Government is prepared to give consideration to a proposal to increase the spouse rebate to a sum of $2,000 and also to make a corresponding increase in the sole parent rebate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Matters of policy of the kind mentioned by Senator Bjelke-Petersen would be more properly addressed in the Budget context and not canvassed at this stage. However, the proposal that she has put before us with regard to increases in the spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate is perhaps only one way in which people would consider that assistance through the tax system might be addressed towards the family. For instance, as I understand it, about one-third of the spouse rebates goes to families where there are no dependent children. I am not aware of whether that was known to Senator Bjelke- Petersen when she put forward the proposal that she has outlined this morning. The assistance to families through the family allowance, the spouse rebate and other tax measures will be before the Government in the forthcoming Budget preparation. I am sure we will have many suggestions that will need consideration. For my part, the spouse rebate in cases where there are no dependent children would not be the highest priority in a tax review.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to the concern expressed by senior members of the Australian computer industry about the possible retrospective application of a sales tax to packaged computer software? Can the Minister explain why the computer software industry has been told repeatedly over the past 14 years that its products were service and not goods and were therefore not eligible for research and development grants, grants in aid or tax incentives? Can the Minister further explain why in the last 12 months several-but only a tiny minority-of the firms have been told the opposite? Why has computer software suddenly become a good and thus liable for sales tax? Will the Treasurer examine the possibility of exempting computer software from sales tax as an incentive to a rapidly developing industry which uses Australian technological skills, which is labour intensive and for which Australia is rapidly acquiring a high international reputation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will inquire of the Treasurer about the problem, if one exists, outlined by Senator Siddons. I am not aware of why there has been any recent change in the application of sales tax to a small number of companies. If there is some difficulty in a particular instance I may need to seek further information from Senator Siddons, but if there is any general problem I will see that the Treasurer gives his attention to the matter and I will see that the Senate is advised accordingly.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Health will recall his answer to my question on 25 March this year when he informed the Senate that Dr T. H. Hurley's report on the family medicine program was expected to be received by the Government some time in April. Can the Minister now tell the Senate whether the report has been received and considered and whether it will be made public?

—I recall that Senator Walters asked me a question about the report being prepared by Dr Hurley. During the brief period that I was Minister for Health Dr Hurley called on me and actually presented the report. So, I can advise the Senate that the report has been received and is now in the hands of the Government. It is under consideration and it will require some Government decisions. I understand that a decision as to whether and, if so, how it will be released is yet to be taken. That is one of the decisions which my successor would have before him at this time.

—In accordance with Standing Order 98 I direct to Senator Ryan a question in relation to the Sex Discrimination Bill 1981. Does Senator Ryan expect the co-operation of the Government in securing the passage of the Sex Discrimination Bill? What would be the major benefits of such legislation? Will the honourable senator approach the new Minister responsible for women's affairs to seek his co-operation in its passage?

—While I have received no official statement of the Government's intentions as to my private member's Bill on sex and marital status discrimination, the indications I have received at this stage suggest that the Government will not support the passage of the Bill. This is despite the fact that the primary purpose of the Bill is to put into effect the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women-a convention which the Federal Government has signed and has given lip service to but which it has failed to ratify. The intention of the Bill is to ensure that the provisions laid down in the international convention prevail throughout Australia. In answer to the second part of Senator Colston's question, the major advantages of my Bill would be to prohibit discrimination on the grounds of sex or marital status against both men and women in the areas of education, provision of services and goods, accommodation, land, clubs and all areas of employment within which the Commonwealth has power. It also provides for affirmative action programs in public and private employment.
—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I think the honourable senator is reading her answer. She is now making a speech, and she should not be reading a speech.
—I think Senator Ryan is responding to the question, but I ask her to complete her answer shortly.

—Mr Deputy President, I was following the great ministerial tradition of question answering in this place. Finally, with regard to co- operation or consultation with Ministers of the Government who may be interested in discussing this Bill, I point out that the fact, as was reported at the recent Liberal Party Federal Conference, that support of Australian women for the Liberal Party is declining and electoral support of Australian women for the Australian Labor Party is increasing may help to create a more sympathetic response by the Government to the passage of this Bill. I look forward to the opportunity of discussing it with the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment or any other Minister who may consider it important to do so.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask that the paper from which Senator Ryan was reading be tabled.
—Mr Deputy President, I table the paper.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware that the unanimity of the recent Australian Sheep Meat Study Mission to the Middle East on live sheep exports has broken down? Does the Government intend to act on the addendum to the Mission's recommendation and consult with interested industry bodies on the establishment of funding arrangements for a positive program of development and expansion of markets for Australian hogget and mutton in the countries importing Australian live sheep?

—I am not specifically aware that there has been a breakdown in the unanimity expressed in the recommendations which have been tabled and to which I understand the various parties to the mission on the export of live sheep were and still are in agreement. I understand that there were some differences of view on the methods of funding which might be adopted in respect of a program to encourage the greater export of carcass meats. That is a matter of detail on which I would expect the Minister for Primary Industry to be having discussions with the parties involved. As I indicated at Question Time yesterday , the recommendations are available, they were tabled in the Parliament and they have received the consideration of the Government. They are recommendations which are to be pursued by the Minister and I would expect that in addition to pursuing those recommendations he would be in a position to make a public statement on the matter in the not too distant future.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask it in view of the non-answer yesterday by the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs about the Government's attitude to the Falkland Islands affair. Instead of the Government trying to keep up an appearance of having its options open, will it give a clear and unequivocal assurance that Australia will not become militarily involved and will not follow the Thatchers and Galtieris of this world who are sacrificing the lives of Service personnel as playthings in their domestic political games at no personal risk to themselves. The answer given yesterday and the published comments of the now Minister for Defence sounded more like they were inviting a request from Britain. Will the Acting Leader give an assurance that the Government does not wish to have a request from Britain? Why is it necessary to have such a request before deciding not to participate? Is it not about time that the Australian Government pleaded with the United Kingdom Government to take a more reasonable attitude to ceasefire and negotiation, while at the same time making the same plea to Argentina? Finally, has Australia tried to discover whether reports that United Kingdom ships in the area are carrying nuclear weapons are correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the question to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle yesterday on this matter. I cannot remember which senator asked it.
—Senator Mason.

—I thank the honourable senator. The answer that the Acting Minister gave was a perfectly clear statement about the Government's position in relation to this matter. The question now asked by Senator Coates does not add anything to what Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was asked yesterday. I can only reiterate and confirm what she said in answer to yesterday's question. There is really nothing further that the Government can say at this stage in relation to that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Coates asked whether the Government would plead with the United Kingdom to support a ceasefire. I would have thought the Government has made its position quite clear in that it gives the strongest support to the stand the British Government has taken in relation to this matter. Apparently one has to reiterate for the benefit of some Opposition senators that the negotiations which took place for a considerable time broke down primarily because of Argentina's insistence on its sovereignty being acknowledged. That is the fundamental basic issue in this conflict. The Argentinians have asserted sovereignty and have acted aggressively to impose their notions of sovereignty. The British are defending their rights and the rights of--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are defending Vesteys.

—It is very interesting to hear the Opposition talking about defending Vesteys as Senator Button has said. Other Opposition interjections have all suggested that there is something wrong with the British stand, a stand to protect its subjects against clear aggression from the Argentinian Government . The Australian Government's view is that the action and attitude of Britain in regard to this question is to be supported strongly, as I am sure it is by all Australian people except some apparent dissidents in the Australian Labor Party. I will refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs the matter of whether inquiries have been made about British ships carrying nuclear armaments.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I again invite the Acting Leader of the Government, who represents the Prime Minister in the Senate, to deny that the Government is inviting a request from the United Kingdom.

—I said that the answer Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle gave stated the Government's position clearly and accurately. Nothing that was said by her yesterday or anything that I may say today would indicate that the Government is seeking any request from the United Kingdom.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory whether he has seen an article in the Australian Financial Review of today's date headed 'Canberra is first past the post in industrial property review'. The article refers to a report of Jones Lang Wootton on the industrial property market and states that that company has:

QUESTION.PARA: come out with a strong recommendation that industrialists consider relocating to Canberra.
The article goes on to state:
In support of their recommendation they cite six reasons, which are:
Communications are not a problem as there are good road links in most directions.
Very cheap land prices.
Lower building costs than either Sydney or Melbourne.
Cheap rental and purchase prices for established properties.
Incentives offered in Queanbeyan for industries decentralising or developing in the region.
Large pool of skilled, reliable labour, with a history of good industrial relations.

Will the Minister bring this article to the notice of the Department of the Capital Territory and the Canberra Development Board with a view to seeing that these facts are widely publicised? Will the Minister also see that the Government looks at the report it called for, seeking suggestions as to incentives--

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring!

—Which may be offered to people coming to Canberra with a view to seeing that action is taken on the incentives as soon as possible so that the national capital is put in a similar position as other States and towns with respect to offering incentives for people to take up these opportunities?

—This question follows the debate yesterday in this place concerning the Fraser Government's economic strategies in relation to the Australian Capital Territory. It is interesting that that motion was proposed by Senator Ryan on behalf of the Opposition, but we now hear claims from the other side that such matters, which are constructive for the development of Canberra, are in fact boring and that no one wants to hear of them. I, for one-I know that this is the case with honourable senators on this side-am very interested in matters which will advance the future of Canberra. Certainly this is one of those constructive things which is implicit in Senator Reid's question. This was referred to at length both by Senator Reid and me during the debate on the Australian Capital Territory in this place yesterday. It clearly identifies with the policy of this Government and that of the Minister for the Capital Territory in trying to encourage private enterprise into this area. Plainly there are advantages to businesses locating in this area, as is outlined in the article referred to by Senator Reid. We would expect that people might have their attention drawn to those particular points. I will certainly bring that article to the attention of the Minister for the Capital Territory and also to the Canberra Development Board and ensure that it is given the fullest possible airing.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Does the announcement by the Minister for Administrative Services that the Government has set a target of 40 per cent to 45 per cent of survey work to be contracted out to the private sector signify a running down of the work of the Australian Survey Office? Is this particularly so given that currently some 10 per cent to 15 per cent of government survey work already goes to the private sector? Further, can the Minister give an assurance that the Australian Survey Office will remain a strong viable unit with career opportunities within the Office, and that staff surveyors will not face the prospect of redeployment or redundancy as a result of the razor gang decisions to transfer survey services to the private sector?

—This is obviously a question which no doubt could have been canvassed during the Estimates committee hearings in relation to the Department of Administrative Services. I have no information as to whether it was. There are a number of detailed matters on this point on which obviously I do not have immediate information. I will refer it to the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman. I undertake to do so for Senator Gietzelt and to bring down an early reply for him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EXPORT OF OIL DRILLING EQUIPMENT: UNITED STATES EMBARGO

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs . I refer to a report in today's Australian that Japan is seeking Soviet oil and gas off Sakhalin Island but that development cannot proceed because of the United States embargo on the export of drilling equipment. The article suggests that tapping of the nearby oil and liquefied natural gas would make Japan more confident in negotiating with Australia on prices for coal and North West Shelf liquefied petroleum gas. In view of that suggestion, what is the Government's current attitude to the embargo?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no information on the matter. I ask that the question be placed on notice. I will see that an early response is given.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY ACTIVITIES IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, either in his capacity as Attorney-General or as Minister representing the Prime Minister. It refers to a 60 Minutes program screened on Sunday, 23 May, during which Mr Christopher Boyce, described as a self-admitted Soviet spy, claimed that the Central Intelligence Agency cheated Australia of intelligence information gained at secret United States bases in Australia, including Pine Gap. Recognising that the Opposition has expressed concern that the role of the Central Intelligence Agency in Australia is not subject to the control of the Australian Government, irrespective of political persuasion, will the Minister advise whether the Government is satisfied that it has been fully briefed on the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency and the role of the United States bases in Australia, whether the Australian intelligence organisations have conducted any inquiry into foreign intelligence organisations in this country, and whether he considers that such serious allegations as those made on 60 Minutes require a thorough investigation?

—I did not see, and I have not seen a transcript of, the interview referred to by Senator Coleman. I heard in general terms about the matter. As the question raises matters requiring serious consideration and attention, I will take notice of it and give a considered answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PENSIONERS LIVING BELOW THE POVERTY LINE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In a recent report in the Examiner of 25 May the Launceston City Missioner said that 35 new families each month came to the Mission for help, in addition to those already on the books. He said that one of the real tragedies is that people are far more desperate than is realised. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that there are nearly 380,000 children of people on various types of pensions in Australia, almost all living below the poverty line. Does the Minister not agree that this is a shameful situation? When will the social security benefits be raised to above the poverty line to allow people to live in dignity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the report mentioned by the honourable senator in her question. She referred to the difficulties of people who are on pensions and who have children. She asked when pensions and benefits would be raised. The setting of pensions and benefits is, of course, a matter for Budget consideration. I am in no position to anticipate what decisions might be taken by the Government over the coming months and announced in the Budget. With respect to the Government's approach to the question of those in the community who are on low incomes, I point to the major commitment the Government has made to the indexation of the great majority of benefits which ensures that on two occasions in each year there are adjustments to the bulk of benefits paid by my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: I point to the fact that the 1976 change to the family allowance principally affected the sorts of families to which Senator Hearn referred-families which gain no assistance from the tax deductions, which until that time were a substantial part of the benefit provided for families and which provided a greater degree of assistance to the well-off than to those with low incomes. Since 1976 the same level of assistance has been provided to low income families as to all families, which puts us in an unusual position in the whole of the Western world. Over recent years there have been adjustments to pensions and to the additional allowances which are payable for children.

Having said that, I accept that a proportion of those who receive pensions and benefits from my Department do have difficulty in meeting their requirements. We responded in the last Budget to some of the areas which we saw as being high areas of need. The adjustment to supplementary assistance was meant to be a step in the direction of assisting those who are identified as being likely to be in need, such as those paying high private rents. The adjustment in family allowances for larger families is an adjustment which affected a selection of families who are statistically shown to be more likely to be in difficulty. I think there is an obligation upon the Government to try to identify those sections of the community in which people are living at a standard which is below what we would regard as reasonable in Australia and to try to make the necessary adjustments.

Having said all that-Question Time is not the time to make a speech on these matters-and in endeavouring to respond to the honourable senator, I would simply point out that the Government's ability to respond to the many additional demands which are made on the welfare system is inhibited by the fact that over a period of 10 years we have gone from about one million people seeking income support from the Commonwealth to about 2.2 million to 2.3 million people. There has been a very substantial real increase in expenditure in this field, quite apart from those increased numbers, and the contribution which is required from taxpayers has increased to a very marked extent. Bearing in mind that the party which Senator Hearn is a part of is demanding tax cuts-Mr Willis is demanding very substantial income tax cuts in the coming Budget-and bearing in mind that her party has disavowed any question of new forms of taxation in its desperate attempt to get into government, I would throw the challenge back to them to indicate from what source additional payments ought to be made, because I think there is a very great difficulty in meeting the very extensive demands which are made on the welfare system in this country without very substantial increases in taxation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Justice Michael Kirby, the Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, when indicating in an article that the Commission had been requested by the Federal Government in 1976 to produce a report on the law that should govern human tissue transplants, said:

QUESTION.PARA: In the long run it may not be entirely safe to leave it to scientists and business interests (groups who are bound to be enthusiastic about pushing forward the limits of genetic manipulation) to state finally the terms upon which they will do so.
Can the Minister advise the Senate as to the present stand the Government has taken on the matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what work Mr Justice Kirby and his Law Reform Commission have done lately on the question of human tissue transplants, or on the ethical issues which these raise. It would be wrong to suggest, however, that those who have been involved in transplantation or research in this area do not have a sense of responsibility or an appreciation of the problems for the community of the work which they are undertaking. I recall that the National Health and Medical Research Council in one of the areas akin to transplantation- that is, the question of in vitro fertilisation-has recently taken some very positive steps to examine the ethical issues involved. I recall that some years ago some of the researchers in that area tried to get some of the churches to take on a consideration of the ethical issues. I understand that one of the State governments is moving to examine its responsibilities in this area. It is appropriate for Senator Kilgariff to ask what is the present position of the Federal Government. I will seek from the Minister for Health an up to date statement and make it available to the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF FILM STUDIO COMPLEX IN CANBERRA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. In relation to the development of a multi-million dollar film studio complex in Canberra, what is the Australian content or involvement in the company United American and Australasian Film Production Pty Ltd? What is the estimated cost of construction of this complex? If the Australian financial content is less than the requirement set by the Foreign Investment Review Board, can the Minister inform the Senate when a decision will be made in relation to this proposed development?
—I ask Senator Jones to put that question on notice.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Will the Minister ask the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to consider clarifying the position of sales tax exemption for four-wheel drive vehicles used for primary production? I have received several submissions from Western Australian pastoralists which make the point that two almost identical vehicles are treated totally differently with regard to the application of this tax.

—It transpires that, notwithstanding the disappearance of the ministry of Business and Consumer Affairs, I am still here and apparently representing that aspect of the Government's activities. I think the Minister for Industry and Commerce is now responsible for that area. I will refer to him the question which the honourable senator has asked and will ask for an early reply.

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, follows a question asked by Senator Walsh earlier today. I ask: Will the Minister confirm that the Government continues to accept fully the guidelines of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest, albeit somewhat weak and extraordinary as they are? If the Government does accept those guidelines, can the Minister tell the Senate whether the Minister for Primary Industry, in the terms of Bowen recommendation 8.6, informed the Prime Minister or the Acting Prime Minister last Wednesday that he was involved in an apparent conflict of interest? Did he tell either the Prime Minister or the Acting Prime Minister that he continued to hold shares in the Murray Goulburn Co-Op. Co. Ltd, one of the companies to which advances have been made by the Australian Dairy Corporation and one of the companies which, presumably, should have a penalty imposed on it with the Minister having the power to fix that rate of penalty?

—Yes, I certainly can confirm on behalf of the Government its adherence to the guidelines recommended by the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. The Bowen Inquiry was set up by the Government and when it reported the Government adopted its guidelines in regard to ministerial conduct. They have been in operation now for some years. I do not know the exact date on which they came into operation. There is no question as to the Government's adherence to the guidelines laid down. As I indicated earlier in answer to Senator Walsh, there is some dispute in relation to one aspect of the interpretation of the guidelines. This dispute arose, according to his version of them, in relation to a previous matter concerning Mr Nixon. Indeed, the second part of Senator Button's question possibly raises that same question again. As the Prime Minister said when this matter was raised previously, Mr Nixon had disclosed the shares that he holds in Murray Goulburn Co-Op. Co. Ltd. It was explained that he holds those shares as a producer of dairy products, it being a requirement that shares be held in the company in order to sell products through it. The same question seems to have arisen again in Senator Button's question. I will refer the matter to the Prime Minister and ask him to provide a detailed answer.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. In the light of the important and vital preventative work done by the National Marriage Guidance Council in saving marriages and thus, incidentally, social security payments, can the Minister give an assurance that funding of the National Marriage Guidance Council will be maintained at at least the same level, in real terms, as it was in 1981-82?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has continued to fund a large number of the marriage counselling organisations that are approved under the Family Law Act. The moneys that are made available to them by way of a grant each year have steadily increased over the years in which the Government has been in office, although the actual rate of increase has varied from year to year depending upon the circumstances of the organisations concerned and the total sum of money that the Government can find available in the Budget context and in the Budget strategy. The same approach is being followed by the Government in regard to the forthcoming Budget. I cannot give any guarantee of any specific amount being available to marriage counselling organisations as a whole or individual organisations. These are matters that will have to be decided by the Government in the Budget context.

ANSWER.PARA: I think Senator Watson can take some assurance of continued funding of a substantial character of counselling organisations from the past performance of the Government in this regard. Also in a speech I made two or three months ago, which was fairly widely reported, I indicated the very great value that the Government attaches to the work of the marriage counselling organisations. It is not limited to the Marriage Guidance Council; there is a number of such counselling organisations. We appreciate and attach significance to the work of these organisations. These are all matters that will be given serious weight in discussions about funding in the coming year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to the dairy loans controversy. Mr Burston, who is a member of the Australian Dairy Corporation and General Manager of Colac Dairying Company Ltd, Victoria, has thrown some confusion into the matter. I wonder whether the Minister can explain the situation. Mr Burston said on AM this morning and is reported in the Age as saying that no gain had been made by that company from the late repayment because it did not have the money and did not have the stock. Am I to understand that the money was used to pay the farmers? Was extended credit given to a distributing company? Was that the intention of the loans of the Reserve Bank of Australia? To which company was this credit extended? For how long was the credit extended? I ask the Minister whether, because of the confusing answers that are coming from various directions, he will make a clear statement tomorrow to the Senate as to what actually is the case, the manner in which the loans were made and the way in which the loans are being used by the recipient companies.

—I do not have precise information on the matters raised. I will not add to any confusion which may be abroad on this question by endeavouring to give an answer based on supposition. However, on the question of whether a gain was made by any company which had not repaid an advance, that would depend on the general financial position of the company and on the use to which the money was put. That could vary considerably from case to case. The companies receiving the money were paying interest on that money. I think the rate was 15.75 per cent. They had a liability which was accruing to them while they had the money and that, of course, was a cost to them. It would only be if the retention of the money involved their getting a benefit over and above that cost of 15.75 per cent or if, for example, it prevented them from having to borrow at a higher interest rate that any gain would accrue. The position could vary from case to case. I mention that it would be difficult-I do not think it would be possible- to generalise on the level of gain which might have been made by any of those people, without examination of the particular facts and circumstances. As far as Mr Burston's statement is concerned, I do not know whether I am pleased or sorry that I was not able to listen to AM this morning; but I was not. I have not seen a transcript. I have not seen the remarks. I have not seen the report in the Age . Although I have seen some news clips relating to this matter, I do not recall seeing any clip from the Age or indeed any clip which quotes Mr Burston. I will examine the matter and will certainly try to advise the Senate by tomorrow of the answers to the questions raised by the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —To return to matters which were touched upon in the previous question, a couple of questions were raised yesterday on which I have been provided with some additional information which I would like to put before the Senate. The position of Mr Peter Lever-Naylor was raised in a question yesterday. I am advised that he retired from the Nestle Company Australia Ltd on 30 June 1978 and that he occupied the position of manager of the production division prior to retirement. In June 1981 he acted as an adviser to the Minister of Rural and Industrial Development in Sri Lanka, as a result of the Minister's request to the Nestle company in Sri Lanka, on the administration of the dairy industry in that country. He has had no business association with the Nestle Company Australia Ltd since his retirement in June 1978. He was originally appointed as a representative of manufacturers on the board of the Australian Dairy Corporation on 1 July 1977 and following his retirement from the Nestle Company Australia Ltd was appointed as a member with special qualifications on 1 July 1978, and he still occupies that position. Therefore, it is clear that Mr Peter Lever-Naylor has had no association with the Nestle Company Australia Ltd since his retirement on 30 June 1978 and therefore has not been involved in any way in that company's business since that time.

ANSWER.PARA: Questions were also raised by Senator Button, indeed in Question Time earlier today, about the review of loans provided to manufacturers by the ADC. I have been provided with the following information. Four times in each financial year -in September, December, March and June-the Corporation requires manufacturers to certify the amount of product held in approved stores and on which loans have been made by the Corporation. These returns are then reconciled with Corporation records. Additionally, since the establishment of the Corporation's internal audit unit in 1978 periodic checks of stock levels on which loans have been made have been part of the unit's work program. These checks have ascertained several discrepancies of an insignificant nature which have been rectified. Prior to 1978 and since the scheme's inception in 1975, as indicated by Senator Button in his question, there has always been a requirement for quarterly certification by manufacturers detailing stocks held for which the loans have been made. The ADC advises that all the discrepancies of an insignificant nature which have been detected in the past and which have been rectified have been bookkeeping matters involving small quantities of stock and there is no indication of any intent on the part of the manufacturers to deceive. The entire system is available to the staff of the Commonwealth Auditor-General for scrutiny as part of the Corporation's total financial operations.

Senator Button also asked me when the ADC's current inquiry would be completed . The ADC has advised that it is hoped to have the inquiry completed by the end of next week. It will certainly be completed in time for the next board meeting of the ADC, which is scheduled to take place on 17 June.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Briefly, I think that the conduct at Question Time today displayed the hypocrisy of the Opposition in its frequent calls in the past against a practice which is exhibited, in this chamber, maybe subtly from time to time, but blatantly today. The paper tabled by Senator Ryan shows very clearly that the question put to her today by Senator Colston was prepared by her or in her office. Whilst I am not criticising questions being directed to a shadow spokesman, this matter is such a clear example of a self- serving party political device that it must be noted as illustrating the hypocrisy of various calls made from time to time by the Opposition. I wonder whether Senator Ryan asked Senator McLaren to ask the question. He hesitated, but eventually Senator Colston succumbed to her request to put the question today. I want to underline the fact that in the conduct of Question Time today the procedures of the Senate were blatantly abused. The Opposition may jeer, cry and growl at the moment, but this is the kind of accusation which it makes from time to time and it illustrates the hypocrisy of such criticisms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question asked by Senator Missen and the answer given to that question be noted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges sought leave to move his motion. I do not want to see a great debate starting at this point.

—I will not debate the question. The Government must realise that it misuses Question Time. We could pick up the question in this way. I seek leave to continue my remarks later in order to put the matter on the Notice Paper as the question and answer are important.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Teague was talking about hypocrisy . He is probably the person best qualified to speak about hypocrisy in this chamber. He made accusations about Senator Ryan preparing a question to be asked either by Senator McLaren or me. Mr Deputy President, I point out that the question I asked was initiated by myself so that I could ask a question of Senator Ryan in this chamber about a very important Bill. Time after time in this chamber honourable senators opposite throw Dorothy Dixers to Ministers and we have had to sit here and cop it while they prostitute Question Time in such a way. If they continue to do that they will occasionally have to expect that honourable senators on this side will ask questions of other honourable senators who have passage of a Bill in this place. Excellent Bills are being prepared by honourable senators on this side, and it is quite in order for us to ask those questions. If Senator Teague wants to make comments about Senator Ryan preparing a question that has been given to people on this side, he should have proof of that before he says so. I reiterate that the question I asked today was initiated by me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Teague raised an important matter about questions on notice and questions without notice being put to Ministers. Of course I agree with Senator Colston insofar as a hypocritical attitude has been taken by Senator Teague. Senator Teague well knows that on his side of this place at least half the questions asked are Dorothy Dixers; they are questions about which notice has been given to the Minister and answers are readily available. The answers are often so long winded that even the President from time to time has had to direct the Minister answering the question to keep his answer concise, precise and relevant. We have seen Ministers read from long- winded, prepared answers to questions of which notice clearly has been given by the senators on the Government side.

SPEECH.PARA: It is suggested that we have erred in this area. When Opposition senators are conscientiously seeking information in respect of government administration we invariably get a reply from Ministers that they will refer the matter to the relevant Minister in the other place. We do not get adequate information because the Minister of whom we have asked a question represents a Minister in another place and is not fully aware of the matters which we ask about. Therefore, nine times out of 10 we get inadequate answers to our question. That is particularly so of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and other senior Government Ministers. They do not provide us with the essential information.

On this occasion we are concerned about the shortness of the parliamentary sitting and about the fact that time is not available for us to debate matters which we regard as important. I refer to Senator Ryan's private member's Bill and to Senator Evans's Bill. The Government is not prepared to make time available to have these matters dealt with in the autumn session; they will languish for another three or four months before they are dealt with. I think it is about time that Senator Teague realised that he is not the Government's Mr Falwell.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President--
—For goodness sake, do you really want the thing to blow up?
—Yes. I seek leave to make a statement about Question Time this morning. My name has been mentioned.
—Is leave granted?
—Mr Deputy President, I hope that we are not going to embark along a long road.
—I had sought leave.
—I will hear Senator Durack for a moment.

—Senator Teague has had his say. Two Opposition senators have been given leave to speak on the same subject. I would have hoped that the subject might be put at an end. I suggest that honourable senators let us get on with the business of the day.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen has sought leave to make a statement on a matter raised by Senator Teague. Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: — I make this statement because I heard in my room, of course without any notice being given to me, a motion being moved that a question that I asked this morning and the answer given be noted. I find now that that matter has been put off. However, the matter has already been drawn to the attention of the people in Australia and to the Press. Obviously there is a snide implication that I asked a Dorothy Dix question, which I never do, and about which I have the strongest objection. I want to make it perfectly clear that I certainly give Ministers notice of questions when I want facts in regard to matters such as dieback in trees, which I raised this morning. I give notice of such questions so that I can get some information. I make it perfectly clear that no Minister suggests to me that I should ask a certain question. I want to say-I have said it many times-that it is proper for honourable senators to seek information. What is not proper, I think, is for honourable senators to ask questions about matters on which Ministers want to make a statement. Ministers ought to do that by way of statements. I have said that before and I say it again but I make it clear because this morning nobody on the other side of the chamber had the courtesy to tell me that a motion would be moved in regard to my question. I make it clear that it was no Dorothy Dixer.

—by leave-I claim to be misrepresented by Senator Missen. Mr Deputy President, I moved a motion that the Senate take note of the question and answer. If Senator Missen had been listening carefully he would have heard that I said the question and answer were important. I moved the motion so that the matter could be placed on the Notice Paper for further debate . The reason I did that is that dieback concerns me. It is a problem not only in Victoria but also throughout the whole of Australia. That matter should be examined in depth by the Senate. That is the reason I moved that motion. I think Senator Missen misunderstood what I was doing. I merely sought to place the matter on the Notice Paper for further debate.

—by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Teague. Senator Teague claimed that Senator Ryan requested me to use Standing Order 98 to ask her a question in relation to a Bill standing in her name on the Notice Paper. He then went on to accuse honourable senators on this side of the chamber of being hypocrites. He further said that I had refused Senator Ryan's request. I make it quite clear that at no stage did Senator Ryan approach me; I did not refuse any request from her. I remind Senator Teague that people who live in glass houses should not throw stones. On my files I have many documents which I asked to be tabled in this Parliament. They relate to questions to be asked by certain senators-I think I have a couple of such questions from Senator Walters-and the proposed answers. If honourable senators on this side have now indulged in that sort of operation the disease must be catching. It was started by honourable senators on the other side. They have little cause to accuse senators on this side of being hypocrites and of doing things which we did not do. I claim Senator Teague was quite wrong in making that accusation.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This morning Senator Chaney provided some information as a consequence of questions asked yesterday in respect of Mr Peter Lever-Naylor. I would like Senator Chaney to follow up responses to the question asked yesterday. My point is that the information provided today was not adequate. The information sought yesterday was in relation to the period during which the Nestle Company Australia Ltd was involved in a breach of provisions and misuse of funds. I asked whether Mr Peter Lever-Naylor was involved with the Nestle company at that time. I do not think the information Senator Chaney provided was an adequate response to those questions. I make this statement in response to the co-operative nature in which Senator Chaney has approached this matter in the last couple of days.
