DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Fraser Government to provide leadership at a time of great social and economic difficulty.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the Senate will adjourn this week so perhaps it is a good opportunity for honourable senators to leave this place with something to think about. That is why this matter of public importance has been submitted. Essentially it relates to the failure of the Government to provide leadership in relation to some very important problems facing this country. I think in all fairness it can be said that when the Fraser Government was elected in 1975 and again in 1977 it promised an alternative view of Australian society. It promised new leadership, better government, better economic management and a whole range of things. Indeed, the rhetoric of those heady days is familiar to all honourable senators in this chamber and should particularly be familiar to members of the Liberal Party. It was said that, if the Fraser Government were elected, inflation would be drastically reduced, interest rates would fall by 2 per cent, anyone who wanted to work in Australia would get a job, Medibank would be maintained, the Prices Justification Tribunal would be retained, taxes would be reduced and the tax rip-off would be ended. It was said there would be no more tourists as Prime Minister and that there would be new standards of propriety in government and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The average Australian listening to those claims in 1975 and 1977 would, I think, be quite entitled to say: 'Well, that sounds pretty good. Those things will probably make this a better place to live in'. But the question which we address to the Senate now is: What does Mr or Mrs Average Australian say now? What do they understand now both about those matters and about current problems in terms of response to those problems from this Government? Let me just remind honourable senators about the current situation. Inflation is running at 10 1/2 per cent, which is one per cent above the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. We have the highest interest rates ever. We have the highest unemployment since the Great Depression. We have an enormously increased tax burden on lower income earners and tax avoidance estimated by Professor Russell Mathews to represent a 20 per cent loss in personal income tax revenue to the Government because of tax avoidance schemes. We have no universal health insurance scheme; we have a decline in the level of home ownership in Australia; we have a Prime Minister who is continually gyrating around the world advocating grandiose schemes for curing world problems and ignoring the problems which this country faces. We have a scandal-ridden Ministry. Twenty-one Ministers have been replaced since the Fraser Government came to power. Thirteen former Ministers have been appointed to jobs for the boys, which were going to be abolished, and we have a situation of economic management which can be summarised only as the classic example of all these defects of the Government. As Professor Russell Mathews put it in an important paper earlier this year:
It--
That is, the Commonwealth-

has used its centralised financing powers to return to the thoroughly discredited policies of the Great Depression involving acceptance of high levels of unemployment at the same time as urgent capital works are deferred for lack of funds.

All of these things which go to the living standards of ordinary Australians can be summed up in a sense, though, in one quite dramatic figure. In 1976, when the Fraser Government came to power, in terms of per capita income Australia was No. 8 on a list of OECD countries. In 1981 it had dropped from No. 8 to No. 15-a fair drop down the hit parade in six short years. Only recently we were passed by Japan. So what became of Fraser's new society which was promised in 1975 and 1977? What is the situation of the society in which we now live, with chronic problems of unemployment, poor economic management, continuing inflation, declining home ownership and growing poverty? Where are the promises and where is the vision for the future as to how long this sort of society will continue under this Government? Are people not entitled to ask, on the record of this Government: Will unemployment still be around at the present level in the year 2000 if this Government remains in power? Will inflation still be running at current levels? Will we still be without universal health insurance schemes, with a declining value in pensions and with a decline in government services such as is continually apparent if one looks at the major government instrumentalities designed to provide services to the Australian people? What strategies does the Government have to deal with this current crisis in social and economic policy created by government policies? Let us look at the decline in government services to which I have referred. Although I cannot go into detail in a short speech, let me make just a few points. Hospitals in Australia are now starved for funds. The Australian Broadcasting Commission, a once great national broadcasting service, has been deliberately run down by this Government to the point where it has become something of a joke. Telecom Australia is another great public instrumentality. But because of Government policies in relation to capital loan raising it is unable to provide the sorts of services which a national telecommunications network should provide, which the national public-owned telecommunications networks in most countries provide.

In six years under this Government there has been declining access to education , declining retention rates in schools and declining access to post-secondary education. In terms of this Government's commitments to the rural sector of the Australian community, there have been: A series of scandals in relation to subsidy schemes; the abolition by the Government of the Decentralisation Advisory Board which, to the credit of the Government-it was a Fraser Government initiative-was successfully encouraging industry development in provincial cities in Australia; and the complete abdication of any responsibility the Commonwealth Government has towards land degradation in the vast rural areas of Australia. All of those areas of government service are declining at the same time as standards of living for the Australian people are declining. The taxation system which, in a sense, is a linchpin-if I can use that unfortunate expression in the context of this Parliament-is in a mess. I again use Professor Mathews's words:

If governments were to set out deliberately to design a taxation system which would redistribute income from the poor to the rich, which would substantially relieve the rich of the cost of financing social welfare transfers and public services; which would consciously discriminate against wage and salary incomes in favour of other incomes and capital gains, which would distort the pattern of consumption and production, and which would provide a major stimulus to wage inflation and industrial conflict, it would be difficult for them to develop a set of tax arrangements that would be more successful in meeting such perverse objectives than the existing Australian system.

No doubt if Senator Sir John Carrick were here he would say that it was all the fault of the Whitlam Government. This Government has been in office for seven years. When it came to office it accepted responsibility for these things. That is what one does when one is in government. It is no good blaming it on the trade unions, on what is happening overseas, on various interest groups in the community, on the Opposition, or on anybody else who might be mentioned, because it is a government's responsibility to provide leadership. Instead of doing that this Government has become a scapegoat government. Everybody is to blame except the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and his Ministers. Instead of leadership we have had government by inquiry and government by experiment.

Let us look at the inquiries commissioned by this Government at great cost, in respect of which no action has been taken. I mention just a sample. What has happened to the report of the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment in the hands of this Government, with continuing conflict between the dries and the wets in the Fraser Government? We had the report of the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia which was central in a sense to continued industrial development in this country. It was central to social equity and the issues of income redistribution and sharing of burdens. Perhaps it was not a good report but it was a very important report in terms of the concept involved. We have the report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission which has been languishing for 18 months without a government decision. We have the report of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment-the Fraser Government's document which was to provide a blueprint for education to the year 2000. What has happened to the blueprint? It is grey with dust now. But nothing has been done in any sense about its recommendations. There has been no response from this Government. Instead, the Government has engaged in a few little ideological experiments with the Australian people. The sorts of social experiments in which this Government engages remind me of those horror movies in which some unfortunate corpse is placed on a table and operated on by Dr Crippen or somebody such as that.

First, it has flirted with monetarism, which Shirley Williams has accurately described as a convenient philosophy arriving at the right time to fill the vacuum in conservative thought. Secondly, it has flirted with a commitment to deregulation. As a result, numerous inquiries all over the place are working out how things can be deregulated. The results of most of those inquiries will only lead to a different system of regulation, perhaps more comprehensive than the present system. There is a conservative case for continuity of development in relation to public institutions; a case which this Government seems to ignore. Thirdly, there was the extraordinary experiment of the razor gang. It was heralded as something which would save the Australian taxpayer $560m. That, of course, is a joke. People know that as a result of the razor gang's activities taxpayers will have to pay more. One sample of the razor gang's activities in Sydney concerns the servicing of Commonwealth cars by private enterprise. It now costs four times as much as it cost to have it done in a Commonwealth garage. That is just one example, but it is a graphic one. It is typical of the razor gang's activities. The cosmetic changes to the Australian Wool Testing Authority 's constitutional basis is another example of its absurd activities. After 12 months Sir Phillip Lynch abandoned the notion that the razor gang would save $ 560m. On 18 February of this year he said:

. . . it was not a review of expenditure levels or public service staffing, rather, it was an attempt to chart a realistic role for Australia's Federal Government in the special circumstance of the 1980s.

I would like to hear from him what he thinks about the special circumstances of 1982 in terms of social and economic equality and the Government's economic management. He said that it was not a cost cutting exercise at all; that people had made a mistake about that. I suppose he thought that it was just a little bit of pre-election propaganda. Afterwards, Professor Mathews, to whom I referred earlier, had this to say:
The main purpose of the Review of Commonwealth Functions seemed to be concerned not with improving efficiency in government--
Contrary to Sir Phillip Lynch's view-
but rather with reducing the Commonwealth Budget deficit by shifting expenditure responsibilities to the States or by disposing of Commonwealth property and activities to private enterprise.

I say again that there is a case for continuity in relation to these matters. The fourth great ideological experiment of this Government was the so-called new federalism policy. It is a shambles in terms of its failure upon implementation. I do not want to quote Professor Mathews again but, as this Government's leading expert on federalism, the words that he has chosen to use to describe the system are less than charitable. I put it to the Government that there is a case for avoiding ideological experiments of either extreme in the tragic situation in which this country finds itself. Politicians such as Sir Robert Menzies understood the value of continuity in politics. In Australia we have a mixed economy. There is value in continuity in the development of such an economy with the public sector being well developed and looked after and the private sector being encouraged by an impartial government-not a government which hands out favours all over the place to particular friends, but one which is impartial in its encouragement of the development of the private sector. With such a government we can develop a much more balanced society without all the disturbances which come from ideological commitments, most of them imported, to the sorts of bizarre views I have mentioned, the bizarre experiments in deregulation, razor gangs, monetarism, new federalism-all the slogans of the Fraser Government which would clutter a large sized ballot box if they were all put in there together.

Instead of that, of course, we have had scapegoat government, government by inquiry, government which avoids responsibilities by blaming other sections of the community, governments in which the Prime Minister makes speeches written by Owen Harries and in which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) reads speeches for the Prime Minister in Adelaide and governments which talk about the importance of the philosophy underlying the Government's actions. What is the philosophy underlying the Government's actions now which will lead Australia out of the present mess? Instead, the Government, for example, promises export led recovery at one election and a resource boom led recovery at the next. Take Treasurer Howard, for example, that pea green incorruptible of the Liberal Government and a latter-day Robespierre. On 10 October 1980- conveniently a week or two before an election-he said that the expected resources boom would create tens of thousands of jobs. On 11 November 1981 he changed his tune and referred to the so-called resources boom as a term which he tried to avoid using. In the same month the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) said:
I therefore back away from calling the current developments a boom.
That was the thing that was going to create tens of thousands of jobs, something which all Australians are legitimately concerned about when they look to the future.

As I said, we have had a situation which entitles people now to ask: 'Where are the answers from this Government for next year? But more importantly where are the answers for 10 years hence about where this society is going? Where is the equivalent vision that we were offered in 1975 and 1977? Can it all be achieved by a few tax bribes at the next election or is there some overall economic strategy which tax cuts would be a part of, or is it just a few throw-away bribes, the old pattern of conservative government? Where is the leadership out of current social and economic difficulties? When are we going to have a prices policy and an incomes policy?'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will just finish this sentence.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Consensus is the important question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an extraordinary note for the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) to finish his speech on. He more or less had to be sat down. He did abide by the consensus , and I give him credit for that. Perhaps it was a fitting end to a speech which showed quite a deal of promise in the title that he chose for it, but which failed dismally to deliver the sort of attack which I think he intended. The Leader of the Opposition introduced for debate in the Senate today a matter of public importance which he called:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Fraser Government to provide leadership at a time of great social and economic difficulty.

I thought that this was to be some sort of mid-term debate on economic and social policies in relation to which the views of the Government may conflict with those of the Opposition. Instead of Senator Button concentrating his fire on one or two major issues, he sprayed that fire in all directions and in, I thought, a very inconsequential and disconnected way tried to rely on a number of throw-away lines and trigger words which were designed to create some sense of unease about the present situation. He did not firmly put a coherent alternative policy, something which one would have expected from the Leader of the Opposition; nor indeed did he concentrate a major attack on the policies of the Government. He ended by asking: 'Where are the answers?' I propose to address my remarks to that question. It is interesting that the Leader of the Opposition has to ask that question and does not provide, or even wait for, an answer. I notice that he is leaving the chamber. He does not seek to provide any answer at all to the major questions which are facing us. (Quorum formed). The Leader of the Opposition, having asked where the answers are without having provided them, proceeded to depart, although I see that he had to remain for the quorum. Obviously very few Opposition senators are interested in the answers because very few of them answered the bells for the quorum.

TALK.START.PARA: —They deliberately walked out to express their disinterest in their own matter of public importance.

—Perhaps they were following their leader in that regard. The Opposition has introduced a matter of public importance. I think its response to it, the attitude it has expressed and the quorum that was called are indications of how much faith it has in its own proposition. Of course, we have to go back to see the problems that the Government has faced. Senator Button said that the Government has been in office now for 6 1/2 years. He said that the Government now has to take responsibility for the problems that are facing the nation. Of course, the Government has to take that responsibility, and has shouldered it for 6 1/2 years. But it is important to note that the Government accepted that responsibility after the debacle of the Labor years of 1972 to 1975. Certainly we are accepting the responsibility now, but we accepted it in 1975. It is just as well that we accepted responsibility in 1975 because of the debacle that faced Australia at that time as a result of those years of an Australian Labor Party government.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the economic indicators. By 1975 inflation was running at the rate of 16 per cent to 17 per cent. That had a most devastating impact on the Australian economy. I think that apart from the Depression that was probably the most devastating blow the Australian economy has ever suffered. This situation was brought about by the totally irresponsible economic policies of the Labor Government of those years.

I do not want to dwell on that because quite clearly we are now dealing with circumstances seven years on from that period. We are debating the question of which party is better suited to cope with the problems that Australia is facing and may face in the future. I think it is important to note the record of the Labor Party in the years it was in government and to compare the record of the present Government which shows a steady improvement in Australia's position over the years it has been in office. This Government tackled effectively the problem of inflation. The level of inflation which was created by Labor policies is well and truly down. But the serious and devastating truth is that the Labor Party does not tell us about policies which will maintain the growth and stability which has been achieved or which will encourage the level of investment which has been achieved in the years of the Fraser Government.

Certainly, inflation was a major problem and we had to pursue very tough restraints on government expenditure and take unpopular stands in regard to wage and salary restraint in order to cope with that very serious problem. But those policies, as sound and as important to maintain as they are, of course are policies which are unpopular. I think it is a measure of the leadership of the Fraser Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that we have been able to keep our nerve and our heads and maintain those policies which are vital if this country is to be able to maintain levels of inflation which are not out of proportion with those of the rest of our trading partners, which are not devastating to the confidence of the people and which are not destructive of people's savings to which inflation is such a threat. These policies must continue to be maintained.

Senator Button asks where are the answers. The first and foremost answer is that the Government will maintain those responsible policies of economic management which we have pursued for the last six and a half years. But the most difficult problem of all that we had to face in those early years that we were in government was to restore a sense of confidence in Australia, to restore a confidence by Australians in their own economy and in their own future, to restore the confidence of overseas investors in Australia as a sound place for investment. That was the problem we had to face in 1975. I believe that one of the most important achievements of the Fraser Government over the last six and a half years has been the great success it has had in restoring the confidence of which I speak. Confidence was utterly destroyed by three years of Labor. If Labor were given the chance to govern again I have no doubt that it would destroy that confidence because its policies--

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't give us a chance to govern last time.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition was heard in comparative silence. I believe that the Attorney-General is entitled to the same courtesy.
—Could I make a personal explanation?
—Not during his speech.
—I know I have to wait but this is the perfect time to make it.
—The honourable senator may do so after the Minister has finished his speech.
—But, you see, the Leader of the Opposition was not provocative.
—Order! The honourable senator may seek leave to make a personal explanation after the Attorney-General has finished speaking. I call the Attorney-General.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Opposition, of course , having raised a matter of public importance for debate, the Leader of the Opposition having asked for questions to be answered, there seems to be the greatest determination on the part of such few Labor senators who are present in the chamber to frustrate the opportunity of the Government to--
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the state of the House.
—Here is further example of it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Georges

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I have attracted your attention to the state of the House. I have every right to do so in spite of what the Attorney-General had to say.

INTERJECT.PARA: (Quorum formed).

TALK.START.PARA: —In such little time as is now left to me as a result of the constant interventions and quorum calling by the Opposition, I just want to sum up the major problems that the Government has faced and the success that the Government has had in doing so. It took some time, after assuming the responsibility for Labor's debacle, to get inflation rates down to levels where Australia could compete effectively in world trade, which is a most vital matter for us, and it took some years to restore the confidence of overseas investors in Australia and of Australian investors and Australians in Australia's future. This has been achieved in recent years. We have seen some very impressive figures on growth in Australia. The non-farm product growth in the last year or so has gone up to something like 4 per cent which is a very impressive figure. The private capital investment in Australia in the current year is in accordance with the Budget estimates of 10 per cent to 15 per cent real growth. The levels of overseas investment, of course, are back to the historically high levels which applied in the early 1970s before the Labor Government frightened away foreign investment. So there has been growth. There has been the creation of jobs. The Labor Party, of course, has been wanting to persuade the Government to adopt irresponsible policies involving particular forms of artificial job creation. But this Government's policies have created real jobs. Over the last two years more than 200,000 new jobs have been created in Australia. The Government's policy works and the Government will continue to pursue it.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of the name calling in which the Labor Party indulges all the time in this chamber and instead of asking questions I think the Labor Party should tell us how it would be able to achieve a better performance than the Fraser Government. All we have heard from honourable senators opposite, of course, are examples of great increases in expenditure coupled with reductions in taxation. One cannot have the sort of increase in expenditure that Labor wants and reduced taxation at the same time without creating huge deficits-of course, that is what Labor's record shows it has done in the past-and fuelling inflation more and more for the future. That is the only answer I have heard from the Labor Party although today we did not hear any answers from the Leader of the Opposition.

Australia is facing a difficult period in the world economy. Improvements in world trade and the economies of our trading partners are slow. We have to face those problems but they can be faced only by continuing the policies of responsible management which the Fraser Government has followed. All would be put at risk by a government losing its nerve and trying to spend its way out of problems. The problems have to be tackled at the international level. The Prime Minister has given a very real indication of leadership in the initiatives that he has taken recently with regard to easing the restrictions on world trade. I believe that that is the only recipe. We have to tackle the problem at home. We have to tackle the problem abroad. Australia can have every confidence in the continuing leadership of the Fraser Government in the years ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian malaise of the late 1970s and early 1980s incorporates sluggish growth, rising unemployment, a growing incidence of poverty, falling real standard of living for a great proportion of the population, a mood of despair and cynicism and, most serious of all, the potential for social discord and even violence. It has been marked by Australia's progressive descent down the international ladder of economic growth and real incomes. This Government has failed. The evidence can no longer be denied. Contrary to its oft repeated assertions, the record of this Government in respect of critical economic indicators, such as real gross domestic product growth and levels of unemployment, has been dismal when compared with the other countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Compared with the leaders of the OECD-countries such as Austria , West Germany and Japan-this Government's record has been wretched. In the five calendar years 1976 to 1980-all the figures for 1981 are not available and that is the reason I have excluded them; I know there is a temporarily high Australian growth figure for 1981 which will be revised downwards because it incorporates a massive statistical discrepancy-real GDP growth in Australia averaged 2.5 per cent. In the OECD as a whole it was almost 3.5 per cent. Who would have imagined that? Of those who have been listening to the propaganda of this Government who would have imagined that throughout that five-year period- the first five years of the Fraser Government-real GDP growth in Australia was well below the OECD average as a whole?

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has suggested that the Labor Government's record was very poor by international standards. Again, the reverse is the case. For the calendar years 1974 and 1975, which were years of world depression, aggregate growth in the OECD countries as a whole was 0.5 per cent. There was actually a negative growth in 1975. The Australian figure though not brilliant was comparatively high. It was comparatively extremely good. The aggregate figure was 4.7 per cent and in 1975 it was 2.2 per cent. Throughout that period Australia had a growth rate eight times as high as OECD countries as a whole. Since that period we have had growth rates below the OECD as a whole.

Likewise, the same situation applies to unemployment. In the period 1976 to 1980 Australia consistently had a higher rate of unemployment than the OECD average. It has had a rate of unemployment three times higher than the best of the OECD countries which, in this case, is Austria. In only one of the five years from 1976 to 1980 that this Government has been in office-the 1981 figures should not be counted because they will be revised-did the Australian economy achieve a growth rate high enough to maintain pre-existing levels of unemployment, a growth rate high enough to prevent unemployment from actually rising. To prevent unemployment from actually rising a real GDP growth rate of about 4 per cent is required because productivity grows by 2 per cent a year and the work force grows by about 2 per cent a year.

In addition to those dismal growth figures-they are dismal by international standards-what is the snapshot picture of the Australian economy? We have record post-war interest rates, rising unemployment, record taxes which are unjustly distributed and an inflation rate of 10.5 per cent and rising. We heard something about inflation from Senator Durack. We will probably hear more about it from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). Certainly inflation was high in the mid-1970s. When the Labor Government left office, depending on whether one chooses the September or December quarter of 1975 as being the appropriate quarter, inflation was, however, 12 per cent and 13.5 per cent, and it was going down. The trend was downwards. It is now marginally lower, at 10.5 per cent, and the trend is upwards.

This Government has provided no leadership and, indeed, no policies other than an ongoing commitment to redistribute the taxation burden in a regressive way, that is, in a way that has the greatest impact on the lower income groups. It has no coherent or consistent policy. Instead of policy we have seen a succession of stunts. It is not an exhaustive list but a few of the stunts we have seen are new federalism, the prices freeze, the talking up of the resource boom, the razor gang and the latest stunt, the master plan of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for world economic recovery which was unveiled to a completely disinterested United States public and media about two weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you disagree with the basic principles of the plan, Senator?

—One would no more disagree with the basic principles of the plan than one would dispute the multiplication table. It is completely in conflict with the record of this Government in what is actually applied in the specifics of policies. It is even more inappropriate that it should have come from one of the dunces of the OECD class who has the audacity to promote himself to the position of lecturer. If Senator Chaney wants to deal with the specifics of the Prime Minister's proposal perhaps when he speaks after me he might answer this question: If the Prime Minister's proposal is to be taken seriously and is not to be regarded as a cheap stunt for domestic political consumption and ego- boosting abroad, has the Government repudiated the undertaking that it gave to the textiles, clothing and footwear industry that the levels of protection would not be reduced for seven years? The two are incompatible if the Prime Minister's so-called plan is to be taken seriously and not taken as a stunt and if the Government is willing to consider reducing-indeed, if it will reduce-levels of protection to that industry and to all other industries. This cannot be reconciled with the unequivocal commitment that the Government gave to those industries 18 months ago. Perhaps Senator Chaney would care to address himself to that question.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy of the record of the last six years and of our present situation is that it need not have happened; and it need not continue. The common denominator in all of those countries which have maintained acceptable rates of economic growth and low rates of unemployment is an effective prices and incomes policy- whether it is called that or not. Some countries-South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan-have achieved a prices and incomes policy by authoritarian means. Others- Japan and the democracies of northern and central Europe-have achieved it by consensual means. Obviously, that authoritarian option is not one which will be seriously considered in Australia or which should be seriously considered in Australia. Only social consensus is acceptable. A social consensus is a prerequisite to an effective prices and incomes policy which in turn is a prerequisite to maintaining macroeconomic policies which are sufficiently expansionary to restore growth and full employment while simultaneously containing inflation.

A social consensus will not be achieved unless a government has moral authority -and moral authority this Government has not. Whatever goodwill it may have had at the time it was elected was recklessly dissipated and has now been completely exhausted. The Government promised growth and jobs; it gave us stagnation. It promised low taxes; it gave us record taxes unjustly distributed. It promised lower interest rates; it gave us record interest rates. It promised no tourist as a Prime Minister; the Prime Minister gave himself two Boeings at the taxpayers' expense to facilitate his international junketeering. The Government promised no jobs for the boys; we have seen 17 failed politicians appointed to government sinecures. It promised stability; it gave us 21 ministerial sackings, resignations or sideway shifts-sideways shifts right out of Cabinet, I emphasise , as distinct from shifts within the Cabinet. The Government promised ministerial integrity; it gave us Nixon and Sinclair.

How can a government with such a record expect to have-let alone actually command-any moral authority with a Deputy Prime Minister with a soft government loan on which he pays 4.75 per cent interest for his second house in Canberra while people on a fraction of his income pay four times the interest rate? We have a Deputy National Country Party Leader, presently the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair), colloquially known as the 'defendant' being the most experienced defendant in the Fraser Cabinet, although this is a title for which his National Country Party ministerial colleague the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) is currently throwing out a serious challenge. The Minister for Defence is the defendant of the funeral parlour scandal and the defendant of the Senate committee condemnation which said that it preferred the evidence of Mr Webster to the evidence of Mr Sinclair.

We have Mr Nixon who applied National Country Party standards to the personnel of the Australian Dairy Corporation. When Mr Pyle was caught by the Senate committee with his fist in dairy farmers' pockets he was allowed by Mr Nixon to remain on the Corporation. He paid back some of the money that he should not have got in the first place. He was demoted from Deputy Chairman to ordinary board member. I repeat: He was caught with his fist in dairy farmers' pockets and he was allowed to remain on the board. Is it surprising under those circumstances that dairy companies have recently been shown to have misused Reserve Bank of Australia funds following the example of behaviour set by Mr Pyle and accepted by Mr Nixon?

A social consensus is a prerequisite for a prices and incomes policy and an aid to growth-in that sense an end in itself. A social consensus cannot be achieved unless a government has moral authority. The prerequisite of moral authority and such a happier social state being achieved is the removal from office of this dogma-bound government which has no remaining credibility and can never gain any moral authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance brought before it by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Fraser Government to provide leadership at a time of great social and economic difficulty.

I would be prepared to agree that the early 1980s is a period of social and economic difficulty. I think the debate could be conducted with some degree of common ground on that. The social difficulties, are, of course, very much mixed up with the economic difficulties which can be identified in this country and, indeed, in most of the Western world and, I think, in the non-Western world. The economic difficulties which we face are reflected in a declining world trade, in extremely high levels of unemployment around the world with an expected total of some 30 million people unemployed in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Countries and in a situation where inflation is giving rise to very real difficulties and where economic growth is not as high as is required to maintain high levels of employment.

The difficulties that we and other countries face in the economic field in turn produce social difficulties. Recent studies on poverty in Australia clearly indicate that a substantial component of the group in Australia which is in poverty or which can be measured as being in poverty is drawn from the unemployed. Yes, we live in a time where there are some social and economic difficulties. I should mention that some of the social difficulties are related also to the fact that we live in a period of social change. It is well known to honourable senators and I think it is now well known to the public that at least some of the increased social difficulites are caused by marriage breakdown and by a changing sense of responsibilities of spouses to each other and of parents to children. They are matters about which we should all be concerned and which require the attention of Government.

With respect to the debate as put forward by Senator Button, however, I must say that he adopted a scattergun approach to the matter as my colleague the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) said. He referred to a whole list of difficulties some of which touched on the social difficulties to which I intend to address myself in this debate. For example, he referred to declining home ownership. The statistics which we have continue to show that Australia has a remarkable record in the field of home ownership. They show some decline from 1978 to 1980; the regular surveys appear only to be available from 1978 onwards. But we can say that the home ownership rate grew from 52 per cent in 1947 to 63 per cent in 1954. By 1978 it had risen to I think an all-time high of 73.4 per cent and in the latest survey it stands at about 72 per cent. So, yes, there is a small decline and that decline may relate to the problem of interest rates which, again, is a world wide problem.

Senator Button referred to growing poverty. The most recent measures suggest not so much that poverty in Australia has grown in substantial terms but rather that poverty has shifted, with the group in poverty, while remaining fairly constant in number, changing in composition. It is a fact that the number of aged persons living in poverty appears to have declined substantially thanks to the policies of the last 10 years which have increased substantially assistance to that sector. It is quite clear that that has been replaced by a rising number of single parents and by a rising number of long term unemployed people. The problems are different and therefore require fresh solutions.

Senator Button also referred to the declining value of pensions. He knows that the Government has protected the value of pensions-not their value relative to wages but their absolute value compared with the cost of living-by ensuring twice yearly adjustment on an automatic basis. Senator Button asked that we avoid ideology. It seems to me that ideology is not something of which this Government can be accused. He accused us of being monetarists. I defy him to produce an economic commentator who would suggest that this Government has followed strict monetarist policies in its Budget strategies over the last six years. Rather, I would have thought that it would be easy to produce critics who would say that we have not paid a strict regard to monetary theory. I doubt that Senator Button is advocating a disregard of monetary policy and of setting some limits to monetary growth. I think the last Labor person to do that was Dr Cairns when he was Treasurer. He showed a certain disregard for the money supply and he was very swiftly replaced by the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) . I doubt that one would find an economist in Australia who would say that we had strictly adhered to, say, the principle of free trade. Indeed, we had criticism from the second speaker for the Opposition, Senator Walsh, who suggested that we were less than pure in that regard. I suggest that the Government has shown a proper concern for the realities in the selection of its policies. I would not wish to repeat the arguments put forward by Senator Durack which set out the approaches we adopted to some of the basic problems faced by this country.

Senator Walsh drew attention to Australia's good growth record for the years 1974 and 1975 under Labor, campared with the general growth record of the OECD countries. In response to that, I say only that what was quite clear from the published statements of the Labor Party by the end of 1975 was that it had accepted that its economic strategies of that time were mistaken and had led to a very great increase in unemployment and to a decrease in economic stability. If honourable senators want a sensible criticism of the policies which had been followed, they cannot do better than to read Mr Hayden's Budget Speech of 1975, in which he set about trying to rectify some of the problems of the past. Whilst one can point to high growth figures in 1974 and 1975, one can point also to the fundamental disequilibrium that was introduced by the policies of those years-a fundamental disequilibrium which it has been extremely difficult for us to overcome.

I was delighted to note that Senator Walsh agreed with the basic logic of the approach of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to the international sector when he sought international agreement that there should be an end to new protective devices and, further, a step towards reducing protection with a view to restoring world trade and world economic health. It is easy for Senator Walsh to concede the logic and to say: 'But, ha, this Government has not lived up to that logic in its domestic policies'. I point out that, in a world in which we face the restrictive practices of other countries and in which our rural industries, for example, are challenged by the practices of the European Economic Community, it is quite impossible for Australia alone to take a doctrinaire approach to protection. One need do no more than to go back to the words of Senator Button to be reminded of why that is so.

With respect to the speeches which have been made by members of the Opposition, I agree with one substantial point. I agree with the basic point by Senator Walsh that to manage the economy successfully we probably have to achieve a high degree of social consensus. It remains true that whilst all sectors of the community are demanding more than the community can provide- be it the trade unions, the government with its demands for resources, the welfare sector or business-and expect the system to produce more than it can, we cannot totally overcome our economic problems. I believe that is important. The Government has an important role in ensuring that there is community understanding of the limitations which we face and which provide the parameters within which any economic policy can be put to work.

The basic accusation in this matter of public importance is that we have failed to provide a lead at a time of social difficulty. The time for these debates is very limited. I have time only to touch upon a few of the points which I think clearly show that the Government has established a lead and has shown the Australian people the direction in which it wishes to go. I touch on them lightly because time will permit nothing more.

I touch upon the area for which I was formerly responsible-that of Aboriginal Affairs. I point to the first enactment by this Government of land rights legislation, to the establishment of the Aboriginal Development Commission which has put into Aboriginal hands programs with an annual value of nearly $50m and to the establishment of a representative Aboriginal organisation, the National Aboriginal Conference. It is an area which one might say is of little economic importance, but an area which has been one of great social difficulty in Australia for generations and in which this Government has given a clear and unmistakable lead.

I turn to the important area of ethnic affairs. In a country which is so heavily populated by migrants who have been invited to this country and who now make up such an important part of our population, we have had the implementation of the recommendations of the Galbally Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants Committee. No government has addressed itself with more concern to the post-arrival needs of migrants. A host of recommendations have received the attention of the Government and now provide assistance to migrants to Australia in their very often quite difficult transition to living in a new country.

In the field of education it is so easy to overlook the achievement of the standards laid down by the Karmel Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission-standards which were initially established under the previous Government and which have been met in all States under this Government. It is easy to overlook the new emphasis which has been given to technical and further education. Again, I do not have time to go into the statistics but it is well known in this chamber and outside it that technical and further education has received very great impetus under this Government because we understand the need for training for work and we believe that that part of education has in the past been under- emphasised. I point to our emphasis on transition from school to work as another example of programmed development which is aimed at the reality of Australia in the early 1980s and at the difficult social and economic problems which we face.

I point to the programs of what was the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. We made substantial investment, and continue to make substantial investment, in programs which will assist young Australians to achieve job skills. We have had a very substantial increase in expenditure on these programs , from $165m in 1980-81 to $206m in 1981-82. This year 235,000 young Australians will be assisted by these programs- 23,000 more than last year. In the past two years we have had a record intake of apprentices. I point to the various programs introduced by my colleage, Ian Viner, under the general heading of commitment to youth which provide for school-to-work transition allowances and things of that nature. In that field the clearest possible leadership has been given by the Government to the community. We expect the difficulties of the present to give rise to new programs and a new effort by the community.

I turn very quickly to my own Department, the Department of Social Security, and to my own responsibilities, which are intimately concerned with the social difficulties which exist in our community. I point to the fact that in 1976 we made a series of major changes which have been of great benefit to the Australian community. I point to the establishment of family allowances and I remind the Senate that the major effect of the introduction of family allowances was not to help the well-off who lost their tax allowances and gained a family allowance in its place but to help the poorest families to which tax allowances were irrelevant. It is this Government which has ensured that poorer families receive at least the same assistance as better off families.

I point to the introduction of the income test which has facilitated access to the pension by many aged Australians and, most importantly, I point to the twice -yearly indexation of the basic rates of benefits as the fundamental protection given to most Australians who are dependent upon my Department for income support. I point to the introduction of the supporting parents benefit, which extended to supporting fathers the benefits which previously had been available only to supporting mothers. I point to the extension of health benefits to sickness beneficiaries, to the unemployed and to low income earners. These are the sorts of steps which the Government has taken to face up to the realities of a changing Australia, an Australia in which some of our people do not have the benefits that the great mass of Australians in employment enjoy. I can say only that the Government remains intent on meeting problems as they emerge, on removing the problems which exist and promoting a healthy economy, employment and the way of life in Australia which makes Australia probably the best country in the world in which to life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always pleased to follow Senator Chaney in a debate. He can always be relied upon to make a thoughtful contribution to a debate of this kind. My remarks will centre on him because I understand that Senator Chaney, whom I believe to be one of the true liberals in this Parliament, will be used by the Liberal Party as an instrument of new Government policy throughout the next Budget. The policy that seems to be coming out of Government circles, particularly Liberal circles, as a cure for the economic and social ills affecting our community is the policy of implementing massive cuts in welfare as a feature of the next Budget. I will deal with that matter in a little detail as I continue my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, if anyone listening to this debate believes that I am making cheap political capital out of the dilemma in which the Government finds itself today, he has every right to criticise me. But I have great sympathy for the problems that this Government faces and I would have enormous sympathy for the Australian Labor Party, if it assumes office within the next year or two, in trying to solve the sorts of problems that face Australia at the moment. Let us not minimise them and say that they are easy to be solved or that by one sweep of the pen we can fix all of Australia's problems. Let us realise that the problems of Australia are part of a world problem which will affect all of us in the near future.

As we debate this matter of public importance put forward by Senator Button concerning the failure of the Fraser Government to provide leadership at a time of great social and economic difficulty, let us look at the situation in Australia. The world economy is in some form of recession. Some economists believe that that recession will deepen. The Australian currency at the moment, in my view, is between 12 per cent and 15 per cent over-valued. The world is becoming more and more protectionist. Australia is one of the few areas in the world in which massive walls of protection have not yet been erected. I look at the world scene today with not too much optimism not only for the future of the economy of Australia and other parts of the world but also for the narrower and narrower fields in which to manoeuvre which are being left to countries such as Australia. The rest of the world is becoming more protectionist. Let us not kid ourselves about that. Very few other countries still have tariff barriers over which the main exporters in the world can jump. Yet, altruistically, we are trying to say to the world: 'If we want to make a better and less troubled world we have to reduce trade barriers'. How Australia can do that in a world in which trade barriers are going up and up confounds me. In entering this debate today I do not want to give the impression that the Australian Democrats will show people how to fix everything and thereby make cheap political points because I do not think that they are there to be made. But I do wish to be critical-I hope constructively-of the Government.

Senator Button is generous to a fault in the wording of his matter of public importance. He charges the Fraser Government with the failure to provide leadership at a time of great social and economic difficulty. The implication is that the Government has been incompetent, indecisive and ineffective. I suppose one can be excused for thinking that that is the case. In Australia at the moment interest rates are as high as they have ever been. The level of real unemployment is at 12 per cent to 13 per cent and rising. Inflation is high. The number of bankruptcies is up and rising. Queues for welfare housing are growing- something like 100,000 families. An increasing number of people have to ask for charity just to survive. That figure is now about 250,000 Australia-wide, and that is a conservative estimate. A recent survey showed that 15,000 young people are homeless in Victoria alone. The unemployment rate among young people is three times as high as the adult rate. Are we surprised to find that the youth delinquency rate is rising?

One could say that the Fraser Government is responsible for all these things. These things are facts, and I do not think they can be contradicted. All that the Democrats and I are saying is: Using the same sort of conventional wisdom, under a Labor government would things have been essentially different or are new concepts necessary? We have heard Senator Chaney quite properly point to the problems we will have with welfare in the future and the enormous number of aged people who will need to be supported in Australia in the next decade because our population is growing older. He also mentioned the growth of the welfare bill, which will reach astronomic proportions. There is no question about that, and he does a proper job of warning us of it. But there is an underlying assumption on the part of Senator Chaney and others that it is in fact the taxpayers' responsibility to support all aged people. In a humane society, of course, those of us who pay taxes must claim responsibility for the down and outs and for the aged who have no one to fall back on.

But how about re-introducing the concept of the extended family? Is there anything basically wrong with the concept of the orientals and the mid-Europeans who come to Australia to whom it is an inalienable responsibility? We in this country are very fond of talking about inalienable rights but there is inalienable responsibility to look after our mothers and fathers when they get old. That has gone out of fashion in this country in something like 10 to 15 years. Every young couple now assumes that the State will look after mum and dad when they are old and that those couples have no responsibilities. It is remarkable how quickly that change has come about. It has been assisted by governments of both Liberal and Labor persuasions with the best possible intentions of being compassionate and caring for the aged in our community. Of course I am commending government involvement as a concept, but I am wondering whether it is not time for governments to give a lead to people and say: 'It is just not good enough. Our economy cannot afford the concept that when a person reaches the age of 60 he or she is totally dependent on the state, on the taxpayer. You-the daughter, the son-have a responsibility to your aging parents, and a financial responsibility at that'. This is not a new concept; it is a concept that is being pursued, as I said, by most middle Europeans, including those who have migrated to Australia.

During my visit to China a year or two ago I learned that it was unthinkable that any aged person in China be left to the mercy of the state. Such people are primarily, basically and totally the responsibility of their children, particularly when they become too frail or too old to look after themselves. I give that as one example in expressing a belief that the difficulties that Senator Chaney and the Government are now envisaging can be solved. But they cannot be solved by conventional methods such as getting more money through higher taxation. One of the things that bother me is that that 'more money' will not be available. There is not a bottomless pit from which to draw unlimited amounts to spend on education, social welfare and other matters on which everybody in this chamber and in this Parliament wants to spend money.

The Democrats do not walk away from a capital gains tax or a wealth tax. We unashamedly say that it ought to be levied. Levelled at 2 per cent of the total revenue it would give $800m a year additional revenue to the Government. In saying 'a capital gains tax or a wealth tax' let my words not be distorted by our political opponents as the Liberals distorted the words of Mr Hayden at the last election. We should exempt private homes-of course, they would have to be exempted-up to, say, a limit of $200,000. Tax on private possessions would be limited. A capital gains tax or a wealth tax should not hit ordinary people whose wealth increases on paper just because of inflation or some other measure. Why should people who have enormous amounts of money, or who by manipulating stock markets or some other means make massive profits of millions of dollars, be allowed, because of good accountants' advice or tax avoiders' advice, to get away scot-free? The Democrats believe a resources tax at the pithead is essential. It would bring in $500m additional revenue mainly from multinationals . We believe that sections such as section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act could be strengthened to such an extent as to allow the $5,000m to $10,000m tax which is being avoided at the moment to be reaped.

Although we say that the money that governments can spend does not come from a bottomless pit, there are sources of revenue which have not yet been tapped by this Government. The trends that I have mentioned are not necessarily the result of government bungling. If they were there could be some hope because another government could fix them up. The measures needed are obviously simple and well documented. Certain action can be taken in the short term. Interest rates for housing and small business could be subsidised. Selective increases in government spending could be used to stimulate economic activity. A range of relatively minor reforms to the income security system could be made to eliminate the most glaringly obvious poverty traps. However these are band-aids.

What bothers me is that certain signals are being given out by the Liberal Party as to its future policies. I fear that its response to the problems that I have outlined is to resort to a jungle society. There is no less an authority on that than the Federal Council of the Liberal Party of Australia. I commend Mr Geoffrey Barker's magnificent article in the Age on 22 May this year. The rhetoric employed by the Federal Council of the Liberal Party is seductive. It states that future economic growth should be 'based on individual initiative and enterprise within a competitive market with minimum government interference'. The words point to a strong and significant shift to a new social Darwinism. As a matter of government policy it is the survival of the fittest. The notion of government intervention to create and preserve equality of opportunity is gone. This could 'limit individual initiative, achievement or reward'. Instead, according to the Federal Council of the Liberal Party people will be encouraged to 'provide for themselves'.

Of course there is a fatal flaw in this philosophy. In our society those who can provide for themselves are the strong, the ruthless and the wealthy. In a remarkably frank way the Government is signalling a determined policy to preserve the advantages of the privileged. We say that there must be new concepts, a new look. We must acknowledge that the silicon chip is here and have a long term indicative plan against it.
Sitting suspended from 12.57 to 2.15 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon recess we were debating a matter of public importance raised by the Opposition in which it has alleged that the Fraser Government has failed to provide leadership at a time of great social and economic difficulty. On behalf of the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, I confidently reassure Senator Chipp, who spoke immediately before lunch, that the fears he expressed of massive cuts in welfare, as he put it, in the next Budget are highly unlikely. Apart from that I do not intend to say very much at all about Senator Chipp's speech. It sounded rather like a policy speech, an interesting one, that may be delivered on another occasion in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the matter of public importance which concerned the question of the leadership of Australia was raised by the Australian Labor Party. I will concentrate on the Labor Party's vision of Australia and its views of the leadership and vision shown by the Fraser Government. One cannot, as Senator Button, the Leader of the Opposition sought to do, just sweep aside the fact that Australia is a country very much influenced by what happens elsewhere in the world. Leadership has to be viewed in two ways. One view is in relation to the way in which a country is led in terms of its international position. The second view is in relation to how it is led in terms of its national difficulties and problems. Those two aspects go together. As I said, one just cannot sweep aside the fact that Australia as a nation in many ways is dependent on what happens in a world context because some of the sources of problems that we freely admit are faced by the country at the moment are related to that area. Therefore, the question of leadership and the leadership that the Fraser Government is giving to Australia must be directed in that area as well.

Australia is a major trading nation. Our effectiveness as a trading nation will determine our future living standards and expectations. The social and economic difficulties that the Labor Party referred to are, of course, bound up with our living standards and expectations, present and future. Leadership is best demonstrated by a willingness to follow. I suggest to the Labor Party that over the years Liberal governments have been vindicated by a clear and overwhelming willingness to follow on many occasions on behalf of the Australian public. Undoubtedly the reason for that is that Australian citizens, when they have voted in so many elections and endorsed so many Liberal governments, have accepted that the approach of a Liberal government to problems is the approach that they prefer. That acceptance of policies is an endorsement of that approach .

To demonstrate or to give leadership a government must understand the issues that a country faces. I reiterate that this is in both an international and national context. Liberal governments accept that there is an interdependence of all citizens. They accept that governments set the rules and the framework and that it is within those rules and the framework set by the rules that the country will operate. We prefer that there not be over-much government interference in matters between citizens. But we accept that on occasions government action is necessary to provide that leadership that we are debating here today. We consider that there is interdependence between unions and employers. We try to point out that there is an interdependence between the taxpayer and the welfare recipient. One cannot, as the Labor Party has sought in the debate today, take each one of those issues individually without relating them to the other. The acceptance that there is an interdependence of all citizens and that governments set the framework will lead to sound policies if that framework is correct. Those sound policies will lead to confidence in many ways.

Senator Button during his speech suggested that perhaps we should not look at the record of the Whitlam Government. He said that the Fraser Government has been in power for nearly seven years now and that it should be judged by its own record. We stand on our own record. We say that the record that this Government has achieved in its time in government shows that it is providing the right policies and therefore the leadership that Australians expect. One should not entirely ignore the experience of Australia under a Labor government. The debate today essentially is about the Fraser Government. Since it is the Labor Party that is criticising the policies of the Fraser Government, the Labor Party's own policies are relevant to the debate. By implication the Labor Party indicates that it would provide better and preferred leadership for Australians. One should not forget that the verdict not only of Australian citizens but also of people elsewhere who scrutinise Australia for various reasons was negative under a Labor government. For example, in 1975 the number of people leaving Australia for the first time exceeded the number of people coming to this country to live. That showed people voting with their feet and was an indication of the effect of the Labor Party's policies not only within Australia but also as they were perceived elsewhere. This party has the same basic approach and philosophy in Opposition as it had when it was in government. Therefore, we could expect more of the same.

Senator Button did not spend much time enumerating specific areas in which he thought different policies would provide better leadership. He did not spend much time stating what leadership Labor would give through its policies. We ought to remember that the basis of those policies is divisive. In 1974 nearly 6 .3 million working days were lost under a Labor government. That is an indication of divisive industrial policies and an approach to an area which, as I said a couple of minutes ago, requires a mutual understanding on both sides.

I welcome the comments made recently by the new Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee, when he pointed out very effectively that industrial relations is very much a matter of relations between people, that taking issues on their merit and understanding what people want and how they interact with one another is important. It is reflected in policies that indicate that excessive wage rises are not good for other people; they might be good for workers who get them, at least temporarily. To give without criticism any sort of endorsement of moves in that area without regard to Australia's overall economic situation, to what effect those policies will have on Australia 's position as a trading nation and, in the end, that means without regard to how many jobs there will be left in Australia, our ability to maintain our living standards and our ability to meet higher future expectations, is indeed highly irresponsible and not what one would expect from a party that has aspirations to lead this country.

Politics of discontent and envy, of looking at what somebody else has and saying, 'I ought to have that too', just because somebody else has it, is not a basis for sound leadership of this country. Of course, the Labor Party likes citizens to be dependent on government because dependence on government means that it is easer for governments to control the details of the lives of citizens . The recognition of the basic factors for a harmonious and progressive country is demonstrated in confidence as I indicated earlier. There are many indications of confidence in Australia both within this country and outside. I contrast the situation as it is today in regard to the desire of people from other countries to come and live in Australia with the indication I gave a minute ago of the situation of the last year of the Whitlam Government when more people left Australia than wanted to come here.

Briefly I instance the matter of foreign investment in Australia and the fact that investment of money in this country remains high and strong. That is an assessment by others who are looking at the situation in this country in a world context. If they did not believe the Government's policies were strong and sound and that the leadership this country has taken is in the right direction, then those investors would not be putting their money and their financial future in this country. I say also very briefly something which I think was not said before. Another good instance of that fact, frankly, is in relation to what has happened with foreign investment as it relates to interest rates. Interest rates are lamentably high. I will accept that. Nobody in the Government says anything else. It is interesting, however, that, when the prime interest rate in the United States of America was so very much higher than here in Australia, that did not lead to the flood of money out of the country that one might have expected and which has been the case on occasions in the past. That was an indication of the long term confidence that investors had in this country and continuing high levels of investment in Australia are an indication of a continuing high confidence in the leadership the Fraser Government is giving Australia.

Another aspect and measure of a government's capacity to lead are the clear directions that it gives to a country through its policies. Our economic policies have been clear. They have been policies geared to growth, to investment and to individual development of our citizens. Senator Chaney, the Minister for Social Security, when he spoke detailed a number of areas in which the Fraser Government has shown its concern for the economic security of its citizens. I would like to refer just very briefly to one other area, since time in this debate is so limited, and that is the area of education. We have a bulge in our population at the moment which has put pressure on both our education facilities and capacities and on our employment situation. We hope it will be temporary. We are not sitting back and waiting for that situation to take care of itself. We have pursued vigorous policies, particularly in the area of directing the interface between school to work transition. We have provided much money for development of educational programs which make more easy the transition from school to work so that our young people are more attractive employment prospects for employers. We have also given attention to areas of particular need which might have discriminated against groups in the past, areas such as multicultural education and migrant education. Finally, the Fraser Government has had the courage to implement those policies which have shown an understanding of the country and which also show an indication of what the Fraser Government's expectations are for Australia in the future.

I return very briefly to what Senator Button said during his speech. He said that it is no good blaming Australia's problems on trade unions, the world economy, and so on. He wanted to sweep away the factors that influence our country and which have some bearing on government policy. In other words, he was encouraging an attitude that I deplore, an attitude that one hears all the time, that 'they should do something about it'. He would seek to encourage Australians to think that governments are omnipotent, all powerful, and when faced with the problem do have the solutions entirely within their own hands. The sensible role for any government and a measure of true leadership is that it recognises those problems, recognises what solutions are available to it and operates in what it thinks is the best possible way for the benefit of all citizens.

I think we have had a useful and constructive debate today in which many areas and issues have been aired. I believe that in the long run the Fraser Government 's leadership in these areas of social and economic difficulty raised by the Opposition will be vindicated by the electorate. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
