PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Albury-Wodonga Development ( Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill seeks to vary the existing conditions under which certain financial arrangements are provided for under the 1973 Albury- Wodonga (Financial Assistance) Act. Specifically, it will give assistance to the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation and relieve it of its debt burden to the Commonwealth. To that extent and for this basic reason alone the Opposition supports the Bill. However, the Opposition wants to take advantage of debating this matter because it is concerned with the policies being pursued by the Government and views with great regret the approach that the Government has taken generally to the Albury-Wodonga decentralisation proposals and specifically its approach to regional development and decentralisation.

SPEECH.PARA: If ever there was an issue that needs a national input, and is a national responsibility, it is decentralisation. It is an issue to which all political parties pay a degree of lip service and one which all parties supposedly support . However, it has to be said that since the Fraser Government has come to power there has been a general reluctance to follow the initiatives that were taken by the Whitlam Administration during the years 1972 to 1975. Those initiatives were taken because the Australian Labor Party recognised that there was a problem of urbanisation in Australia-the country with the highest rate of urbanisation-and that it required an input by the national government to redress the inevitable drift that was taking place from rural centres to the cities. We subsequently set about establishing a number of regional centres and concepts with a view of at least influencing that trend in the other direction, that is, of establishing satellite cities and other large centres in rural areas to relieve the pressures that were clearly building up in the capital cities, principally Sydney and Melbourne.

Looking now at that initiative, one has to regret very much the failure of this Government to continue those policies that were begun in those important areas. Referring specifically to Albury-Wodonga, the first report of the Development Corporation in 1974 stated the aims of that particular project. The report stated that the Corporation sought to build a new and vigorous city in which there would be a high level of physical and social planning. That concept would be supported by any person who understands the need for a proper policy at the national level.

I remind honourable senators that social planning is an essential prerequisite in any decentralisation policy. The social planning that was prepared for Albury -Wodonga was tailored to meet the particular needs of different social categories-age, income and so on-so that where possible the lifestyle of the existing population would be capable of being continued with a minimal amount of intrusion. In other words, we were learning from our experience in Canberra-a city that was planned and has certain objectives which, to some extent, have been largely realised. That planning would proceed from a full understanding of the historical, social, ecological and geographical uniqueness of a development region. We believe that all citizens would have the opportunity to be informed about and share in the shaping and planning of that new community.

During the several visits that I have made to that region in the years that I have been a member of this Parliament and since the Corporation was established I have seen in practice how the Corporation has sought to fulfil those early objectives and principles of involving citizens in the planning of a decentralisation project. That planning of course would ensure that the advantages of the growth would be shared by existing residents and newcomers; that there would be adequate compensation to those who owned land where land acquisitions for development purposes were undertaken by the Corporation; that every possible care would be taken in the protection of the local ecology; that places of historical interest and importance would be preserved; that future trends and possibilities would be adequately prepared for; and that there would be an allowance for maximum flexibility, both physical and social, to adjust easily to changes of need and desire. That planning would respond to all of these requirements with as new and as fresh an approach as possible. In other words we should have learnt from the great problems of congestion which is such a feature of modern Western civilisation.

The initiative taken in Albury-Wodonga was most importantly a significant new development in the whole area of government co-operation. Many initiatives were taken by the Commonwealth Government. There was co-operation with the States and , in particular, with local government as the planning authority. It was very pleasing to see that that co-operation has extended over a period of years. Of course the reasons for this are paramount and manifold. I know from my own experience that when the State Government provided for what was known as the Sydney region outline plan back in the 1960s it recognised that, as a result of Commonwealth and State initiatives, there would be a population increase approximately double that of the city of Sydney and that this would require an understanding on the part of the authorities to provide at least double the existing public facilities if they were to carry out their function as planning organisations. In other words, there would have to be double the number of roads , ports, wharves, airports, housing-public and private-hospitals, schools and all of the other facilities which are clearly the responsibility of both the Federal and State governments. Because of the failure of adequate policies of decentralisation that outline plan, which we have seen now in its stages of implementation, put tremendous pressures on local councils, local authorities and local citizen's groups. The weight of the increase in population required a replanning of many of the existing suburban areas to accommodate the population pressures and an introduction of forms of high density development. I think we are all aware of the reaction that citizens have to that sort of problem in existing major cities.

It became clear to the Labor administration that there needed to be a very strong acceptance of its responsibilities in the area of decentralisation. We regret very much that the present Government has retreated on the initiatives that were taken by Mr Whitlam and Mr Uren, who was the Labor Party's Minister and spokesman on these matters, during the years 1972 to 1975. Much to the detriment of Albury-Wodonga and other regional centres the future of city dwellers and those who support decentralisation has been affected. Current Government spokesmen claim that the Labor approach during the Whitlam period was a free spending one. They claim furthermore that Labor's approach was over- centralised-quite the opposite of course to the strategy of the Whitlam Government in that period. As an alternative this Government posits its new federalism and a faith in the free market as the answer to these sorts of problems. The Albury-Wodonga project was aimed at combating the sprawl and the growth of our major cities which have lessened the quality of life and increased the cost of living, in particular the cost of buying land. It was a project that was aimed at co-ordinating and distributing growth in a planned and proper way.

It is all right for this Government to talk about controlling the rate of inflation. This Government has an index that seeks to suggest that somehow or other the rate of inflation has been maintained. But that index ignores the basic problem of accommodation-that area which affects every family and every person in one way or another. Of course what has happened in Sydney and I am sure to a lesser extent in other capital cities since the Fraser Government came to office has been another spiral in the cost of accommodation and land. In the post-war years we have seen an increase in the price of land and accommodation of something like 500 times what it was at the end of World War I. This has occurred as the result of the buildup of pressures that have taken place in our urban regions and particularly in our capital cities. Surely this matter has to be taken into consideration when we talk about containing or restraining the rate of inflation.

The biggest single expenditure item that any family has to meet is the provision of shelter. This has proceeded at an alarming rate in the post-war years as a direct result of a lack of national planning by conservative governments. After all, governments at the national level have policies, for example, about migration. We are aware that this Government is bringing into Australia more than 100,000 people every year through its migration programs. We do not quarrel with that figure but the cumulative effect is that in 10 years more than a million people will have been brought into an urban scene. Those people do not come and live in rural Australia; in a substantive sense they come and live in the major cities. The figures that are available show that there is no doubt that most of those people settle in the major States and in the major cities. This puts pressures on the costs of providing not only accommodation but also public facilities. We are now confronted with the latest estimate by the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Macphee, who, in his statement of last year, projected that there would be a population of approximately 19.5 million by the year 2000. If we talk about it in round figures the Commonwealth projects that, by the year 2000, we will have about 20 million people in this country. That projection has been made mainly because in the last few years there has been, as I have said, a rapid increase in the rate of inflation. There has also been an upturn in the number of Australian-born persons.

The program that the Australian Labor Party proposed for decentralisation during its years in office, specifically in respect of this legislation dealing with Albury-Wodonga, was based on a projected population of 17.5 million. The projected population increase of 2 million represents about an 11 per cent increase over the previous projection. What, then, are the prospects for the future? This Government takes the view that it should not intervene, it should not have an interest in planning for that increase in population by providing land, accommodation, jobs and growth in regions other than the capital cities. Clearly, there will be population growth, as I have indicated, and unless something is done about it nationally our major cities will take, as they are taking at the moment, all this growth. The social problems caused thereby will be disastrous. One has only to talk about the airport problem in Sydney to indicate this. The longer the governments concerned fail to agree on this matter , the greater the problem will be. It was talked about when I was in local government 20 years ago and here we are in 1982 and the matter still has not been resolved. The longer it is delayed the greater the problem will be. There is not a capital city anywhere in the world that does not now have a second airport that can cater for the growth of traffic, particularly international traffic.

A government with foresight and compassion would take this into account and prepare a plan for the future. This Government does not believe in planning for these matters. It believes in leaving all such matters to the private sector. This is an indictment of the Government, but a suitable plan will be an important part of the next Labor government's program. We will re-establish a plan that will take into consideration all the processes of change that are taking place in our country, whether they be in population, industry or whatever . Our approach certainly will not be that of the current bunch of people who masquerade as a government in this country. This Government, which claims to have come to office to legislate and operate in the interests of all people, ignores the basic problems facing a great number of the Australian people. If we look closely at the Government's current approach, we discover that for the first time in history we have a Federal Government that has no regional development policies at all. It will be recalled that several years ago the Fraser Government decided to abolish the Department of Urban and Regional Development. In its recent rearrangement and reshuffle of Ministers it even took the next step of abolishing the Department of Housing and Construction. The Opposition finds it inconceivable and unbelievable that a government claiming to represent the Australian people has abolished such important departments having such very important national functions.

We therefore have a government that has no regional development policies at all . Federal funds for urban and regional development, which were a feature of the Whitlam period, have been cut by 90 per cent since this Government came to office in 1975. So it has a very deplorable and sorry record to show the Australian people. The small allocation made in the 1981-82 Budget was made for the winding up of former programs. That means that in the next Budget, which we will be discussing when we come back to Canberra in August, we can be almost certain that there will be no funds at all for regional centre growth programs because such programs are clearly defunct and unnecessary in the mind of this Government. In April 1981 the Federal Government terminated the decentralisation assistance program and abolished the Decentralisation Advisory Board. That was one of the famous or infamous decisions of the razor gang, or the committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, headed by Sir Phillip Lynch. The Government has dismantled former regional development programs and has pursued policies which have had a dislocating effect on the lives of many people and a disruptive effect on the viability of regional economies. It has put the responsibility for this back on to the States. The Government has failed to bring any co-ordination into the process of industrial restructuring that has occurred over the last six years.

The Federal Government has completely opted out of regional development. It has , according to its own policies of new federalism, left the problems to the States. We all know that the States are incapable of providing funds and leadership in these areas, but they could do so in co-operation with a government that has a national concept. The States, of course, recognise that they have been sold a pup. They have no funds to service the regions adequately. That is apparent in all the relationships between the Commonwealth and the States whether they be in regard to education or hospitals. We are aware that this Government has placed a tremendous responsibility on the States, one to which they were unable, because of funding difficulties, to respond adequately. Albury-Wodonga has been left now to develop on its own. It was given a good start in 1974 when we were in office, and since then the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation itself has soldiered on very well. One can only compliment the Corporation on the way in which it has carried out the brief given to it in the original legislation. It is interesting to note, however, that the public sector-that sector which the Government can push ahead-has stagnated in recent times. Public sector employment has hardly increased compared with private employment. I have a table of employment figures from the 1981 annual report of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation which shows that public sector employment is languishing far behind private sector employment activitity in the region. TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not pulling its weight. Those on the other side of the chamber may claim that this is a case of the free market and the private sector doing its job. In the last century and the early part of this century it was the public sector which helped to develop our rural areas. It was Federal government and, particularly in the last century, State government initiatives, incentives and specific programs which brought about the establishment of so many of those country centres which have been able to maintain themselves in the succeeding years. We believe that as a result of the policies being pursued by the Government it is a case of government neglecting its role in a mixed economy and neglecting its role in decentralisation. Whilst we support the concept of a mixed economy we believe there is a need for greater public input which is so crucial in the effort to better the lives of the Australian people whether they live at Broken Hill, Albury-Wodonga, Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne or anywhere else. This 'let it all slide' attitude and its effect elsewhere have a debilitating effect upon the average citizen. In the booming mining towns such as Gladstone or those in the Latrobe and Hunter valleys, the lack of urban and regional planning and the failure to provide local authorities and State governments with funds for infrastructure have resulted in chaos, a lack of social facilities and basic services, dreadful accommodation shortages and social problems galore. One does not need to visit those areas to understand and appreciate the depth of the problem. Those problems need the assistance of Federal Government initiatives. This is another side of the Government's total reliance on the concept of a free market philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that the Australian Labor Party sees the initiatives of Albury-Wodonga as a beginning to the sort of approach it will take when it comes back into office. It is a part of what the Labor Party sees as an overall plan to develop and diversify city, regional and country living in Australia. The current Government ignores that approach and, naturally, the people and towns of Australia suffer. We congratulate the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation on its work so far and we look forward to the time when it can be assured of receiving from the Commonwealth the co-operation and help it deserves, not only with respect to Albury-Wodonga but also with respect to at least another dozen regional centres in Australia that can prosper and develop only with the assistance of a government that has a concept of recognising its responsibilities in decentralisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Albury-Wodonga Development (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1982 is to enact an agreement between New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth by which New South Wales and Victoria will be relieved of their obligations to repay loans and to pay interest on loans provided by the Commonwealth in relation to Albury-Wodonga. In lieu of repayments the Commonwealth will have access to funds generated by development activities. The Australian Democrats do not oppose this Bill but it does give the opportunity to take pause and consider the whole question of decentralisation in Australia. Indeed, our dismal failure to decentralise is one of the important submerged issues of our society. It is very far from being academic. It is unhealthy socially for a nation our size to have a larger proportion of its people living in a few large coastal cities than any comparable nation on earth. It shows a degree of lack of concern, a lack of appreciation of the great natural assets we control and a sort of contempt for the fact that we do not use or apparently want to use most parts of this whole continent.

SPEECH.PARA: Our rate of major urbanisation is very unhealthy socially but from the point of view of defence strategy the scenario is even more alarming. A majority of our citizens in this country are concentrated in a small number of large coastal cities, each of which is indeed a sitting duck for submarine missile attack in time of war. I have seen calculations showing how two submarines using their missiles-two submarines only-could do the job of destroying the bulk of the population in all of our major cities. Of course, we have nothing in the way of defensive apparatus that would prevent those missiles arriving. In addition, by far the largest part of our industry is also among the eggs in those few baskets . We have also thoughtfully provided major targets in time of war, possibly even nuclear targets, smack in the middle of our biggest cities-just in the way we have placed Garden Island, one of our naval bases, as strategically in the centre of Sydney as it would be possible to put it-thereby guaranteeing that in the case of war enormous casualties would occur in our major cities. That seems madness to me and to the Australian Democrats. We should be trying to strengthen the viability of other areas of population, especially to try to make them as self-sufficient as possible, with small localised supplies of electric power, their own health services and balanced industry.

This Bill relates to Albury-Wodonga. I think a lesson has been taught there, and possibly even more so in the Orange-Bathurst region, which might indicate that a broader view is necessary than was taken when those areas were proposed as growth areas. I am speaking here with the benefit of hindsight. It is easy to be wise after the event. Nevertheless, I think it is important to learn the history and the lessons these things may give. The problem of Albury-Wodonga, and perhaps even more for the Orange-Bathurst area, has been that once they were categorised as growth areas the price of land there skyrocketed and we got in fact an opposite kind of effect, where those areas did not go ahead and develop at all because other places near them were more competitive. So, instead of Albury-Wodonga and Bathurst-Orange going ahead as far as was hoped, Wagga and Dubbo, the neighbouring city in each case, were the cities to grow most as a result of this ironic situation. What is needed is an overall understanding for the need of growth outside the cities generally, a uniform growth of the areas outside the major cities-not specialised in certain districts-although I feel that the Albury-Wodonga experiment, well-intentioned though it was, did have grave flaws in that kind of direction.

The question of decentralisation and urban and regional development in general has suffered badly since the advent of the Fraser Government in 1975. Expenditure on decentralisation and growth centres under the Australian Labor Party in 1974-75 was $64.7m. This fell by 1977-78 to $25.6m under the Fraser Government. It has barely been adjusted to inflation over the last four years when the estimated figure for 1981-82 is $32.4m. In 1981-82 funding for urban and regional development and environment related issues has declined by 28.3 per cent on 1980-81 figures. Senator Gietzelt said that the Whitlam Government established a separate Department of Urban and Regional Development but this was abolished by the Fraser Government. The Australian Democrats also regret that. It is another way in which a major underlying problem of the country, like so many others, has been allowed to slide, apparently in the pious hope that in some way or other the future would remedy itself. That will not of course happen . Problems of that sort which are allowed to go on deteriorating, like several others in this country, have a tendency to accelerate. Their effects become greater as time goes on. Also, there is the problem that what might be relatively easy to remedy now will be very much harder to remedy in the distant future.

I think it is imperative that the Federal Government be responsible for taking the lead in the area of decentralisation for a number of reasons. It is the practice of State governments and local government bodies to deter an overall approach to the problem because it is bigger than they can cope with individually. I think that is a reasonable and respectable point of view, that local government and State governments have to deal with many more detailed problems. The big problem is basically too much for them and is also one, I think, which demands some kind of national co-ordination. Of course, the Federal Government provides for or controls most of the funds which are available to the other levels of government and, to a great extent, what is done in those kinds of areas can be encouraged from Canberra. The Federal Government decides on and is properly responsible for national economic policy and protection issues. Certainly I would have thought the defence implication which I mentioned earlier should be a matter of considerable concern to the Federal Government.

The Australian Democrats, as a matter of policy, are committed to the active promotion of decentralisation. We are very interested in the devolution of power . We believe that the smaller the group of people, the smaller the community, the better it can control its own affairs. This makes a much more human, more civilised and better method of government than having big government in one place which attempts to do things for an entire set of communities with very diverse views, very diverse interests-and properly so. They have every right to diversity. It is one of the things that makes the country interesting and, incidentally, which make it strong. To try to make our society completely homogenous would be a mistake.

We should encourage new population centres away from the major cities. These figures are quite alarming. Eighty per cent of Australians-eight out of ten-live in urban centres of 5,000 people or more. Sixty per cent live in capital cities. Of that number, 40 per cent live in Sydney and Melbourne. That, I think, is a social malaise. I was in the western suburbs of Sydney looking at the problems in big dormitory suburbs such as Blacktown and thereabouts the other day. I am convinced that the problems there-I spent several days there talking with people -are not the result of the people there. The people are not to blame for some of the appalling things that happen in those very inhuman environments. It is a fact that those environments exist when they ought not to exist, where people should not have to live in that kind of way.

I think any Western country has to look reasonably at what is happening in the People's Republic of China, where there is a very conscious effort to decentralise. Indeed, the people's communes, I think, represent a very effective decentralisation of the largest population in the world, now over 1,000 million people. During my last visit to China I met with the Responsible Member of the Revolutionary Committee governing Shanghai. One might say that at that time it was its council. The Responsible Member was the equivalent of its mayor. He said that there had been encouragement of huge movements of people and industry out of Shanghai in order that it should avoid the disgrace of becoming the largest city in the world. Those were his precise words.

We should realise that in the event of major catastrophe, nuclear war or whatever, even of an acute economic downturn in the world, our people, or the people of any country as highly urbanised as we are, are far more vulnerable to anything that might happen, either military or economic, than a society that has taken trouble to decentralise its people in the way I have described in China. I think we should give those people credit for that, whatever else we might think of their society.

The only way to encourage a greater population in rural areas-and here I am quoting the Australian Democrats' policy-is to make sure that the conditions of life are balanced so that people are encouraged to live in country rather than city areas. Telephone calls should be on a time rather than a distance basis and the new satellite technology makes this very simple. There is no reason in the world why people in country areas should have to pay more for their telephone calls than people in the city. I think we should try to remove extra freight costs because of distance and make some compensation to people so that it is not an automatic fact that if one goes and lives far from the central cities everything will cost one more. It should be a legitimate purpose of government to see that things cost people less in country areas so that they will be encouraged to live in those places. The other discrepancies of rural areas have to be compensated for over a time. While the failure to decentralise continues those discrepancies become worse. I am speaking now of poor health and education facilities. These things can be enhanced and improved rationally and reasonably only when cities and areas outside the major metropolises of Australia can grow and can have the prospect of a continued period of growth, which is even more important. There must be that kind of compensation.

We believe that there are a number of activities that the Federal Government should consider soon. They are basically philosophical; they basically require action or review from the Federal Government to change its present performance. The Federal Government must take the lead and it must maintain, if possible, a continuity of policy. The Democrats have asked for indicative planning a number of times, and I have given a notice of motion proposing that there should be a basic understanding and basic areas of agreement between all political parties on matters of this kind so that there is no discontinuity of policy when there is a change of government. This is very important. Periods of 10 years, 20 years or perhaps even longer are necessary for communities to develop in the way I have described, even for businesses to consider moving in and to think that they have a viable future. Businesses which go into these areas might reasonably look at a number of years during which they will not make money, but they may well look forward to a growing society and say: 'In seven, eight or 10 years this will be a goer and it is worth our while putting money in'. It is not worth while if they feel that, when the Australian Labor Party replaces the Liberal Party or Liberal replaces Labor, all will be thrown away and will change.

On behalf of the Democrats I plead again for more consideration of this ideal of a basic conference on the economy at which all political parties, unions and employers-as many groups as are interested-come together. I am aware of the immensity of that task. Honourable senators may recall that the Democrats have allowed a period of two years simply for planning such a conference so that its terms of reference will be right, it will know exactly what it is doing and everybody concerned will know what is going on. The Australian Democrats believe that the most eligible areas for development lie with small businesses and the private sector. Of course, it is the small businesses which will go to the smaller towns and develop themselves. A good object lesson for us can be found during the 1970s in the United States, where 80 per cent of new jobs were in the area of small business. We can do that in Australia too, but it will not happen by itself. It will not happen unless the Government of this country takes an honest and reasonable look at the problem of decentralisation, instead of paying lip service to it, and lays down a series of active, pragmatic proposals which will make it easier, better and cheaper for people to live in the country. This will encourage people to go to the country, with small business and, perhaps later on, industry to follow them. Decentralisation is not just about different locations or a different scale. It relates to the overall socio-economic structure-the power sharing and resource allocation within our society. It is as deep and as fundamental as that. The Democrats support the dispersal of power and resources so that they are closer to the people.

I conclude with an example of the classic problem of this kind in Australia. I refer to the north Queensland city of Townsville, which is now a city of over 100,000 people. It should properly have an international airport. The Burdekin scheme should go ahead. The whole of the region around it should be developed into an important new area. Indeed, it should be the capital of a new State. The Democrats have proposed that the new State of Capricornia should be located in north Queensland and that Townsville should be its capital. We believe that until that happens the area will not develop to the extent that it should. Is not that more important than the petty political jealousies that are preventing it now? I think that an initiative by the Federal Government to study the whole question of which new areas need a regional approach is perhaps another part of the problem. There is evidence that the Murray Valley could be a completely new State. I find that I am greeted very pleasantly by mayors in the Murray towns when I go there and suggest it. It is madness that a river such as the Murray should be the boundary between two States. It is an anachronism that is causing immense problems for the river and for the environment around it. It is something that should be corrected. I hope that will shed a little light on this matter. The Federal Government apparently does not have any ideas on the subject . If it had, one would expect it to be doing something or to have some lines of approach which it might take in this important matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a Bill to vary the conditions of certain financial assistance provided pursuant to the Albury-Wodonga Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1973. I mention that because, as is often the case with legislation which has the general support of the chamber, the debate has been used as a vehicle for honourable senators to raise matters in related areas which they feel are of concern. I note the views which have been expressed by Senator Gietzelt on behalf of the Opposition and by Senator Mason on behalf of the Australian Democrats. In light of the heavy program we have for the remainder of the sitting, a general perambulation by me through the wide fields that they have canvassed would not be in order, but I thank them for their support of the Bill. I note that it is a benign piece of legislation in that it supports amendments to an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States which essentially relieves the States of some very substantial repayment obligations with respect to both capital and interest.

SPEECH.PARA: It was said during the second reading debate that lessons had been given in the Albury-Wodonga situation. I thought that was an interesting twist on 'lessons having been learnt'. Perhaps Senator Mason was being very subtle by suggesting a lesson was available but had not been learnt. Perhaps one of the lessons is that the need for this agreement and the relieving of the States of these very heavy capital and interest obligations teach us something about the way in which decentralisation needs to be approached if we are to avoid public burdens which are quite insupportable. The need to forgive those debts is a concession to the fact that, in the way this agreement was organised, it gave rise to public commitments, that is, commitments on the part of taxpayers which were thought to be repayable but which, in the event, have proved not to be so. In fact, the taxpayer has borne this burden. We should not lose sight of that. I wish to make no further comment. Again, I thank the Senate for its support of the Bill and trust that it will have a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
