(5) assist local government bodies to meet road funding difficulties'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the speakers list for this debate contains at the moment the names of a further six senators, all of whom come from the larger States where the major problems with roads and hence with road funding are. I will be interested to hear what my fellow South Australians have to say about the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1982 and what honourable senators from Western Australia and Queensland have to say about the problems that they are facing in their States. I imagine that, to a certain extent at least, there will be certain similarities in the problems that we are facing and the comments that we have to make. This Bill enables grants of $734m to be allocated in 1982-83, $778m in 1983-84 and a further $825m in 1984-85, all of which money is to be available for road funding in Australia. These amounts represent increases of 7 per cent, 6 per cent and 6 per cent respectively for the three financial years that are mentioned. Whilst this may seem commendable at first glance, a closer look at the figures will show that in fact over the past few years road grants by the Commonwealth Government have not kept pace with road maintenance and construction costs, a fact which is placing an increasing burden on those other levels of government, and in particular local councils, which have to make up the shortfall. I think this was realised, at least partially, by the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) in the other place on 27 October 1981 when in part of an answer to a question of that day he said:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of representations and complaints have been received from local government that the estimated increases for which we have allowed in the program will not cover the actual cost of road construction. Last year I asked the Bureau of Transport Economics to undertake a survey of the road construction index. I expect to receive a report from the BTE at the end of the year. When it has received that report the Government will be in a better position to make a real assessment of the road funding program that was announced last year.

I would also like to remind the Senate that on page 17 of the fifth annual report of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations a number of recommendations are proposed including an expanded role for the BTE and that local government be given an opportunity to obtain equity in the Australian Road Research Board. I would suggest that the sooner the Government directs its attention to these recommendations the better.

The Bureau of Transport Economics report '1981 Road Construction Input-Price Indexes' shows that there has already been a 15.3 per cent increase in construction costs due to substantial increases in the cost of materials such as bitumen, aggregate, pipes, steel and so on. One does not, therefore, have to be a financial or mathematical genius to work out that a grant increase of 6 per cent or 7 per cent will not go anywhere near maintaining funding needs of this area. When we add to these price increases, the cost of meeting wage rises as well as demonstrable increases in road use in both rural and urban areas, something which particularly affects the larger States such as South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia, it can be seen that some more drastic action than that proposed by this Bill must be taken. It has been estimated, for example, that in Victoria, one of the smaller States, road travel has increased by 66 per cent in the last 10 years while funding has fallen in real terms by 22 per cent. Furthermore, it is expected that travel on metropolitan roads in that State will have increased by another 40 per cent by the year 2000, and that, I remind the Senate, is less than two decades away.

I am somewhat appalled at a number of statements made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in his second reading speech earlier this year. He made the comment that the allocations would be firm and final amounts. He went on to say:
The Government was not willing to encourage inflationary pressures by building into its expenditure programs open-ended commitments to meet unlimited future cost increases.
He also made this point:

It needs to be recognised that the Government's deliberations on road funding have to be undertaken in the light of the need for continued overall restraint on the Budget and, within that, the competing funding demands of other Commonwealth programs.

I suggest that if the Government is to place restraints on road funds required for increased road maintenance it is only sensible that it place some restraint on road use. The Minister also made the point:
. . . the Commonwealth is not committed to maintaining the existing funding relativities indefinitely.
However, he made no attempt to say where the shortfall is likely to be picked up .

It is patently apparent that this particular form of penny-pinching by the present Government to road funding is going to produce some rather disastrous results in both the long and short term. Increased travel time and delays, especially in urban areas, leading to increased fuel consumption and increased vehicle operating costs are just one. We can go on to refer to things such as increased traffic on urban residential streets because people are going to divert themselves from the use of major arterial roads, for instance, which are going to become increasingly congested. That is already becoming patently apparent in Adelaide, where I take a rather circuitous route to get my two children to school in the mornings when I am home. I do this rather than take a shorter and more direct route because the longer route, at the moment at least, is less congested and less cluttered up with traffic lights and therefore the trip is smoother. But I can see that this sort of situation is not going to continue. A few more people are going to work out that it is easier to get to some part of the Greenhill Road by going up West Beach Road than down Anzac Highway. The two roads will become equally congested. In addition, of course, increased freight costs will result from the increased traffic costs which I mentioned earlier and hence higher prices will have to be paid for goods, particularly in country areas. Again, I must stress that this is a particularly invidious sort of end result for States such as South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland.

Serious and universally resented problems are already occurring in rural areas because of the Government's dismal record on road funding and the problems are proving enormously expensive to local councils in country areas. The States that I have already mentioned-I now include the Northern Territory-have large numbers of isolated areas and consequently there is a very great need for long stretches of road connecting small as well as larger towns. I can assure honourable senators from my visits to areas particularly in the mid-north of South Australia that the people are becoming heartily tired of being treated as second class citizens. Most of those smaller towns, and hence most of those local government areas, are situated in what can be or have been in the past known as blue ribbon Liberal seats. The people of those areas are beginning to wonder whether their adherence to right of centre politics is not doing them any good at all; that they are in fact being seen merely as electoral fodder for a Liberal-National Country Party government and allowed to go their own way in between elections. It seems unfortunate that those people, who already suffer from isolation and to a certain extent lesser facilities than people in urban areas get, should also suffer from worse and increasingly bad road conditions.

I point out that South Australia is particularly hard done by. The Local Government Association of South Australia Incorporated has issued a page of information entitled 'Local Government and Trends in Road Finance'. At the bottom of the page it points out:

. . . South Australian Local Government is now spending an increasingly higher proportion of its total revenue on roads. For example, in 1979-80 16.8 per cent of Local Government revenue was expended on roads. In 1981-82 (the latest figures available) this proportion has risen to 21.2 per cent-a significant increase.

That was an increase of about one-quarter or 25 per cent in two years. That, I suspect, is not going to do the Government any good come the next election. As I said earlier, I spent some time this year travelling to see local government authorities in areas such as the mid-north, the Barossa Valley, the River Murray regions, the west coast and the south-east of South Australia. Everywhere I go the comments are the same. There is major frustration, anger and resentment at the invidious position that country local government authorities are finding themselves in because of cuts to road funding. Furthermore, they point out with monotonous regularity that this problem is exacerbated by the Government's double standards with regard to Australian National.

Country people have, of course, two main forms of transport available to them- or at least they do in South Australia, where air services are limited to the major regional centres. Country people in South Australia and, I suggest, also in the other larger States are almost entirely restricted to getting themselves and their goods from point A to point B by using road or rail. These two forms of transport run through the same areas and offer the same services to the same people. A major complaint from the people who have to use these services is that they operate under two completely different sets of financial and management rules. Australian National is expected to operate as a business and, hence, expects the users of the service to pay accordingly for the provision and upkeep of that service. Australia's road system is not geared to having the user pay according to the use made of the facilities nor are the users expected to contribute directly to the maintenance of the service. In some areas this is beginning to show a considerable amount of damage to roads.

South Australia and the industries in South Australia are commendably working towards decentralisation. Some fairly heavy industries are being established in some country towns in South Australia. For example, a cement works is being set up in Angaston. Honourable senators can imagine the weight and the number of trucks that use the road system around Angaston. They are tearing the roads to shreds. The onus is not on the user to contribute to any large degree towards the maintenance of the roads that are being torn up in that way but on local government authorities and, hence, ultimately on the local residents who contribute by paying rates which seem to be going up with monotonous regularity.

We have two systems of transport available to country people which affect each other's costing and which operate under completely separate sorts of rules and regulations. As freight and other costs of using Australian National rise, so more use is made of the road system in the same area. As a result, Australian National further increases its prices and generally further limits its services. Hence, more people are forced to use the road system with the inevitable and, I would have thought, rather obvious result that additional maintenance is required to mend the additional damage done to road surfaces. This point is made particularly well in a telex that I received recently. It contained extracts from a report of the half-yearly meeting of the Mid North Regional Organisation in South Australia which was held on 26 March 1982. It was titled 'Impact of Grain Traffic on Roads'. In part, it stated:

The increasing trend in the use of road transport to cart grain out of the silos in lieu of rail transport is of concern because of the implications to local government. Increased road haulage is having a significant impact on local roads in some areas through deteriorating surfaces and need for consequent repair and maintenance.

Is this trend purely a matter of economics? It seems obvious that cost differentials and levies between road carriers and Australia National are a factor. Road carriers, in tendering for the transport of bulk grain, do not need to allow for a road factor as they use a public investment, the road system, which is repaired and maintained by the public at large, namely local government which picks up the cost for this. Councils, via 'in-house' maintenance, effectively subsidize the road carrier.

On the other hand, Australia National is totally responsible for the upkeep of its own right-of-way and infrastructure, and must therefore include such costs in its tendering. It is somewhat disturbing that the rail system, although sitting side-by-side with the road system, is not being fully utilized.

I interpolate here to say that to make matters worse the revenue gathered from the petrol excise is only in a very limited way returned directly to local government or to State governments for use for road maintenance and development. Yet this is one of the few taxes-it may not be the only tax-which applies to a specific group of people using a specific commodity. This is a long telex and I will not take up the time of the Senate in going through all of it. It concludes by saying:

. . . one obvious statement can be drawn-it is a further example of the policies of other bodies (government, semi-government and private) putting more strain on the existing road system, through greater and heavier traffic, although funds to roads are being withdrawn in real terms.

Figures supplied by the Australian Council of Local Government Associations from Canberra relating to Commonwealth roads grants indicate that the percentage of total Commonwealth outlay on road grants has dropped from 2.1 per cent in 1974- 75 to 1.6 per cent in 1981-82-a drop in percentage which is even greater when compared with 1972-73 and 1973-74 figures which were 2.9 per cent and 2.7 per cent respectively. Inevitably, as Commonwealth allocation decreases in real terms the amount which local government must contribute to road maintenance and development must increase with a commensurate diminution of the amount of money it can spend on other local government services and needs. In South Australia, for example, as I have already pointed out, local government spending has increased by 25 per cent from 16.8 per cent to 21.2 per cent between 1979 and 1981. Again, the resentment that this is causing is best expressed in the motion that was passed at a regional government meeting in Snowtown in South Australia last August. The motion which was carried unanimously at the regions annual meeting stated:

That, as it is unreasonable to expect local government with its limited revenue raising capacity to take up vital shortfalls in road funding, the unsatisfactory consequences of the Federal Government's policies must be pursued to secure a more equitable and realistic treatment for local government.
The report continues:

In moving this, one of our delegates stated that this issue had gone beyond the point where the authorities cannot take it seriously. They must face up to and answer the facts-the figures as presented tell the story. The region has a road problem, as has local government generally, and this needs to be rectified.
The Opposition has made some attempt to face the problem in its amendment which, in part, states:
. . . the Senate is of the opinion that a substantial supplementary allocation of road grants should be made available to the States, the Northern Territory and local government without delay to-
(a) reduce the backlog of established roads needs;
(b) accelerate the rate of road construction and maintenance works;
(c) improve the efficiency of road transport services;
(d) reduce the incidence of road deaths and injuries; and
(e) assist local government bodies to meet road funding difficulties'.

All it does is make some attempt to face the problem. It sets out the problem areas but it does not go on to give any indication of how the Opposition would see that supplementary allocation being provided. I would have thought that any party putting itself forward as an alternative government could have come up with a better way of achieving the aims that we certainly support than simply by suggesting vaguely that there ought to be a substantial supplementary allocation . To that end the Australian Democrats propose to move an amendment which I believe rectifies this omission. After considerable consultation with local government authorities in South Australia we propose to add at the end of the Opposition's amendment the words:

. . . that that allocation should reflect the increase in road construction costs revealed by the Bureau of Transport Economics' road construction price index, and that allocations in future years should be determined in accordance with that index.

I suggest that only when such adequate funding action is taken will Australia's national highways and roadways-whether local, arterial or whatever-become, as one manufacturing organisation described them, assets rather than liabilities. I am enormously proud of what South Australian rural local government authorities have done with very inadequate funds. What I have seen of road development in South Australia indicates that they have gone to incredible lengths to make sure that local residents are not as seriously hampered by the problem as they could well have been. But this has been achieved at the expense of other services and community needs. It has been at the expense also of having to increase local government rates. These authorities will not, however, be able to continue that sort of situation for ever.

I conclude by saying that whether we like it or not Australia is highly dependent on road transport for the movement of people, for the movement of primary and manufactured products and for defence. We must ensure the safety of drivers and passengers in cars and truck drivers who use the roads as their means of livelihood. They are all dependent on the quality of roads that are provided in this country. Responsibility for this, it seems to me, lies primarily with the Federal government. I believe that it is only good sense to develop sensible policies with regard to roads since they provide, unarguably, an essential service for Australia and must hence receive the adequate, substantial increases in funding that they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines, you have foreshadowed a motion that you have not formally moved.
—I move the Democrats' amendment to the Opposition's amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of words proposed to be added, add:

', that that allocation should reflect the increase in road construction costs revealed by the Bureau of Transport Economics' road construction price index, and that allocations in future years should be determined in accordance with that index'.
Copies of the amendment have been circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Roads Grants Amendment Bill which is designed to amend the Roads Grants Act 1981. In supporting this Bill I acknowledge that if the Federal Government is to rein in inflation it has to act with prudence in the allocation of its resources. There is very little real prospect of inflation, interest rates or unemployment declining if governments spend more than they raise. However, it is incumbent, in my view, upon governments to distribute properly their resources not only towards social needs and demands but also towards those areas that are likely, due to sensible investment, to produce wealth and growth for all people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I address myself at the moment to the concept of investment as it applies to transport and in particular to roads. I refer at the moment to two aspects-to the investment initiative and the reactive investment. In referring to the investment initiative that must be considered in allocating funds for roads, I remind honourable senators of the enormous wealth that has been created and generated by the opening up of Western Australia through the construction of the road system. Today Western Australia enjoys 164,000 kilometres of public roads or 19.6 per cent of the total Australian road network. There was an urgent need in the early 1960s to develop the north-west of Western Australia particularly in respect of the beef export industry. During the Western Australian beef roads program of 1962 to 1974, $40m was invested in beef roads. That was partly responsible for an ultimate export sale of beef in excess of $200m over the same period. It was that sort of investment that created economic and social development. The roads are still there, still functioning, still adequate and still ensuring that there is an ever-increasing return on that initial investment. It was in that instance that the missing link was accurately identified. Because that program was of national significance the Federal Government made a contribution. That contribution, of course, was more than matched by the State Government.

The State Government's great land settlement programs in the 1960s, for instance, could not have been achieved without the new techniques for building cheap, serviceable access roads in the new farming areas. The consequent development, employment and export earnings were largely attributable to the road and bridge construction work generally that was carried out during that period. The lifting of the export embargo on the iron ore industry in the 1960s heralded a dramatic period in the development of Western Australia. The mineral wealth of the Pilbara region was to be tapped, new towns were to be born and old towns, such as Port Hedland and Roebourne, sprang to new life and a new era of road construction was to commence in preparation for the future.

A great deal more development can and will take place in Western Australia. But the potential for resource development, whatever its nature-whether it be farming or mining-cannot be fully realised while so much remains to be done in road construction generally. In my view it is only after we have the initial investment that there should be follow-up or reactive investment, as I described it. I believe the Federal Government must resist pressure to adopt reactive investment to the detriment of road funding and the future economic and social development of Australia. We all know that hospitals, schools and social welfare are vital, visible and popular but it must never be forgotten that the provision of those services which are demanded by the community can be provided only for as long as there is strong, virile and active economic development in this country.

The road construction industry ranks highly in comparison with most industries in its ability to create jobs. It is indeed one of the best mediums for creating employment in the economy. In my view providing a job is an excellent welfare service. Despite Australia's great need for economic development and the job creating opportunities it brings, I see the temptation for governments from time to time to place a disproportionate priority on soft expenditure-on welfare- rather than on hard decisions and hard expenditure on roads. The benefits of increasing road funds as they apply to economic development are self-evident. Roads stimulate development.

Then, of course, we have the enormous influence that social factors can have upon economic development. For example, in the Pilbara region of Western Australia, in part due in my view to the very unfavourable environment and the harsh conditions, there is a very poor record of industrial relations. One has to wonder how much of that industrial relations record is due to the living standards and the working conditions. Isolation between towns, isolation between towns and the recreational coastline and isolation between towns and the capital cities certainly cause problems. I believe many of those problems could be alleviated if there were very effective and proper road communications.

If Western Australia is to succeed in attracting foreign capital and the development of remote resource wealth then it needs significant Commonwealth grants to finance its road infrastructure in these areas. Because in recent years emphasis has already been given, particulary by the Western Australian Government, to improving roads in the northern part of the State and in the northern goldfields areas because of urgent development requirements, urgent improvements to many important arterial roads in the south-west of Western Australia have been deferred. Significant increases in funds are required to upgrade such roads and to prevent deterioration in service as well as safety. A recent joint Commonwealth-State study of national roads in Australia-the second report of the Members of the Committee of Senior Representatives of Commonwealth and State Road Authorities-has shown that at present funding levels it will take 27 years to achieve interim standards and 37 years to achieve ultimate standards throughout Australia. In Western Australia the position is considerably worse. Because of the great length of national roads in Western Australia-Western Australia has 29 per cent of national roads-it will take 44 years to achieve interim standards compared with the Australian average, as I said, of 27 years. This means that Western Australia will not have a dust-free, almost flood-free, national road system built to interim standards until the year 2026.

The particular projects which require urgent consideration in my State are: The widening of the Great Northern Highway from Wubin to Meekatharra at a cost of $ 15m; the construction and sealing of the road between Fitzroy Crossing and Halls Creek at a cost of $57m; the construction and sealing of the road between Newman and Port Hedland at a cost of $115m; the widening of the Eyre Highway at a cost of $46m and work on the Great Eastern Highway-construction between Perth and Northam at a cost of $34m and reconstruction east of Northam at a cost of $10m. Work has already started, as I understand it, on the Fitzroy Crossing-Halls Creek project and is expected to commence on the Newman-Hedland road in the 1982 -83 period. However, urgent improvements have to be deferred on the Great Eastern Highway and there is little likelihood that the work will start on widening the Eyre Highway for many years even though the present width is totally inadequate, safety is diminishing and maintenance costs are rising rapidly. The six projects mentioned above will probably not be completed for about 20 years at present funding levels.

I note that the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) suggests that the most pressing problems are in Queensland and New South Wales. With respect, this is contrary to the findings of the Commonwealth-State study to which I have just referred and which found that New South Wales could complete the national highway system to interim standards in 24 years, Queensland in 33 years and Western Australia in 44 years. The study further found that a 25 per cent increase in national road funding is required to complete the national highway system to interim standards by the year 2000. In my view, this seems an unreasonably long period by any criteria. I would not want it thought for a moment that Western Australian people are not prepared to carry their part of the burden and their part of the tax responsibility for road construction and maintenance. To accommodate steadily decreasing Commonwealth funding in real terms, State charges have increased at a rapid rate. From 1975-76 to 1981-82 Western Australian funds have increased by 118 per cent while Commonwealth funds have increased by 43 per cent in current figures. Perhaps more important and more relative are the constant or real figures. In the five year period from June 1976 to June 1981 Western Australia increased its efforts by 26.4 per cent whereas the Commonwealth efforts actually decreased by minus 8.8 per cent. I remind honourable senators that in the period 1981-82 Western Australians are paying $62.46 per head in State charges for roads. That represents an increase of approxi- mately 11 per cent over the previous year.

Regrettably, I suspect that the 1980-81 to 1984-85 Federal allocations which were determined in 1980 were based on calculations of a steadily declining level of inflation. An increase of 11.1 per cent was provided for 1980-81, an increase of 9.1 per cent was provided for 1981-82, an increase of 7.1 per cent was provided for 1982-83 and an increase of 6 per cent was provided thereafter. On current inflation levels, these figures appear to me to be decidedly inadequate and I refer honourable senators to the recent report of the Bureau of Transport Economics covering increases in the road index for Australia. Of course, the road index is a measure of the increasing cost of construction of roads. In 1979 -80 the index was 15.9 per cent and in 1980-81 it was 15.3 per cent. With respect, I will refer back to the increase in Commonwealth funds. In 1978-79 the Commonwealth increased its expenditure by 7.5 per cent while the increase in the road index was 15.9 per cent. In 1979-80 the Commonwealth increase was 11.2 per cent while the increase in the road index was 15.3 per cent. In 1981-82 the Commonwealth increase was 9.1 per cent while the increase in the road index was 16 per cent. In 1982-83 the Commonwealth increase is 7.1 per cent while the increase in the road index is 16 per cent.

To conclude my comments on Federal funding, I remind the Senate that the Commonwealth at present collects $3,107m from its petroleum parity pricing policy and expects to collect $3,357m in 1981-82. Of course, it naturally receives very considerable additional revenue through taxes on petroleum production. This revenue collected by the Federal Government has increased from $250m in 1976 to over $3,000m in 1981-an increase of 1,200 per cent. It ought to be remembered that while the Commonwealth action in the area of oil parity pricing has achieved the conservation objectives, desirable as they are, it has had a detrimental effect on State revenues. High oil prices have reduced fuel consumption and encouraged smaller cars and had a depressing effect on both the State fuel levy and vehicle licence fee collections.

I conclude my plea for greater Commonwealth expenditure on road grants, and more particularly my plea for greater expenditure in Western Australia where it is well deserved, by making the following simple observations. Western Australia has 29 per cent of the national highway system. It has 19.6 per cent of the Australian road network. It occupies 33 per cent of the Australian land mass and , due to the fact that it has only 8.6 per cent of the Australian population, it has a very limited base from which to extract revenue for the purpose of road funding. Of course, Western Australia does provide 20 per cent of Australia's export earnings and yet it receives only 12.67 per cent of Federal road grants. Western Australia's export earnings and hence associated balance of payments contributions, as well as exchange rate stability and growth, are matters of public record. I conclude by saying that I hope that the proposals for the next period are reviewed by the Federal Government to make them more realistic and more in line with the levels of cost and levels of indexation as described already in my previous comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Road Grants Amendment Bill 1982. I was very interested to hear the first Government speaker on this Bill, Senator Crichton-Browne, who commenced his opening remarks by saying that he fully supported the Bill and then went on to tell us about all the problems being experienced in Western Australia because of lack of finance to build and maintain roads. We have a person who, whilst he is prepared to support the Government, is also prepared to criticise it and make a lot of remarks about the needs of Western Australia. I want to dwell upon that because what Senator Crichton-Browne has said here today highlights the article which appeared on the front page of the Australian of 18 March. We have to go back that far because it is just five weeks today since this Bill was introduced into the Senate. It has been waiting around for five weeks to be debated. The front page of the Australian of 18 March carried the headline 'Backbench fights cutbacks to State road funds program'. I will quote from that article. It is by Russell Schneider who used to work for Senator Withers when, I think, Senator Withers was Leader of the Opposition in this place from 1972 to 1975. The article commences:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government yesterday dismissed bitter backbench complaints against plans for a reduction in road funds to the States.

Our spokesman in the other place made mention of this in the debate on the Bill and nobody from the Government side stood up in the debate and denied that the story by Mr Russell Schneider was anything but fact. I will not quote all of the article because I will not have enough time, but the article continued:
But Government backbenchers pointed out that the proposed funding was less than the inflation rate and far less than the 15 per cent actual increase in road building costs over the previous year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 15.9 per cent.
—Well, 15.9 per cent. My understanding of Senator Crichton- Browne's remarks today is that he will support the Bill because it is a good Bill. The article further points out:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to cut back road funding in real terms is expected to lead to major clashes between the Federal Government and the States and local government .
Of course, what is said there is absolutely true, as I am well aware because of what has happened in South Australia. The article continues:
The NCP rose en masse to attack its own minister's proposals-a move deliberately aimed at forcing Federal Cabinet to reconsider money for highways and local roads.
The Queensland Premier's wife,-
I am pleased that she is in the chamber now-
Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, said the principal complaint from Queensland local government was on the lack of Federal finance for roads.
I will be interested to see how Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen casts her vote on the amendments before us today. The article further states:
The NCP MPs were joined by Liberals Mr Gordon Dean (Qld) and Mr Murray Sainsbury (NSW) who said the Commonwealth had to provide increased funds for road building in rural areas.

Of course I looked at the voting details on the House of Representatives Hansard of 20 April and I saw that both of those people who are quoted as being highly critical in the party room voted for the Bill, as will Senator Crichton-Browne today. The article goes on to say:
NCP sources said after the meeting they were totally dissatisfied with the proposed roads allocation.
This article goes on to quote what some of the State Ministers have said. It states:
Queensland's Minister for Main Roads, Mr Hinze, said the cutbacks were ' disastrous' . . .
The South Australian Minister for Transport, Mr Wilson, said the Federal Government was reducing spending on the nation's highways without regard to the needs of the States.

I can verify that quote attributed to Mr Wilson because I will refer to a meeting of the Mid-North Regional Organisation which I attended last year and at which Mr Wilson was the guest speaker. When certain motions were moved he blamed the Federal Government for the problems which were being experienced by South Australia. The article goes on to state:
The Minister for Consumer Affairs and Roads, Mr Wheelan, claimed the situation in NSW was quickly nearing crisis point.

These are the criticisms that have been levelled at this Government because of the penny-pinching it has engaged in in providing funds to all the States for their road programs. We can see, when we look at this Bill, that for the seventh successive year real Commonwealth grants to the States will be cut in 1982-83, 1983-84 and again in 1984-85 unless this Government is removed from office, a fate it justly deserves. The only effect that blowup in the party room had on the Minister for Transport and Construction, Mr Hunt, was that he cut down his second reading speech to one-third of last year's effort when introducing the Bill in the other place and when Senator Messner introduced it in this place on his behalf.

Later today National Country Party and Liberal Party senators will have an opportunity to bring their principles out of the Government party room, to voice them in this chamber and to back them with their vote for the Opposition amendment. I learned just a few moments ago that there is a further amendment to the Opposition amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt when this Bill was last debated. I am particularly interested, as I said earlier, to note that Senator Bjelke-Petersen's husband's Minister for Main Roads, Mr Hinze, has described the cutbacks as disastrous. I will be interested to see how she casts her vote.

Last November the Minister, Mr Hunt, admitted that Commonwealth road grants were not keeping pace with increases in road construction costs. He is well aware of that; he admitted it. He said that the Government would address the problems of declining road grants on the release of the report of the Bureau of Transport Economics on a road construction price index in early 1982. Of course we already have that report. It is very critical and highlights the problems faced by the States. That report was tabled by the Minister quite a few weeks ago now. It is five weeks since this Bill came into this place and, I think, five weeks and a few days since it was debated in the other place, so it is well over two months since that report was tabled by the Minister. His response to the problem was again to defer its consideration until after the Budget.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to the South Australian Royal Automobile Association journal, the Motor, which ran an editorial in this month' s issue. I suppose the majority of people who drive vehicles in South Australia are members of that organisation which speaks on their behalf. The editorial in the May issue of the paper, headed 'Govt. Sees Problem', states:
The Federal Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt has at long last publicly acknowledged that inflation is having 'adverse consequences' on road building and maintenance.
The Minister's 'adverse consequences' sounds like a polite way of describing a disastrous situation . . . because that is what it is.
We all recognise that. Even Senator Crichton-Browne recognises it, although he will support the Bill. The editorial further states:
Numerous representations by State and Local Government Authorities prompted the Minister to 'hurry along' a study by the Bureau of Transport Economics into road building costs.
To nobody's surprise, the report, released in March, revealed that there had been a significant acceleration in road building costs since 1979.
This increase was between 15-16 per cent per year.
And what action has Canberra taken to halt the deterioration of the road system ?

Road grants have been increased by 7.2 per cent for 1982/83, less than half of the annual increase in road building costs, and astoundingly this pitiful handout will be dropped to levels representing only 6 per cent increases for 1983/84 and 1984/85.
The article goes on:
Is the Minister for Transport championing the cause of Australian road users in the face of this damning indictment?

Well, he has issued a press statement informing us in well-worn political phrases that he is 'concerned' about the continuation of inflation and that the Commonwealth Government 'is determined to do all it can to reduce inflation in the road sector and the economy as a whole'.
It all sounds drearily familiar. The editorial goes on to state:
The Minister admits that adequate roads are essential to meet the increasing demands imposed by industrial expansion and economic growth in the coming years.
But what about here and now? Road programmes by State and local authorities are being slashed and necessary road projects are being put into pigeonholes for a decade ahead.

That is the problem we face and which has been recognised by the Royal Automobile Association in South Australia to such an extent that it saw fit to run an editorial in its paper on that score. I hope that when funds are being allocated for road funding perhaps in the next Budget and when we are discussing a Bill of this nature after the Budget, the Minister will take some cognisance of what reputable authorities such as the RAA and local government authorities have had to say. I will mention these later.

The Minister's reference in his second reading speech to State relations constitutes a superficial attempt to encourage dissension among the States in a battle for declining road funds; that is, to put it simply, to set one State against the other in a very bitter dogfight. That is what is happening. One State will be competing against the other at Loan Council meetings and Premiers Conferences-wherever they meet-because they have local government bodies on their backs about funding for local roads. As was mentioned here by a previous speaker, because of curtailment and the closure of country rail services-that is another argument-greater use is being made of country roads. It will not be long -I have said this in this place before when talking about railway cutbacks- before the States and the local government authorities have to come to the Federal Government and seek more and more money to build better roads in country areas where the rail services have been curtailed. In my view that cuts out not only employment but also services to farmers. It will also create a greater debt for the taxpayer for the construction of these roads so that these massive transports can use them to cart farm produce.

The main purpose of this Bill is to provide financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory for road construction and maintenance purposes. The Opposition does not oppose that. The schedules attached to the Bill detail allocations of $734m in 1982-83, $778m in 1983-84 and $825m in 1984-85. These amounts respectively represent increases of 7 per cent, 6 per cent and 6 per cent over the previous years allocation. The new road construction price index report tabled by the Minister recently objectively reveals the sharp and irresponsible cutback in real Federal road grants. This has been mentioned here today by the Government senator, Senator Crichton-Browne. The report highlights the increases in fuel and bitumen prices as the two fastest rising components of the index. Both increases are the direct result of this Government's oil pricing and economic policies.

As my colleague Senator Walsh has repeatedly pointed out, that pricing policy of the Government was not a conservation one; it was a tax raising gimmick. We now find that its argument has been knocked into a cocked hat because there is a surplus of petroleum all over the world. We now have countries vying with one another to sell petroleum. The Australian Government is sitting pretty because it is reaping the harvest of increased petrol tax.

In the 1979-80 Budget Speech the Government undertook at least to maintain the level of road grants over the three years 1977-78 to 1979-80. Even using the old inappropriate indices we find that over that period Federal grants were reduced by 3.3 per cent. The new index reveals that the real cutback was 8 per cent, despite the promise made in the 1979-80 Budget Speech. It also exposes a massive 21 per cent cutback in real terms in road grants to Victoria between 1975-76- that was the end of the reign of the Whitlam Government, when we were providing adequate road funds and doing the best we could despite frustrations in this place-and 1980-81. More telling still is the cumulative fall in road grants to Victoria compared with what they would have been if the Commonwealth had maintained the 1975-76 level for five years to 1980-81. No doubt now the Liberals in Victoria-probably as time goes by even those in this place-will try to blame the Cain Labor Government for the deterioration of roads in Victoria. If they do they will join their Liberal and National Country Party counterparts in other States who already are blaming the Federal Government for the state of their roads because of these cutbacks.

Expressed in 1980-81 prices, using the latest Bureau of Transport Economics index, the total cumulative fall in road funding is $112m over five years. Other States also have to contend with cutbacks in Federal road funds. I have a table showing the figures State by State, but I will indicate only how these cutbacks affect South Australia. Total road grants to South Australia in 1980-81 were approximately 28 per cent less in real terms than they were in 1975-76. The cumulative real fall in funding to South Australia for expenditure on South Australia's roads from 1975-76 to 1980-81-five years-was $77m in real terms. I recall that Mr Tonkin, the now Liberal Premier of South Australia, when he was the Leader of the Opposition and putting forward the State Liberal Party's policy in 1979, said that he fully supported the policies of the Fraser Liberal Government. Now we find his Minister of Transport, Mr Wilson, criticising the Fraser Government because of the lack of road funding. I said at the time that Mr Tonkin was very foolish during that election campaign in saying that he fully supported the policies of the Fraser Government because they were bringing the whole of the Commonwealth into economic ruin. That has come home very vividly to Mr Tonkin in recent months. He is now trying to dissociate himself from Mr Fraser because within the next 10 months we will have an election. The Government cannot go any longer than that. Mr Tonkin is now trying to scuttle away from Mr Fraser and what he is doing to the economy of the country.

At a meeting in Adelaide on 13 April this year between local government representatives and Australian Labor Party members of parliament we were told of the financial difficulties being experienced by local government bodies in South Australia due to this Government's cutback in road funding. It was a very representative meeting. At that meeting were Mr Jim Hullick, Secretary of the Local Government Association, Mr Des Ross, Senior Vice-President, Mr Mike Lennon , Resource Director, and Mr Bob Hart, Secretary for the northern region. The members of parliament who attended that meeting were: Mr Peter Morris, the Federal Labor Party shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Terry Hemmings, State shadow Minister for Local Government, Mr Chris Hurford, the honourable member for Adelaide, Dr Neal Blewett, the honourable member for Bonython, Mr Ralph Jacobi, the honourable member for Hawker, Senator Bolkus, Senator Dominic Foreman, and me. It was a very interesting meeting and we were able to learn a lot.

Arising out of that meeting is an agreement that, irrespective of whether the Labor Party is in Government or in opposition in future years, meetings of this nature should take place at least once a year, if not twice a year, so that each side can be fully informed about the problems-particularly local government problems-and local government people can be informed about the thoughts and policies of the Labor Party. We were given certain documents at that meeting. I will quote from one of the documents that was given to us because it puts the whole problem into a nutshell. It is dated 13 April, and headed: 'Local Government and Trends in Road Funding'. It states:
Commonwealth contributions to Road Funds have been falling steadily since the mid-seventies.

That is borne out in Appendix 1 to the document. I showed the table to the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, when she was at the table and to a Hansard officer and there will be no problems in having it incorporated in Hansard. I will seek leave later to have it incorporated in Hansard after I have quoted from this page of the document. The document states:

2. The projected budget allocation for 1982/83 will continue this trend. Furthermore, the Government's proposal for a 7 per cent increase next year is offered at the same time that the Bureau of Transport Economics has published its long awaited road Construction Price Index. The index demonstrates a road construction price escalation of 15.3 per cent in 1981 following a 15.9 per cent increase in the previous year.
3. South Australia is disadvantaged in relation to its part of the road funding cake. For example, South Australia has-
9.7 per cent vehicle population
9.7 per cent kilometres travelled
12.2 per cent length of roads
15.5 per cent land area
9.3 per cent total population
yet only receives 8.2 per cent of Commonwealth Road Funds.
Is it any wonder that the local government authorities are complaining? The document continues:

In addition, the transfer of the South Australian Railways to the Commonwealth has placed further demands upon our road system. Australian National have continually reduced country rail services in recent times.
I mentioned that earlier. I have continually complained about this matter. The document further states:

4. Local Government will continue to make its contribution to the road system. Local Roads Grants are now based on a total formula approach whereby an 'effort' component will, in part, determine funds received. Moreover, longer-term roads planning is now becoming evident in many areas of the State, demonstrating our commitment vide the Mid-North Region of Councils.

More importantly, South Australian Local Government is now spending an increasingly higher proportion of its total revenue on roads. For example, in 1979-80 16.8 per cent of Local Government revenue was expended on roads. In 1981 -82 (the latest figures available) this proportion has risen to 21.2 per cent-a significant increase.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the table which I have already shown to the Minister and a Hansard officer.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I came away from that meeting with the local government authorities with the view that the notice of motion which I had given was fully reinforced. The notice of motion which I gave in the Senate on 19 August was a result of a meeting held by the Mid-North Regional Organisation for region 8 at Lyndoch on 14 August 1981. Three resolutions were carried at that meeting. I outlined them in a notice of motion hoping that they would come up for debate long before this Bill was introduced in the Parliament and hoping that the Government might take some notice of them. However that was not to be. We are now faced with this legislation and, of course, the resolutions passed at that meeting will be of no event now. The resolutions, which I outlined in my notice of motion, were:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Region in conjunction with the Local Government Association bring to the attention of State and Federal parliamentarians, the considerable concern felt by Local Government at the impact of their funding and other policies which disadvantages Councils particularly:

(a) the shift of responsibilities transferred to Local Government which has not been accompanied by a corresponding allocation of Federal and State financial resources to the levels necessary for maintaining the system; and

(b) the absence of any positive moves by the State Government to carry out its election policies in easing the financial plight of Local Government by contributing its own resources through the Grants Commission in the form of untied grants to Local Government.

(2) That the Region contact all Federal and State parliamentarians representing South Australia and inform them of the state's unjust treatment in comparison to the other States in the allocation of road funds by the Federal Government which has declined to an unacceptable level in recent times.

I was present at that meeting. As I said earlier, Mr Wilson, the South Australian Minister of Transport, was the guest speaker at that meeting. When that motion was carried, Mr Wilson sought leave to make a comment during which he blamed the Federal Government for the problems being experienced by local government in South Australia, particularly in relation to road funding. There are probably many other areas in which the Minister would now take a different tack to that which Mr Tonkin took in 1979 and seek to blame the Federal Government for all the ills that South Australia faces.

Most motorists in South Australia are members of the Royal Automobile Association of South Australia Incorporated. I ask them to take another look at the article in the Motor magazine on the funding sought for their roads. There is a quite extensive article in that magazine. I will not quote it because I am sure that any South Australians listening will reach for their copy of Motor to see what the RAA has to say about the problems it sees facing the motorists in South Australia.

On top of the Fraser Government's contemptuous disregard of the financial plight it has created for the State governments and local government authorities , it bulldozed legislation through Parliament last May abolishing the long- standing discretionary power of State road authorities to decide which national road construction works they should build or put out to tender. We have discussed this matter in this Parliament at some length. We now find that State government instrumentalities, such as the Highways Department of South Australia , which draw up the specifications for any road works have to tender against private road contractors for the very job which they were carrying out most successfully under the administration of the Labor Government. Under the Tonkin Government, much of the work is now being farmed out to private enterprise. A lot of the plant and equipment is being sold at bargain basement rates or leased out at peppercorn rentals so that when the Labor Party gets back into government at the next election it will be faced with the grave problem of finding finance to buy back very expensive road equipment to carry out the road program.

This unwarranted legislation-a political pay-off to the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors-was opposed by all the States irrespective of their political persuasion. It constitutes blatant feather-bedding of wealthy private construction companies. A colleague in the other place, Mr Wallis, the member for Grey, spoke about this happening in his own electorate. He instanced some cases where private contractors had gone broke in years gone by because they had cut their tenders to the bone and the South Australian Government had to come along with its own equipment to finish it. Of course, that delayed the work to some extent. Mr Wallis is conversant with the problems experienced on the Eyre Highway and on the road between Whyalla and Port Augusta. Mr Wallis's speech is in the House of Representatives Hansard of 20 April for anyone who might like to look at what he had to say.

There is absolutely no proof that private contractors build roads better or cheaper than State road authorities or local bodies. That has since been admitted by the Minister for Transport and Construction. The Government acted without regard for the damaging and destabilising effect its decision would have on public road authorities and local government bodies in country towns. Already there is evidence to show that taxpayers' money is being wasted as a result of the blind determination of the Minister for Transport and Construction to ensure that more national road construction works are carried out by private contractors in preference to public road authorities.

Labor in government will restore to the States their former discretionary power over national road construction and end this Government's feather-bedding of wealthy private construction firms. The Government may claim that increased road expenditure does not create employment. However, research of the Bureau of Transport Economics has shown that 64 per cent of direct and indirect expenditure on roads goes to the employment of labour. My time has nearly expired. In opening this debate for the Opposition, Senator Gietzelt moved an amendment that has the full support of honourable senators on this side of the chamber. I have been advised by the Australian Democrats that they have moved a further amendment. I will read the amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt on behalf of the Opposition. He moved:

At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that a substantial supplementary allocation of road grants should be made available to the States, the Northern Territory and local government without delay to-
(a) reduce the backlog of established roads needs;
(b) accelerate the rate of road construction and maintenance works;
(c) improve the efficiency of road transport services;
(d) reduce the incidence of road deaths and injuries; and
(e) assist local government bodies to meet road funding difficulties'.
I hope this amendment has the support of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always regarded roads as a subject of importance to Australia. The need to provide adequate finance for roads is concurrent with that view. I regard roads as national assets that need to be cared for properly and maintained to the highest possible standard. As well as that, I believe our road network has to be extended to cater for the continued development of our natural resources and to provide for an efficient interstate trading program. Apart from these two important factors, I think it is quite significant in respect of our growing domestic tourism industry. I think that by the year 2000 tourism will become one of the most important economic activities in the world. The cost of the construction and maintenance of roads has become a financial monster that provides State governments and local government bodies with tremendous difficulties. That is the reason the Commonwalth Government has to assist in providing finance for this important construction and maintenance activity.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of fact that local government authorities, because of their financial inability to maintain or reconstruct roads, have been forced to rip up some bitumen surfaces and revert to a metal surface, which I believe is regrettable. Some examples of that have been provided to me recently by the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. For example, in the Mildura shire 2 1/2 years ago 40 kilometres of road were ripped up as the seal was in too dangerous a state to remain. Now the shire has to put in $2.50 of council funds for each $1 grant to avoid a continuation of this practice. There are other examples. The Morwell and Warragul shires each recently returned two kilometres of road to an unsealed surface. I have been given to understand that the tearing up of bitumen in the Urana shire is under active consideration. I think it is quite important for the Government to recognise that unless it provides adequate finance at a time when the cost is manageable, or relatively so, the Government will have to face considerable additional expenditure in the future. This was illustrated quite clearly by an article in the Local Government Bulletin of April 1982. It referred to an address given to a previous conference of local government authorities by John Taplin, Professor of Transport Economics at the University of Tasmania. The article reads:

At the symposium on the Australian roads system held in Canberra under the auspices of the Australian Automobile Association two years ago, he told listeners that even if the budget for roads was only 15 per cent deficient according to the BTE's warranted program, the net discounted benefits lost would amount to $484m. To put it another way, for a total investment over a numer of years of $1,301m (discounted) the total benefits would be worth $1,785m ( discounted). These figures are discounted totals to allow for the fact that investing a dollar this year costs more than it would next year-and getting a dollar in return is also worth more now than in the future! Whichever way you look at it, it's a lot of benefits to miss out on-and it isn't hard to work out how much more Australians are missing out on considering that funding for 1981- 82 has fallen a massive 40 per cent short of the warranted program.

I think those points ought to be noted by the Government. The next three-year allocation of funds for the five-year road grants program which was announced in 1980-that is, $734m for 1982-83, an increase of 7 per cent; $778m for 1983-84, an increase of 6 per cent; and $825m for 1984-85, an increase of 6 per cent- seems to me to be rather short of what it ought to be, having regard to the fact that the costs of construction have gone up by an amount in excess of 15 per cent in the year.

Take 1974-75 as a base year. In that year road grants to the States amounted to $362.8m. In 1982-83 at current prices the amount is $709.3m; and at constant prices it is $258.5m. For 1983-84 the current price figure is $751.8m, and the constant price figure is $238.3m, which is a quite significant figure. Those figures indicate that the real terms decline in the decade to 1982-83 will be 36 .4 per cent. In the decade to 1984-85 it will be 39.4 per cent, unless the funding levels announced are reviewed and some notice is taken of that problem in the forthcoming Budget.

As secretary of the Government members committee on local government I have met with the Federal executive of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. As South Australian representative, I also organised a meeting with the local government sub-committee on roads in South Australia, together with my colleagues Senators Teague, Hill, Young and Messner, Mr Porter, Mr Giles and Mr Chapman to discuss this matter. As a result of our discussions and as a result of the local government committee's consultation with the Automobile Association of Australia, the tourist industry and other interested people, we have provided the Government with a submission making certain recommendations that we hope will be taken notice of and will be reflected in some way in the forthcoming Budget. I believe that the Government does recognise the problem. I think that is illustrated quite clearly in the reference in the second reading speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to the report of the Bureau of Transport Economics. The Minister stated:

The Bureau of Transport Economics has recently completed a report on the development of a national road construction price index. The report, which the Minister for Transport tabled on 17 March 1982, indicates that in recent years increases in Commonwealth road grants have not kept up with movements in road building costs.
Therefore, the Government will be examining in the Budget context the scope for the provision of additional road funds.

I look forward with some optimism to that event. I hope that the Federal Government will provide adequate topping up funds for road construction and maintenance purposes throughout Australia. I am particularly interested, of course, in the national highway leading from South Australia to the Northern Territory. Construction work on that project is going ahead and we are looking forward to its completion by the promised date, which I understand is 1987. Other roads in South Australia, particularly in the northern part of the State, need to be given some priority as well. We look forward with some optimism. We hope that the South Australian Opposition will change its head in the sand, non- development attitude to the mineral potential of the Roxby Downs area. Roads will be required as infrastructure to service important areas such as that. This , of course, will benefit the South Australian economy. I stress to the Minister the importance of the Government paying adequate attention to providing further funding to top up the funds necessary for road construction in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1982 which apportions certain moneys to the States for road construction. I think it must be said that if the total Australian Government Budget were used for roads it would not be adequate to provide for our road needs. Therefore it is essential that the money that is allocated be spent wisely and, more importantly, that it be divided fairly. I will discuss the matter of funds being divided fairly later. The Federal Government has taken it upon itself to try to spend Federal funds for roads wisely. We have insisted that all construction of roads in the national highway network be let out to tender. It is obvious that that is necessary if we are to have any idea of how our road construction costs are going and if we are to make any attempt to get best value for the dollar being spent. The mechanism for that is in place and I understand that it is working quite well.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment to the Roads Grants Act will provide grants of $734m to be allocated between the States according to certain categories, namely, national roads, arterial roads and local roads. I think it should be said at the outset that the Commonwealth is really responsible wholly and solely for national highways only. A lot of flack is sent in our direction about many other roads which really are not our responsibility. Arterial roads and local roads are the sole preserves of the States and local government. We provide funds to them but they are mainly funds of a topping-up nature. I know that, when I move around the country, and I dare say the same thing applies to all other senators, I meet deputations and have brought to my attention the need for more funding for roads . Much of the funding sought is for roads over which the Commonwealth has no jurisdiction whatsoever. I think it should be understood that we are responsible for national highways and that other roads are the responsibility of the States and local government.

One way in which we have helped local government is through income tax sharing. Everybody knows that the local government share has now risen to 2 per cent. That, of course, is not enough. I would be very interested in a survey of the percentage of local government moneys spent on roads now as against what was spent 20 or 30 years ago. I rather suspect that many other priorities have been inserted in the local government system and that the priority for roads has fallen a bit behind. I suspect that even the extra money that is now available is not being spent on roads. Nonetheless I think that overall all governments should take road funding far more seriously. Last year a defence statement was brought down in which we were told that we are to buy a tactical fighter force replacement aircraft, the FA18. I find it inconceivable that we have given permission for an open-ended purchase. We do not know yet what that aircraft will cost but this Government has said: 'Yes, we will buy that aircraft'. I am not denigrating the aircraft; it is a superb aircraft. But I think we could certainly get our act together a bit better when it comes to such purchases. We have an open-ended arrangement for the purchase of this aircraft, the ultimate cost of which is not yet known to us, yet we cannot look at roads in the same manner. We have open-ended defence contracts but I look upon roads as being as important as any of our defence procurements. In addition, roads have a developmental role to play. I think the Government should be looking far more seriously at a developmental and defence role for our road networks. Even before I went to school and when I was allowed to wait for the mail truck at the front of my farm I can well remember seeing convoys going to the north during World War II. Sometimes those convoys would use our front paddocks as overnight bivouacs. Although our road system has advanced since that time I still do not think we take it seriously enough from a defence point of view.

As I have just said, if we have open-ended contracts for defence procurements we certainly can look at our road networks far more seriously when it comes to apportioning Commonwealth moneys. When it comes to getting those moneys for roads there is vast competition for funds in Canberra. Many good causes are put up by various bodies-various echelons of government. That competition is never ending. That is how it should be. But I think it is essential that good cases be put up when we are after money for roads. With all the ragings of the various State governments through the Press the only documentation that I have seen that presents a solid case is that which has been provided by the Commonwealth through its own Bureau of Transport Economics reports. I find that a pretty sorry state of affairs. We as senators, and our colleagues in the State parliaments, can say what we like in our own States through the Press. That counts for nought in Canberra. What we need in order to put up a case in Canberra is good documentation. As I said, the only documentation we have is that which has been provided by our own BTE reports.

One does not have to be a Rhodes scholar to know that road funding has not kept up with consumer price index increases. Those facts are there for everybody to see. I think the Government has been neglectful in that area. As has been mentioned already the BTE road construction price indexes for 1969-70 to 1980-81 show that road construction costs have increased at a greater rate than the CPI. That was not told to us by any other road authority. It was told to us by our own BTE in its report. I welcome that report. At least it has now given the Commonwealth something on which to hang its hat. It can now look seriously at the increases in road funding which are so necessary for the development and defence of this country.

We have before us two amendments, one which has been moved by the Opposition and one which has been moved by the Australian Democrats to that moved by the Opposition. Frankly, I find such amendments rather hypocritical when we have seen the stand taken by the Opposition on other issues. The chickens are really coming home to roost. A combination of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats took some of the revenue from the Commonwealth Government when they rejected the sales tax legislation. That happened only a few weeks ago , yet here they are asking for more money. It should be on the record that that action took $130m away from us this year and will take $330m in the next financial year-moneys that could well have been spent on the road system of Australia. We have this hypocrisy of taking away and then expecting the Commonwealth Government to give. As far as that hypocrisy goes the chickens have really come home to roost.

A further matter at which we should look is the question of dividing funds fairly. As I said earlier, the Commonwealth is responsible only for the funding of national highways. Once again, the only documentation that I have seen which puts a case is the BTE publication 'An Assessment of the Australian Road System 1979'. The BTE, which is an instrumentality of the Commonwealth, not of the States or of any other authority, provides this documentation which shows that Queensland has been badly treated. It is ironic that our own Commonwealth figures-we are being belted over the head by the States with our own Commonwealth figures-in this instance show quite rightly that Queensland is being badly treated in the apportionment of those funds. Table 6.19, to be found on page 151 of the BTE report, shows actual and economically efficient road expenditures. As I have indicated, a breakup of those funds shows that Queensland is the only State to be disadvantaged. It also shows that Queensland is the only State found wanting in its own expenditures. I rather hope that this is being taken on board when the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police seeks to obtain more funds from his Cabinet colleagues, not just from us in Canberra where we have to wear those decisions. The Queensland Government has to come to grips with that table in the BTE report. It has to allow the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police more funds.
While there is never enough money, as I have said, it is essential that the money which is available be divided fairly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that your Government is not providing it fairly?

—This table has been brought down by the BTE. Before that we had no table. I point out that the table shows that Queensland is disadvantaged. In the next breakup of funds Queensland should be treated as fairly as other States to make up the difference indicated by those figures. At this stage I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard table 6.19 to be found on page 151 of the BTE report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. If we look at the percentage of national highways in each State as against the percentage of funds allocated to each State we see once again that Queensland is disadvantaged. For instance Queensland has 25 per cent of the national highways, yet it receives only 19.79 per cent of the funds allocated. That is the allocation about which I am concerned. Until we alter that figure to make up the difference year after year Queensland will receive only 19.79 per cent of the funds allocated, whereas it has 25.03 per cent of the national highways. I indicate that Victoria has 4.26 per cent of the national highways, yet it receives 17.46 per cent of the funds allocated. So there is a basic unfairness there. I hope that when the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) reports back to the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) and when this matter is discussed in Cabinet in light of future Budget discussions, we can once again look at roads more seriously and Queensland can get a far better and more rightful share of those funds. We are not asking for something to which we are not entitled. We are only asking for that which the Commonwealth's figures show Queensland should be receiving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity, in this debate on the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1982, to say a little bit about the need for more funds for Queensland. We have just heard Senator Collard from Queensland put a very good case as to why Queensland should have more funds for roads. Inadequate funding for road maintenance and construction in our State of Queensland certainly is a problem. It is also a very real problem as far as local authorities in our State are concerned. Earlier I listened to Senator McLaren talking about honourable senators who might criticise the Bill and yet vote for it. All I want to know is how many times in the 11 years that Senator McLaren has been in the Senate has he actually voted against his party?

—I have never gone against it because we have a different method . We don't go out and say we criticised it. We stick to our policy. We are not like you people. You criticised it but you did not vote against it.

—The honourable senator thinks he is never wrong. I am working on the basis this evening that, if one draws the Government's attention to particular problems, it is possible that it will take some action. The second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will be examining in the Budget context the scope for the provision of additional road funds.

Mr Hinze, the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, has been very outspoken about this matter and I certainly hope that the Commonwealth Government will take notice of the comments made about the need for more funds for roads in Queensland when the next Budget is brought down. Senator Collard gave us some very good statistics on this matter. The amounts provided in the Bill for the next three years involve annual increases of 7 per cent in 1982-83, 6 per cent in 1983-84 and 6 per cent in 1984-85. We have been told that road costs have gone up 15 per cent in the last year or so; it is obvious that the amounts which will be made available by the Federal Government will not be adequate to cover the costs of road construction and maintenance for the next three years.

The Queensland road network is enormous. There are 192,000 kilometres of roads, including 40,200 kilometres of declared roads which are the direct responsibility of the Department of Main Roads. If we consider that Queensland covers an area larger than Great Britain, France, East and West Germany and Italy combined, then we will realise that there is a need for a capable and efficient road system. That can be clearly understood. I also remind honourable senators of the population growth in Queensland. It is growing by approximately 50,000 people a year. They are not just tourists; people are coming to Queensland to settle. This growth can be connected with the great deal of private enterprise required to develop our resource potential. This is good not only for Queensland but also for Australia as a whole because many of these resource industries are export based. This needs to be taken into account. Of course, these developments have increased considerably the need for good roads and good road communications in our State. If one were to look at this problem in purely unemotional economic terms, it would be just as advantageous to the Federal coffers as it would be to Queenslanders themselves to ensure that Queensland had an efficient road system.

Queensland is a very highly decentralised State, having more than 10 cities with populations of 30,000 people. It has vast mining areas and more towns are being developed each year. That is why I feel that Queensland does need an efficient road system. The Commonwealth Bureau of Roads stated in its final report that Queensland should have received $228m in road funds for the 1979-80 year. However, the actual allocation was only $117m. One does not have to be a mathematical genius to work out that that is a $111m shortfall. In the 10 years from 1967-68 to 1977-78 the following changes in Budget allocations took place: Social security and welfare rose from 16 per cent to 27 per cent of Budget outlays; education rose from 3 per cent to 9 per cent; health rose from 6 per cent to 11 per cent; and, unfortunately, road grants fell from 2.6 per cent to 1 .8 per cent in that 10-year period. In 1981-82 road funds fell to 1.68 per cent of the total Budget outlay. As a result of this, the State and local authorities have had to do something about trying to provide further moneys themselves. Queensland has imposed a very big increase in registration fees. I understand that the Federal Government allocates money on the basis of a formula that takes into consideration the size of the State plus the population.
