I am afraid that when it allocates the money it must forget about our extra population. I often hear talk in this chamber about gerrymanders. I sometimes wonder whether these figures might not have been gerrymandered to favour the smaller, more populated States.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must have been Queensland that did it. It is the expert.

—I do not know who did it. We would have looked after ourselves a little better if we had done it. I am sure about that. I have here a newspaper report of a submission made by the Australian Automobile Association to the joint government parties transport committee. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's road system would fail completely without substantial extra funding . . .
The AAA made the submission on behalf of more than 3,500,000 members of the RACQ and its sister clubs.
The article further states:

Federal allocations to the States for roads, as a proportion of total Commonwealth outlays, had dropped from an average of 2.73 per cent between 1955 and 1973 to 1.73 per cent in 1980-81, with a further drop to 1.68 per cent estimated in the current financial year.

Unfortunately, this decline in road funding has occurred during a period when Federal revenues from fuel taxes have increased. Although the State Government and local authorities have been trying to do their bit, as the AAA said, unless funds available to the States are increased substantially, and having regard to the increased cost of maintainance, the inevitable result will be a rapid deterioration in the road network. The AAA made this following very effective statement:
On the other hand, expenditure on roads was a sound investment which would return economic benefits many times the cost of the road works.

These included: fewer deaths and serious injuries on the roads, and consequent savings in medical and social service costs; energy savings; lower vehicle operating costs; reduced private and commercial travel times; lower transport costs, and less unemployment.
The article continues:

'A high standard road system and a high level of mobility are essential for the development of Australia's agricultural, industrial, commercial, energy and natural resources and to cater for people's social, cultural, educational and other needs,' the AAA claimed.

The Bureau of Transport Economics has recently completed a report on the development of a national road construction price index. That report, which the Minister for Transport and Construction tabled in the House of Representatives on 17 March, indicated that in recent years increases in Commonwealth road grants have not kept up with the movements in road building costs. The Minister also indicated that as a consequence of that finding the Government would be examining, as I mentioned earlier, the scope for the provision of additional road funds. Of course, I would welcome that decision, as would all honourable senators. I realise that the Government's deliberations on road fundings have to be undertaken in the light of the need for continued overall restraint in the Budget and the competing funding demands of other Commonwealth programs. However , in view of the fact that the Minister has admitted that there are major deficiencies in our national highways in all States, and furthermore that most problems are in Queensland and New South Wales, I am ever hopeful that the Commonwealth may realise its allocation inefficiencies and act accordingly. I know that the Minister recently had the opportunity to examine at first hand the state of the Bruce Highway between Rockhampton and Townsville. As a result of that rather eye-opening journey he has agreed to an examination by the Commonwealth and Queensland officials of the feasibility of a jointly funded project to bring the Bruce Highway to an acceptable standard within 10 years. That is a rather long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Casey is interested in it too, Senator.

—I just feel that it will give honourable senators a chance to travel on the highway when it is completed and to see what a great place Queensland is. I am sure that if the Minister himself travelled on some of the other roads in Queensland he would initiate similar projects all over the place. I also agree with Senator Collard's statement about good roads being very important from a defence point of view. I am quite sure that I have made myself clear on the matter and my concern about the raw deal that I feel Queensland has had in regard to road funds. I know that the Minister is aware of the deficiencies in the fund allocations to Queensland and I hope that he and his Department will be able to rectify the anomalies and make a more realistic approach to the problem. I am optimistic that now the real cost of road construction has been brought to the Government's attention it will take action as soon as possible to make increased funds available for road construction not only in Queensland but also throughout Australia. I certainly hope that if the Government does not do it before the Budget is brought down it will certainly do something in the Budget about making further funds available for the construction of roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Senate proposes to support the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1982. The provision of funds for roads is an important part of the Government's annual expenditure. This Bill will implement a program over the next three years which is part of the five-year road funding program which the Government announced two years ago. We are now towards the end of the second year of the program. It is an important part of the road funding program in Australia that there should be- as there still is-over a period an indication of future funding so that planning can be done not only by the Commonwealth but also by the States and local authorities. However, as we have progressed in this plan it has emerged that the actual percentage increases for the next three years-7 per cent, 6 per cent and 6 per cent respectively-are in fact less than the index of the road construction costs that is prepared by the Bureau of Transport Economics.

SPEECH.PARA: This problem has been highlighted in this debate. Although honourable senators drew the Government's attention to the problems this is causing, the Government has been aware of them for some time. Indeed, in his second reading speech the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) acknowledged that there was such a problem and that the Government proposed to examine the matter in the context of the forthcoming Budget. Government senators have recognised that this is a matter for Budget consideration and that this legislation is not the appropriate vehicle to engage in any major changes to a program which is simply implementing the five-year program that had been announced by the Government at an earlier stage. Whether anything more can be done or provided-as I said, the Government will be very alert to the concerns that have been expressed-must be looked at in the whole Budget context, and that is when it will be done.

The Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have moved amendments which in broad terms demand that there should be increased allocations both in the present legislation and in any future legislation. Indeed the Labor Opposition amendment seeks larger expenditure, not simply to bring it up in accordance with the current BTE index of road costs but also to reduce backlogs and accelerate the rate of construction and maintenance. Of course, as always happens in these debates in the Senate, the Opposition and, in this case, the Democrats have joined in general terms and said that there ought to be increases in government expenditure here and now and in the future, but they do not put any estimate on what those expenses should be or give any indication of what ceiling they suggest there should be on increased expenditure on roads. We could expend hundreds of millions of dollars more on roads to meet the sorts of matters that have been raised by Senator Crichton-Browne from Western Australia and Senator Collard and Senator Bjelke-Petersen from Queensland. Those huge States have great development works taking place in remote parts. Of course the demand for road construction, including the completion of the national road program and so on, in those areas is enormous.

Government senators recognise as well as the Government that a judgment has to be made about priorities and about the total economic strategy that is required for the nation. These are very difficult decisions that can be made only in the Budget context. Let me simply give the Senate some idea of the costs involved. The provisions this year for an increase in the road grants to meet the BTE index will involve an additional amount of something over $40m. In the coming year that figure will be higher. So we are looking at very large sums of money indeed and ones which have, as I said, to be given very careful consideration in the overall economic strategy of the Government.

As I said, the Opposition, which came in here today with a pious matter of public importance about lack of Government leadership and so on, does not provide any indication of what it would do, how much money it would spend or where it would get the money from. That is the very party which twice this year has deprived the Government of funds. I refer to more than $300m for the next financial year and to over $100m for the current year. The Opposition has the effrontery to come in and ask the Government to spend large sums of money on a specific program which it does not even cost or indicate what ceiling it wants to place upon it. I hope that the Senate will not pass the amendment to the motion which has been moved by the Opposition and that it will give the Bill, with its beneficial provisions of funds for the coming years, a speedy passage.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Haines's to Senator Gietzelt's amendment) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Gietzelt's), as amended, agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one matter that I wish to raise and to clarify, that is, the interjection by Senator Bjelke-Petersen criticising members of the Australian Labor Party who were not prepared to cross the floor on issues such as this. I remind Senator Bjelke-Petersen that members of the Labor Party are elected on the policy of the party. We are duty bound, and not afraid, to support that policy. We do not run around the country making pious promises that, if we are elected, we will do other things and saying that we are free agents. It has been proven here today that Senator Bjelke-Petersen, although she was very critical of the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1982 because there was not enough money allocated to Queensland, is not a free agent. She is trapped in the policies of her party. I have no objection to that, but I object to people such as Senator Bjelke-Petersen saying that they are free agents and can do as they like with regard to legislation. We have had conclusive proof today that this is not so.

SPEECH.PARA: During a debate in this chamber some time ago on road finance many statements were made by Senator Jessop and Senator Kilgariff that they would support the promise made by Mr Sinclair in Alice Springs during the 1977 election that a Federal Liberal-National Country Party Government would set up a special fund to construct the Stuart Highway. That promise was broken. Senator Bjelke-Petersen made mention of the fact, when I chided her about this legislation, that promises made by Mr Hunt would be honoured in the Budget. I remind her of the promises made by Mr Sinclair. They were never honoured. At that time former Senator Bishop moved an amendment to the Appropriation Bill with regard to the Department of Transport to set up that special fund in conformity with Mr Sinclair's promises. When it was put to the vote Senator Kilgariff, who was a great advocator of this proposal, and Senator Jessop, who was most vocal, walked out of the chamber and refused to vote.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen has accused me of not being prepared to cross the floor . In the time that I have been in this chamber, no Government senator or, to my recollection, no Government member of the other place, has ever been prepared to cross the floor and vote with the Opposition if it meant bringing down the Government. They will cross the floor on things that do not matter, but never when the opportunity of bringing down the Government, to back up something that they have said in the electorate. The honourable senator should not in the future make pious promises and accuse the Government of not providing money for roads and then come into the chamber and vote for the very thing for which she has stood on the public platform in her State and criticised the Government.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Durack) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Governor-General Amendment Bill 1982 is a small and relatively unimportant Bill which proposes that the annual salary of the Governor-General, which is now $37,000, should be increased to $70,000 a year tax free. It is not a very important Bill. It is a very simple proposal. It will provide a salary increase for the Governor-General . I just want to make some comments, however, about the enormity of the increase and to indicate that the Opposition opposes the proposal contained in the Bill. I think a few things can be said about the size of the increase compared with the hardship that many ordinary Australians are facing as a result of government economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it quite clear that in pointing these things out the Opposition is not reflecting in any way upon the personality or appropriateness of the new appointee to the office of Governor-General. I might say that personally I regard the new Governor-General as a great and distinguished Australian. My personal sadness stems from the fact that the High Court of Australia has lost a great judicial mind. I am sorry that that great judicial mind will now be serving this country in the capacity of what I would regard as a dead-end job. We do not in any sense make any qualifications about the appropriateness of Sir Ninian Stephen as a distinguished Australian for this appointment. But the salary which is fixed by this legislation involves questions of principle and of practice on behalf of this Government.

The size of the increase is a demonstration of the Government's lack of sensitivity to the problems faced by ordinary Australians and the lack of consistency shown by the Government in relation to wages policy and incomes policy, or the total absence of incomes policy. Day after day the Government expresses concern about the demands of wage earners who are trying to support their families. It calls for wage restraint and blames many of this country's problems on the move by ordinary wage earners to maintain their living standards . This proposed huge increase in the Governor-General's salary is an extraordinary example of inconsistency and double standards.

I think a number of points should be made. While ordinary Australians experience a decline in living standards, a decline in government services, rising interest rates, rising costs for consumer finance and a rising inflation rate, calculations show that an increase of $27 would have been required, for example, in the average income of an Australian family to restore real spending power to what it was when the Fraser Government came to power. This conclusion is not only advanced by the Opposition but also supported by the Australian Taxpayers Association. So the Government should not be hectoring ordinary Australians about their response to declining living standards and calling for restraint only in the wage sector at the same time as it is dispensing largesse to the office of Governor-General or any other office of a similar kind.

I simply make the point that there is to be a 90 per cent increase in salary. When one takes into account the fact that the Governor-General's expenses are largely covered by separate appropriations for accommodation, transport, living expenses, et cetera, one sees that the salary is very much in the pocket money category and is largely available for the Governor-General to dispose of as he wishes. A $70,000 tax free income is the equivalent of $150,000 in annual taxable income. I do not want to say much about the way in which the increase was calculated. I recognise that the salary is not to be altered during the term of the present Governor-General and a calculation of projected increase has to be made in that regard. But the rate of increase is enormous. It represents in real terms an increase of 50 per cent over the rate of remuneration paid to the present distinguished Governor-General during his period of incumbency of that position.

The Opposition takes the view that no rational explanation has been given as to why there should be an increase of this size and objects to it. It objects not so much to the actual salary as to the method of calculation, the absence of any explanation as to why it has been calculated in this way and the absence of any understanding of increased duties which will be required of the new Governor- General which might justify such a salary increase. The Opposition is concerned about the symbolism of an increase of this size in a society where there is very considerable dissention about the levels of remuneration. It is concerned about the fact that some positions such as those of Governor-General and some of the State Governors involve the incumbency of positions which are very lavishly endowed in terms of factors other than salary and these factors have to be taken into account.

I just make the point that the expenditure on the office of Governor-General is indeed very high. It is of the order of $1m in 1981-82, excluding salary factors . So we see there is no justification for handing out this particular largess. It is undesirable, as I said, in circumstances of the symbolism involved. But I do not want to pursue this matter with any recriminations about the actual worth of the man himself, who we regard as a distinguished Australian and who we are confident will provide great service to this country in the office of Governor- General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite are very lucky people. Madam Acting Deputy President, we should sell tickets; we might be able to pay off the deficit. The speech we have just heard from the Leader of the Opposition ( Senator Button) rather showed that he is in somewhat of a dilemma. Like all Australians he welcomes the proposed incumbent at Yarralumla, yet somehow or other he had to put up an opposition argument as to why the proposed incumbent should not have the salary increase. I think it is fair to say, without being rude to my friend Senator Button, that he really did not have his heart in what he was saying.

SPEECH.PARA: I take issue with Senator Button on one thing in particular that he said; that is his statement that he regretted that Sir Ninian was going off to a dead-end job. I do not see the position as a dead-end job. I never have done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you after it?

—Careful, careful. As I understand whatever one can understand about the Australian Labor Party's proposed ideas of altering the Constitution, the Labor Party has not put forward the sort of proposition that we should amalgamate the two positions of head of state and head of government. Therefore, even if the Labor Party were to get the sort of Constitution it wants it would still most likely have a head of state separate from a head of government. Irrespective of whether we like it, the part of the Constitution involving the powers and the functions of the Governor-General is not likely to be altered for quite a long time. Therefore, the office of the Governor-General is not a dead- end job. It may be that only once in every 75 years a Governor-General will have to make a momentous decision, but I would have thought that we should always have occupying that position a person who has the capacity to make the ultimate decision should he think it fit to do so. He is perhaps the only man in the country who cannot pass the buck upwards. He and he alone must make the ultimate decision. For that reason, whether he ever makes that decision is an irrelevance . One ought to have in that office a person of such quality that he has the capacity to withstand the loneliness of decision making-a man who will make the right decision when it is made. I would have thought that even the Opposition would agree these days--
—Kerr should have got a great amount retrospectively according to that argument.

—I was trying to argue that heads of state ought to be paid so that we can get the sort of person who in a moment of crisis can act for the good of the nation. If one is talking about making payment retrospective, one should not overlook the fact that a government led by a Prime Minister of the Leader of the Opposition's party first increased the salary at the end of some 74 years and appointed the incumbent of whom the honourable senator is trying to be critical. I am one of those simple people who believe that top people ought to receive top salaries. I am reasonably well known for saying that if one pays peanuts one will only get apes and monkeys.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why a lot of people think that we should be paid peanuts, given the way some monkeys are now interjecting. I have never walked away from the fact that if one wants to get top people one has to pay top money. That statement of mine-

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am finding it extremely difficult to hear the debate. I ask honourable senators to keep quiet so that I can hear what Senator Withers is saying.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am glad that there is a discerning person from the Opposition in the chair. We ought not to be afraid to pay top salaries to top people. As far as I am concerned, that goes for the majority of the community in Australia. All honourable senators know that this Bill is necessary because of section 3 of the Constitution. I hope that those who wish to amend the Constitution will pay some attention to section 3 of it. I think it has some defects. One defect, of course, is that the Governor-General is still appointed at pleasure. I think it is high time the Governor-General was appointed for a fixed term. From debates in the nineteenth century it is clear there were some quaint ideas then about the relationship between the proposed Governor-General and the monarchy. Australia has moved a long way down the track since the debates of the 1890s. I think it is high time that the Governor-General was appointed for a fixed term. I also think it is time that we provided that the Governor-General can be removed from office only in the same way as judges, that is, on an address from both Houses on proven incapacity.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to have a head of State and to pay him this sort of money he ought to have security of tenure and not occupy that position at the whim of the head of Government for the time being. Judges, of course, have had such tenure almost since 1688. As most honourable senators know, before that date judges, as is the present Governor-General, were appointed only at pleasure. We ought not to overlook the reasons why the terms of judges were altered some 300 years ago from 'at pleasure' to 'good behaviour'. The terms were altered to stop undue influence being exerted on the judiciary. From that date, judges not only had tenure of office but also were paid high salaries to place them beyond temptation. It was never the litigant who would be tempted to bribe the judge. If anybody was going to corrupt the judges then-this possibly applies even now- it was the Executive. Back in the days of the Stuarts it was the King who attempted to influence improperly and corrupt the judges. In those days it was the Crown which attempted to corrupt and improperly influence the decisions of the parliament. The idea was to remove the judges from this area where the Executive could get at them. I think it is unfortunate that the Governor-General does not have the tenure of office that judges presently enjoy.

I agree with the proposition that the Governor-General's salary should not be altered during his term in office. I believe that should be the case because if a head of state's salary cannot be altered during his term of office it is impossible for a government to entice the head of state to do something on the promise of an increase in pay. I know it is an old-fashioned attitude to argue, but I can remember Sir Reginald Wright and the late Ivor Greenwood arguing very strongly in this chamber that once a person accepted a judicial office he should never again have any expectations of promotion, reward or anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that why Wright never went on to the Bench?

—No. I think that is an excellent proposition. For many centuries puisne judges were not appointed Chief Justices-Chief Justices tended to come from outside-because, having accepted judicial offices, they had no expectation of promotion or reward. For that reason, judges normally are not promoted from one court to another. They are not promoted, for example, from a District Court to a Supreme Court. There are very good reasons why judges should not be promoted from a Supreme Court to the High Court.
—Do you believe that without exception?

—No. There is most probably an argument that they never should. Having accepted an office, such a person should never again expect anything from the Crown. He should never be available to be influenced by the Crown. I must say that one of the better things this Government does is to knight immediately those it appoints to the High Court. I think it is wrong to knight people while they are on the Bench or when they retire from it. If they do not have total independence they can be accused of relying on some reward or expecting some reward from government. For that reason, I believe the Governor-General ought not to have any increase in salary during his term of office. For that reason, due to the modern curse of inflation, at the commencement of his term the Governor-General ought to be paid a very high salary. I go along with the idea that the Governor-General's term should not be renewable. He should be appointed for a fixed term. I do not care whether that term is three years or seven years, but I do not think it should be renewable. The Governor-General ought to be totally free from any attempt by the Executive to influence him. I think the same ought to apply to judges. They should not be in positions where the Executive can influence them.

SPEECH.PARA: This brings me to what I consider to be a defect in the legislation, that is, that all the terms and conditions applying to the Governor-General during his term of office and after he ceases to be in office are not spelled out in legislation and too many of those terms and conditions are at the whim of government. Honourable senators will recall that recently Senate Estimates Committee A put down a report in which it criticised the fact that a former Chief Justice was given certain privileges by Executive fiat. I agree with that criticism. If anybody is to receive anything it ought to be done in a legislative form and it ought to be done before that person accepts office. I think it is wrong to offer incumbents, either a head of state or someone in the judicial sphere, something after retirement by Executive fiat. At no time should these people be put in a position where it could be said of them-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Chipp, will you resume your seat please.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. If you consult with the President you will be informed that a position in the gallery has been allocated to the Australian Democrats to have their advisers present for consultation purposes. I hope that you will consult with the President because of your objection to the Australian Democrats using that space. I hope that before embarrassing me on another occasion you will consult with the President and the Clerk of the House to find out that this is the situation.
—I called you to order, Senator Chipp, because you were conversing at the back rails of this chamber. That is not permitted in the chamber.
—With respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, it is permitted. I am asking you to check on that point before you embarrass me again.
—I call Senator Withers.
—He nearly ruined your speech.

—No, I can go on for a week. It was because of the views that I hold that, as Minister for Administrative Services, I put a case to the Remuneration Tribunal concerning the conditions of senators and members. Those honourable senators who were here in 1975 will remember that the Executive interfered and attempted to interfere further with the rights of senators and members. We now have the position in which, apart from disapproval situations, the Executive must accept or reject but cannot interfere with conditions granted to senators and members. It is important that senators and members be free from undue influence or persuasion-call it what one likes. One could even use that old fashioned word 'corruption'. It is because of that that I regret that this Bill does not spell out in full detail all the rights and privileges of the Governor-General during his term of office and during his retirement. He ought not to be in the position of receiving something from this Parliament by way of Executive favour after he retires. Such a situation takes away the independence of the Head of State. I believe it takes away the independence of judges. It ought not to exist.

SPEECH.PARA: The Remuneration Tribunal now sets almost all the facilities and conditions of honourable senators and honourable members while they are in Parliament and after they go. All persons who ought to be independent of Executive influence ought to be placed in the same position. I regret that all this is not spelt out in this Bill. I urge those who are interested in constitutional reform to pursue this matter. How does one protect people from the undue influence-I put it no higher than that-of Executive government in our time? I refer, of course, to a range of people. There is the Head of State; there is the judiciary; there are members of this Parliament. Honourable senators who read the reports of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations will know that that Committee has addressed itself to the actions of members and particularly chairmen of statutory authorities. One does not allege that corruption has taken place. Almost 300 years ago the people who drafted the so-called Bill of Rights were well aware of this matter. Therefore, they took steps to give judges tenure and proper pay and proper pensions to remove them from the influence of the Executive. I hope that as time goes by some of my remarks will be picked up. I welcome the person who will be incumbent in the position of Governor-General. I think he and his wife are very great Australians. They will do the job magnificently. They are well worth every cent of the $70,000 that will be paid.

My final remark is that if this Government believes that the head of state ought to be paid a proper sum-I agree with it-and that judges ought to be properly paid so that we can get the best calibre people to go on to the Bench and if it is believed that public servants in the upper echelons ought to be properly paid so that the Government can get the best advice it is high time that the Government took the same attitude to the Parliament. Unless we get better feedstock in this Parliament we will not get better Ministers. Those in the media who are so critical of what is paid to Ministers and other members of parliament and who continue to deride, degrade and sneer at their capacities and boast about their incapacities ought to remember that this problem most probably lies at their door. If people are not prepared to pay the proper money to those who come into this place then they should not complain if there are apes and monkeys running it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I have that repeated? Did you say that apes and monkeys are running it?

—There are apes and monkeys within it. I am one of those people who have been quite open for years about my belief that Ministers in government are quite disgracefully paid for the hours that they work and the responsibilities they bear. I do not put in a bid for myself. I think the sacrifices which members of parliament, particularly the younger ones, are expected to bear are quite intolerable at times. I am delighted, therefore, that the Government has recognised that the head of state ought to be properly paid. I hope that the Government will recognise that this should flow through to a number of other people in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Withers on his emergence from semi-retirement and on making a splendid speech. I agree certainly with the thrust of what he had to say and generally with the detail. The Australian Democrats will support the Governor- General Amendment Bill 1982. I commend the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) on his speech too. The Australian Labor Party is opposing this Bill because, as I understand it, it believes that the tax free salary of $70,000 to be given to the incoming Governor-General is too high. The Labor Party has a right to say that. It has said that. I think Senator Button said it with dignity , without embellishment and without sensationalism.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fine line decision how much is set as the salary of a person who will be in a position for at least five years and possibly eight years-the term is capable of being extended by another three years. The Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia forbids any increase or any variation of the Governor- General's salary once the appointee has taken office. Therefore, whilst in 1982 values the $70,000 per annum tax free does seem, to say the least, to be a fairly healthy sort of remuneration it will not be subject to any increase, any adjustment, for at least five years. If Sir Ninian Stephen is re-appointed at the end of five years to serve a total of eight years, then certainly, even at today's rate of inflation, eight years from now Sir Ninian's salary will not compare favourably at all with that of, say, a judge of the High Court of Australia. As I understand it, the factor that influenced the Cabinet in determining this figure was that Sir Ninian retired from the High Court Bench to take this appointment before he attained the age of 60 years. Therefore, he forsook any of the superannuation rights that would have pertained to him had he remained in that office beyond the age of 60 years. Section 3 of the Constitution states:
The salary of a Governor-General shall not be altered during his continuance in office.

About whom are we talking? We are talking about the Head of State in Australia, a person with enormous powers. This person has the power to refuse to sign a Bill that has been passed by the two democratically elected Houses of this Parliament. I vigorously disagree with that provision in the Constitution. I think it is monstrous that an appointed person, a person not subject to election , not subject to any form of removal by the people themselves, should have the power to refuse to sign a Bill that has been passed by the House of Representatives, whose members are all democratically elected, and by the Senate , whose members are all democratically elected also. Be that as it may, that is part of this person's powers. I believe that that is a terrifying power. Certainly, I think that any person fit to occupy that position needs to be remunerated in the way which Senator Withers has described.

As we know, the Governor-General has the power to grant a double dissolution, a dissolution of both Houses of Parliament. There is, as all of us know, a very large grey area about when a head of state or a Queen's representative should or should not grant a double dissolution. We remember the speech in India of the former incumbent, Sir John Kerr, in which he said that a Governor-General was not obliged to follow the advice or request of the Prime Minister of the day and grant a premature election or a double dissolution simply because the Prime Minister of the day asked for it. He felt that there had to be in the Governor- General's mind a view that there was some instability in the country. I am not canvassing the view put by Sir John Kerr in India in 1975. But it is a respectable view and one which has to be thought of when a new person is to be appointed to this position and when his remuneration is to be contemplated by the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish we had thought of it--

—I do not want to go into that, Senator McLaren-through you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I simply remind Senator McLaren that it was the Australian Labor Party which appointed Sir John Kerr and I leave it at that.
—Order! Senator Chipp, please address your remarks to the Chair.

—I did direct my remarks to the Chair, Mr Acting Deputy President. I took specific care to do so. The intention of the level of this office as seen by our founding fathers can be demonstrated by the salary that was fixed in 1900 . Then the salary of the Governor-General was fixed at #10,000. It is interesting to note that three years later the Judiciary Act fixed for the first time the annual salary of the Chief Justice of Australia at only #3,500 per annum. As I understand it, the #10,000 then awarded to the first Governor- General was tax free so it was more than three times the salary of the then Chief Justice.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats believe that constitutional reform is urgent in this country. We have been and are continuing to be in the forefront of bipartisan efforts towards constitutional reforms. I am very pleased to be a member of several groups with Senator Missen and Senator Gareth Evans to encourage this bipartisan debate throughout the country. Urgent though these reforms may be, we believe that such reforms can be achieved only after careful examination of the consequences of the changes proposed and after considerable consultation at all levels of the community. If these changes result in a substantially different role for the Governor-General-I for one hope that they will-it may become possible to review the administrative and financial arrangements of the office. But until that time it seems abundantly clear to the Democrats that the principle of effective and visible independence, espoused so wisely by our founding fathers and repeated today by Senator Withers, must be preserved now more than ever. Our decision to support the Government rests mainly on this principle. However, it would be less than courteous-indeed it would be unjust-to ignore the requirement for extremely exacting standards of judicial expertise as well as the deep sensitivity for the values of a vital, diverse and changing community needed in Australia today. It must be a matter of some regret that this capacity is to be lost to the High Court. While this regret is strengthened by some recent decisions of that court, it is outweighed by the sense of relief that this capacity will now be available, if called upon, to deal with matters of great complexity and overriding constitutional importance. I remind the Senate that almost daily, unhappily, there is speculation in the media, inflamed and encouraged by Mr Fraser and Ministers, that there will be an early election; that there may well be a double dissolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course there will.

—I am delighted to have the benefit of Senator Townley's advice. I am sure that opinion makes a significant contribution to this debate. I am sure that every honourable senator has been breathless waiting to hear what Senator Townley felt about the possibility of a double dissolution. Be that as it may, there is speculation in the community daily about this particular matter. It is not a matter that can be taken lightly. The man who would have to make that decision is the person whose salary we are debating this afternoon. I am certain that the same force of mind and spirit would have been brought to bear on any constitutional crisis should this have been encountered during the term of the present Governor-General, Sir Zelman Cowen. Bearing in mind the present state of representation in the two Houses, this is not a remote possibility and the consideration lends urgency to the reforms now in progress. In the event, this did not become necessary and His Excellency has been able to engage in a healing process and to gain new dignity and respect for the office and a measure of community consensus on the value of stable government. It is a considerable achievement on the part of Sir Zelman Cowen and the Democrats acknowledge it with gratitude.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous contributors to this debate have made much of a comparison of the salaries of other high officers of the Commonwealth with the current Governor- General's salary of $37,000. We rest our support for this Bill mainly on the principle that economic independence is the essential element for this office, as referred to by Senator Withers. Nevertheless, I notice that if the proposed amount of $70,000 per annum tax free is transposed into a figure that would be taxable, the salary would be something of the order of $149,000 per annum. In reality if the Governor-General had to pay tax on his salary, he would be receiving something like $149,000. That figure is in excess of the salary of $87 ,000 of the present Chief Justice, on which he has to pay tax, but I repeat that the Governor-General's salary will have to remain constant for at least the next five years and possibly the next eight years whereas that of the Chief Justice and other Justices of the High Court will probably be reviewed and increased each year. The initial term of appointment is for five years and clearly it is the Government's intention to compensate the recipient of a fixed salary for its diminishing real value. My calculations are subject to correction but, if the Government's calculations are correct in equating this particular fixed salary with that of former brother Justices of the High Court, inflation would have to run at the rate of 13.6 per cent for each of the next five years. I say that just as a matter of passing interest. It seems to be the figure arrived at by the Government as to what the real inflation rate might be during the next five years when it has tried to bring justice to the salary to be paid to the incoming Governor-General when he assumes this most important office.

TALK.START.PARA: —That only puts him on the same basis as judges, not a higher one .
—I have made that point. I thank Senator Missen for his interjection. The Democrats commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party does not oppose the principle of an increase in salary for the Governor-General of our country. However, it does take issue with the degree of emolument which this legislation proposes should be paid to the new Governor-General when he takes office later this year. Of course, an argument will always be put forward that we should pay a salary commensurate with the responsibility of office. We do not quarrel with that but we certainly quarrel with the concept that increases the salary of the new Governor-General some 89 per cent as from the date of the retirement of the present Governor-General and the accession to office of the new Governor-General. This is an exorbitant increase in anyone's language, particularly from a Government that says that it has inflation under control and that all Australians should make some sacrifice in terms of their wages and salaries. Of course, we know that this Government can readily be described as a government of double standards. It has one law for the privileged and one law for the rest of the citizens of this country. We must have regard to the fact that this is the Government that has just recently persuaded the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that there should be no increase in salary for one- quarter of our work force which is not in an economic position to get the sorts of wage increases that have already been won at the bargaining table for a vast section of the Australian work force. That Commission has been persuaded by this Government that financially everybody in Australia should tighten their belts. I think it is worth recalling the point made by Senator Chipp a moment ago that the tax free emolument to be paid to the Governor-General by virtue of this legislation in fact means that he will receive an income of $150,000 a year. That will make him, I am sure, the highest paid public official in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We quarrel with the extent of that increase. We believe that if there is to be belt tightening in this country-that is the philosophy of the Fraser Government- everybody should be placed in the same position as the largest section of the Australian people, including those sections that Senator Withers referred to. I remind the Senate of the wage increase awarded through the Remuneration Tribunal in July last year to those eminent gentlemen who constitute the Federal Arbitration Commission. They were given an increase in salary of $8,000 as a result of the decision by the Remuneration Tribunal. That represented a 12 per cent increase. They had their daily allowances increased from $72 to $90 a day, an increase of 25 per cent. Of course, that put the judges who sit in judgment upon the wage claims of the great bulk of the Australian people in a position in which they profited as a result of decisions of this Government. At the same time this Government decided in respect of the $6,000 allocated to members of the national Parliament that they should have their salaries reduced by $3,000 as from 1 July last year and that the second $3,000 awarded by the same Remuneration Tribunal should take effect as at 1 July 1982. Honourable senators will see the sort of double standards that this Government pursues.

Judges of the Arbitration Commission will have a 12 per cent increase in salary and a 25 per cent increase in allowances. Members of parliament will have their salaries decreased by 50 per cent. At the same time, we are asked to provide an increase of some $33,000 which represents, according to my mathematics, an increase of 89 per cent in respect of the emolument to be paid to the Governor- General. Of course, what has not been referred to in the debate is that not only is the emolument tax free but also the taxpayers of this country provide the accommodation for the Governor-General in the capital city, in Sydney and in other places throughout Australia. The Governor-General also gets free meals, a plentiful staff, motor cars and all the other fringe benefits that go with the office of Governor-General provided by the taxpayers of this country. There is no argument about staff, and the staff's wages and salaries as is applied to the members of the national Parliament.

Whilst all this is happening we find that the bulk of the Australian people have seen their interest rates rise by 4 per cent in the last two years alone. Payments on an average home loan have increased by something like $88 a month. The average pay-as-you-earn taxpayer now pays $1 in taxes to the Commonwealth Government for every $3 that he earns, whereas seven years ago when the Fraser Administration came to office he paid $1 for every $4 earned. The average family now pays $10 a week for health care because of the Frasers Government's latest health scheme and because of the increase in sales tax which is costing the average home owner approximately $6.50 a week. In fact the average skilled worker in this country is some $24.50 worse off. Judges sit in judgment and decide that the citizens of this country should have their belts tightened and should not have an increase in salary. We take issue with the hypocrisy, the humbug and the deception that this Government practises in respect of the salaries and emoluments that it wants to pay to those occupying high positions in the administration of this country.

Of course we do not disagree that the salaries of the Governor-General, judges, public servants, wage earners and members of parliament ought to be indexed. There ought to be a principle applying across the board that is fair and equitable to every citizen. But that is not the attitude of this Government and it is not the attitude of Government senators when, time and time again, they support the philosophy of this government which is that the average citizen of this country should be economically disadvantaged week by week and not be able to meet the increased costs which are so much part now of the way in which the average citizen in this country operates. I remind the Senate that that $70,000 provided for in this legislation will be paid tax free. If we look at the degree to which the average taxpayer is contributing towards Federal income-that is, for every $3 he earns he gives $1 to the Commonwealth Government-we will see a very interesting comparison in that we should be giving to the Governor-General a salary of the nature of $70,000 a year to do what? Everything is provided for him; accommodation, meals, travel and staff. The $70,000 is pocket money because everything else is provided by the taxpayers of the country. Of course, the judges in the Arbitration Commission say piously that they do not believe that the wage earners of this country are entitled to an increase in salary because of the prevailing economic conditions.

If that is the yardstick to be applied, it ought to be applied across the board starting from the top: The Governor-General, the judges in the High Court and the Commonwealth Arbitration Commission, right through to the senior permanent positions in the First and Second Divisions of the Public Service. All of these office holders have been awarded substantial increases in salary since the last time the Remuneration Tribunal dealt with these matters. Of course, the same yardstick is not applied because the Government assists in every way possible those in high places to the disadvantage of those in the lower income scale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am gratified by the debate on this measure, the Governor-General Amendment Bill 1982, although a little disappointed that the Labor Opposition has decided to oppose the salary increase, although not the principle of a substantial salary increase for the Governor-General. However, the views expressed in this debate have only commended very warmly the choice of the new Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, who has now retired from the High Court of Australia in order to take up his new position in the near future. But it is very important that there should be, as has been expressed in this Parliament, very strong bipartisan support for that appointment and for the role that the Governor-General is called upon to play.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a little unfortunate, I think, as Senator Withers said, that Senator Button, leading in the debate for the Opposition, should have spoken about the job as a dead-end one because, quite clearly, it is not. Senator Chipp also emphasised that point. I should have thought that members of the Australian Labor Party would, in view of their complaints about what the Governor-General did in 1975, have been the last people to regard the position in that light. The most important job in Australia is the head of state. It involves the representation of the Australian people. The incumbent of the office has performed that role in a very distinguished way. I am sure that Sir Ninian Stephen will also do so.

The debate has centred on the size of the increase of the salary but, as has been recognised, the Constitution provides that the salary cannot be altered during the period in which the Governor-General is in office. That is commonly taken to be a period of about five years. The unfortunate rates of inflation that we have come to live with and which we must project for the near future indicate that at the end of a period of five years the salary of $70,000 will not have the same purchasing value. That is one of the major factors which has led to the figure being fixed at $70,000. I think it has been recognised by Senator Chipp that a convention, and in one sense a statutory provision, has been established in fixing a relativity between the salary of the Governor- General and that of the Chief Justice of the High Court. The legislation provides for the pension of the Governor-General to be geared to the retirement pension of a chief justice.

When these provisions were introduced in 1974 by the then Labor Government a salary of $30,000 a year was fixed for the Governor-General. At that time that salary was considerably in excess of the net salary of the Chief Justice of the High Court. Indeed over the last couple of years the existing salary of the Governor-General has fallen below that of the after tax salary of the Chief Justice of the High Court. So relativity has fallen. If a salary increase of the order of that proposed were not given over the next few years that relativity would again be displaced and it would be highly probable that the Governor- General's salary would fall quite significantly below the salary of the Chief Justice. As I think Senator Chipp recognised in his speech that is one of the important bases on which the salary has been fixed.

As I said, although I am pleased that there has been strong support for the new holder of the office, it is a pity that there has not been complete bipartisan support for this measure. However I am pleased that there has been sufficient support for it and I hope that the Senate will give it a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some time now-for several months in fact-the general public, the Senate and the Government in particular have had available to them information concerning a particular use being made of section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I refer to the use being made of the taxation Act by a film production company-United American and Australasian Film Productions Pty Ltd-which gathers investment from Australian investors on the basis that an investment of $1 yields a 375 per cent tax deduction. Those investment moneys are invested not in Australian films, generally speaking, but in overseas films. As I said this matter came to public attention some months ago but I am particularly concerned that the Government has refused to make clear its attitude to this use of section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

SPEECH.PARA: This scheme was described in some detail in an article by Maximilian Walsh on 4 February this year in a weekly journal called Australian Business. Subsequently it has been critically discussed in all of the responsible newspapers in this country. On 13 May the Age had an editorial which was highly critical of this use of section 51 of the tax Act. It concluded by stating:

. . . the diversion of Australian funds into foreign films at the expense of Australian taxpayers is contrary to the national interest, even if some of these films have some tenuous Australian link. This exploitation of the tax law should be stopped.

Despite the fact that the matter has been raised in the Parliament, by way of questions and some debate, the Government has refused to make its position clear . This is a particularly irresponsible failure on behalf of the Government because apparently it went to great pains over the last couple of years to develop and introduce a particular provision in the tax Act to attract investment in Australian films and to provide some necessary economic stimulus to the Australian film industry. That provision is controversial and its implementation uneven but by and large its justification is that it has assisted local industry. On the other hand we have the operation of another scheme, the legality of which is considered to be dubious by many experts in the area, which offers a much more generous tax deduction to people who participate in it and the investment from which does not go into the Australian industry.

I think it is important that the Government make some specific response on this issue. Is it the intention of the Government that section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act be used in this way? Does this scheme, which provides a tax deduction of 3.75 times the actual investment made by the individual and which has been operating in this country without challenge by the Australian Taxation Office, represent Government policy on attracting investment into the film industry? Public comment on this scheme by Treasurer John Howard as reported in the Australian Business on 4 February was equivocal, and this is not good enough . The Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, has been questioned about this matter by Senator Hamer but her reply in Hansard of 18 May was inadequate. All it did was confirm that section 51 was being used in this way. The other matter which Senator Hamer raised in his question as to the effect of this practice on the Australian film industry was not addressed by the Minister in her reply. Maximilian Walsh, in the Australian Business article, pointed out:
The continued success of the scheme depends on the Tax Department continuing to regard the scheme as being ''an ordinary business dealing''.

I ask: Is it the Government's intention that the Australian Taxation Office continue to regard this use of the tax Act as an ordinary business dealing? It must also be asked why the Government is tolerating two film investment schemes running parallel-one obviously much more generous than the other and able to be used in an unjustifiably liberal way-whereas the specific film tax concessions available to investors under Division 10BA and section 23H of the Income Tax Assessment Act offer a much less favourable, even though in absolute terms still very favourable, deal to the investor. Division 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act offers a 150 per cent deduction and a 50 per cent exemption but those concessions are available only to films certified as Australian by the Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment. The 375 per cent deduction scheme being used by UAA under section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act is available for any film investment. There is no need for the film involved to be an Australian film. Indeed UAA's films have had in general little or no Australian content. Clearly, if this use of section 51 is allowed to continue it will divert Australian investment money away from the Australian film industry into multinational projects such as The Earthling and Arthur-both UAA productions- which do little for the Australian industry and nothing at all for the reputation of Australian films.

The current operation of section 51 raises the question as to why the Government bothered to introduce the Division 10BA provisions. It also raises some other very serious questions which I believe the Government must answer. For example, how many other overseas producer-financiers are approaching the Commissioner of Taxation for a similar approval of a tax haven? How much revenue has been forgone by the use of section 51 in this matter? The Treasurer (Mr Howard) is quoted as stating that the film incentives introduced last year may cost revenue an estimated $24m. The UAA literature being issued for this year seeks over $28m mainly for overseas productions and offers a deduction of 3.7 times that amount-say a deduction of $106.6m. Mr Picton-Warlow of UAA has announced that substantially more funds will be sought and other films planned. Does this mean that the loss to revenue is a loss of $64m at a tax rate of 60c in the dollar? I think these questions have to be addressed by the Government.

The announcement by UAA that it intended to invest $35m in a studio complex in the Australian Capital Territory ought to be assessed in the light of the cost to the Australian public of tax revenue forgone through UAAs use of section 51. There is abroad a general legal view that the Income Tax Assessment Act provides the Commissioner with several grounds to challenge the UAA partnership deductions. Why is the Commissioner continuing to allow them? If this general legal view is wrong and in fact the Commissioner is powerless to challenge the UAA exercise will the Treasurer move to change the Act retrospectively to the date of his recent announcement on such unintended abuses?

Unlike the special incentives provided for the film industry it is very easy to raise money for such schemes in the last few months of the financial year-that is the period we are in now. What steps will the Treasurer take with regard to deductions and payments made in the current year of income if the scheme is outlawed? It would seem too that UAA is in the business of promoting partnerships and if any offer is made to the public it would then be necessary to register a prospectus with the Corporate Affairs Commission. Is UAA complying with these requirements? Is it the case, for example, that UAA has agents in several States in Australia? Is the Government taking any steps at all to investigate the possibility of a breach of the Companies Act by the UAA partnerships?

I raise this matter because as I said it has been brought to my attention and to that of the general public not only by very critical articles throughout the financial Press but also by many people working in the Australian film industry. It is widely believed in the industry that the operation of UAA in respect of section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act will have a seriously detrimental effect on investment in the Australian film industry. The Government must also be aware, because of the series of controversies surrounding tax concessions for the film industry, that the operation of a scheme such as this and the attention it is getting in the financial Press must bring the whole question of concessions for the film industry into disrepute.

Surely the Government, as it has gone to some lengths to provide tax concessions to help the Australian film industry, ought to be prepared to defend the credibility of those concessions. At the moment the situation is that it appears, and it is widely believed, that a massive rip-off is occurring-that a totally unjustifiable level of tax deduction is being made available via this use of section 51 of the Act and that the benefits of that, the investments attracted by this operation, are not going into the Australian film industry but generally going into the production of films which have nothing to do with our local industry and by this diversion of funds into investment into foreign films it is providing a serious threat to our own industry.

This is the second last day, we believe-I suppose some of us hope-of this session of the Parliament. I think it is important that the questions I have raised go on the record. I think it is absolutely important that the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, and the Treasurer, Mr Howard, no longer retain a silence on these matters and no longer refuse to address the very serious issues that are raised but make quite clear what the Government's policy is. If the Government endorses the operation of the use of section 51 in this case will it drop Division 10BA and section 23H? If it does not endorse this use will it follow the advice of the editorial in the Melbourne Age recently and close the tax loopholes? I think the Senate, the Australian public and the Australian film industry are entitled to an immediate clarification of the Government's intentions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —A prominent Western Australian Liberal lamented recently the moral decay of the Liberal Party in Western Australia. He said the Western Australian branch had been taken over by corporate criminals who hide their real objectives behind a smoke screen of States' rights. Those who have heard Senator Crichton-Browne's passionate objections to the proposed Federal crimes commission might understand what he meant as would perhaps those who have followed the progress of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) through the courts of Western Australia and the Shire of Carnarvon. People who attended the Federal Liberal Party conference the weekend before last will also have gained some insight. One Liberal delegate, from another State, was reported as describing the Western Australian proposition and the Western Australian delegates, by implication as a whole, as bigoted and offensive.

SPEECH.PARA: However, today I want to deal with a more fundamental question than that of the sordid commercial activities of some people in and around the Liberal Party of Western Australia. For more than five years the dominant faction in that party has pursued a policy aimed at disenfranchising the citizens of the State. It started in February 1977 when there was a conspiracy to deprive Aborigines in the Kimberleys of the right to vote. In December 1977 it was followed by an attempt to amend the State electoral Act in a way intended to deprive Aborigines and other illiterate people from voting. That attempt failed because to their credit, two or three Liberal members of the State Parliament, along with the Labor Party and the National Party, voted against it. In 1979 other impediments to enrolment were inserted into the electoral Act aimed at minimising the enrolment and therefore the exercise of the franchise particularly of Aborigines , young people and migrants-those groups which no doubt are perceived to have a higher than normal propensity to vote Labor. I regret to say that the attempt has been highly successful. At the time that that amendment to the Western Australian electoral Act was passed there was a difference of 5,000 in Western Australia between the total enrolment on the Federal roll and the total enrolment on the State roll. The figures as at 4 May this year show that that 5, 000 has grown to 41,000, an extraordinarily high proportion of which are concentrated in the Federal division of Kalgoorlie. No less than 24.6 per cent of the people enrolled on the Federal roll of Kalgoorlie are not enrolled for State electorates within the Kalgoorlie division. Almost one-quarter of the people enrolled on the Federal roll in Kalgoorlie do not have the right to vote in State elections because they are not enrolled on the State roll. Many of them think they are on the roll because they have completed cards. But those cards are cards which, following the 1979 amendments to the State Electoral Act, are not accepted as enrolment applications because they are not witnessed by a justice of the peace, a policeman, a clerk of courts or an electoral officer, as the electoral Act of Western Australia now requires. I do not think I need say any more about that, other than to say that no other government in Australia, State or Federal, has ever found it necessary to impose that sort of impediment to enrolment, to restrict to that degree the people who may sign enrolment applications. If people send in a Federal card and a State card, the Federal one is accepted and they think the State one is accepted also, but in fact it is not . I might add that of those 17,000 people enrolled on the Federal roll in Kalgoorlie who are not enrolled on the State roll, some 5,365 are in the State division, Legislative Council, North Province. That is significant. I might add also that according to the 1981 census some 44,000 people who live in the Federal division of Kalgoorlie are not enrolled on the Federal roll. That figure would have to be increased to something over 60,000 for those who are not enrolled on the State roll.

I have stated the impediments to enrolment on the Western Australian roll and I have pointed out that because people have filled in two cards they believe they are accepted on the State roll. A great number of people-I heard this stated in the town of Newman only a couple of weeks ago-believe that they are enrolled on the State roll when in fact they are not. Last Friday we received the latest instalment of this continuing campaign to disfranchise citizens of Western Australia. The President of the Legislative Council received a letter of resignation from one of the then sitting members for North Province, Mr Bill Withers-I understand he is no relation to Senator Withers. He immediately, last Friday, issued a writ for an election to be held 71 days after the issue of the writ. In the last 10 years no more than 30 days has elapsed between the issue of the writ for any general election and the polling day. For by-elections the time has sometimes been longer but it has never been as long as 71 days. One may ask: Why was the writ issued so hastily when the election is not to be held until 31 July? The answer, I believe, is that the electoral roll closes 14 days prior to the issue of the writ and that the Western Australian Liberal Party and the President of the Legislative Council knew very well that approximately 1,000 people had submitted their names for inclusion on the roll in that 14 day period . But because of the precipitate action taken by the President of the Legislative Council those people will not be allowed to vote in the by-election for North Province on 31 July.

In all of this electoral and other chicanery the Federal Liberal Party to date has meekly complied with the actions of the Western Australian branch, although I know very well that many of its members disapprove of them. Their acceptance of the actions of the Western Australian branch has, however, not always been passive. For example, a Bill which I introduced in the Senate nearly three years ago and which was finally voted on last December-if passed it would have required that all persons of Aboriginal descent in Western Australia who are on the Federal roll would as a matter of law be placed on the State roll-was defeated by the combined votes of the Liberal Party and Senator Harradine.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had almost finished what I had to say when the sitting of the Senate was suspended. I was saying that the Federal Liberal Party had complied, among other things, with the consistent attempt by the Western Australian Liberal Party and the Western Australia Government to disenfranchise 40,000-odd of its citizens and that that compliance had not always been passive, that when a Bill to end that disen- franchisement-at least as far as Aborigines were concerned-was put to the Senate last December that Bill was defeated by the combined votes of Liberal-Country Party senators and Senator Harradine. I intend to resubmit that Bill to give those people another chance. That fixes the position only for Aborigines. The great majority of the 40,000-odd people presently on the Commonwealth electrol roll but not on the State electoral roll of Western Australia are non-Aborigines. That number of 40,000 appears to be growing. For that reason, I intend to propose to the Australian Labor Party that I be allowed to submit a Bill for a referendum for constitutional alteration which would ensure that the Commonwealth electoral roll would become the State roll in Western Australia and Queensland, which are the only two States that still maintain separate State rolls. All other States have found that the Commonwealth roll is adequate as the basis for the State roll. There would obviously be a considerable cost saving, which I have not yet been able to quantify, to both of those States. It would also ensure that the 40,000-odd Western Australians currently disenfranchised at a State level by the deliberate actions of the Western Australian Government would then be enfranchised for State elections as well as Commonwealth elections. It would also provide an opportunity for the Federal Liberal Party to dissociate itself from the chicanery which has been the hallmark of the Liberal Party of Western Australia over a long period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been debating the motion for the first reading of the Excise Tariff ( Petroleum) Amendment Bill 1982. In such debates, honourable senators are entitled to raise any matters they wish to raise, no matter how irrelevant they are to the legislation. It is not common for the Government to respond to those debates but, in view of the remarks which have been made by Senator Ryan and Senator Walsh, I thought I should briefly detain the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan expressed concern about the use of certain tax concessions which have been introduced by the Government to encourage the film industry. She suggested that the concessions are being used for purposes which go beyond the original intent, certainly to ease the burden of taxation without necessarily assisting the Australian film industry. It is not an area with which I am closely familiar. I will ensure that her remarks are drawn to the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle). The attitude of the Government towards tax avoidance and evasion is well known. The Bills which have been introduced in this Parliament to prevent the improper use of technical loopholes in the law are many. I am sure that her remarks will be considered closely. In making those remarks, I cannot adopt what she says and I do not do so. I simply say that it will be brought to the attention of the relevant Ministers.

Senator Walsh followed in the debate by making an attack on a number of things. He made an attack on the members of the Liberal Party of Western Australia. He made that attack on a number of bases and he made an attack on the Western Australian Government's actions with respect to the closing of the rolls for the North Province for a State election. With respect to the people in the Liberal Party of Western Australia whom he characterised as corporate crooks-or he so alleged by way of the words of somebody else-I can only say that, having been in the party for some 24 or 25 years, I believe that his remarks would be regarded as both absurd and offensive by the vast number of the members of that party. They would know how ludicrous what he has said is. The membership of that party is drawn very widely from round the State. It is drawn from primary producers, employees, employers, small businesses and the professions. I think that, if there is a sector under-represented in the Liberal Party, it would probably be what might be categorised as the corporate sector. From my experience, which is close, I believe that its membership indicates that it is not a party of big business. It is a party which is made up of the citizenry of Western Australia and a very broad and representative cross-section. I suppose on most Saturdays at this time of the year I am thrown into contact with a large group of those people, and I can only say that to describe them as other than decent, hard working and loyal people would be an absurdity. On their behalf, I reject the comments which the honourable senator has made.

Senator Walsh hung some weight on the concern which has been expressed by Senator Crichton-Browne about the formation of a national crimes commission, a concern which was echoed by the Minister for Police and Traffic in Western Australia, the Honourable Bill Hassell, a concern which was rooted in the well- known federalist views of the Western Australian Government and, indeed, of the Western Australian Liberal Party. It would be well known to honourable senators that on a range of issues it has been the concern of the Western Australian Government and of the Western Australian Liberal Party to maintain a strongly federalist stance. It is a matter of some pride to me and, I think, to many Western Australian Liberals, that the Western Australian senator who is the Attorney-General in this Government has been instrumental in seeing federalist solutions to such vexed questions as the off-shore settlement and the arrangement of a single line of environmental inquiry instead of the duplicate inquiries which applied when we were re- turned to government in 1975. The concern expressed about the crimes commission is one which, as I have said, is rooted in federalist principles. I think those principles were reflected in the Government's concern to indicate, at the time that it publicly said so, that it was considering the formation of a commission given the results of the royal commissions which were running. It was pointed out that this would not entail the adoption of an additional policing function by the Federal Government but rather that the crimes commission would work through existing law enforcement agencies, both Commonwealth and State.

So, again, I reject the argument which has been put by Senator Walsh. I say to him with great seriousness that if he is so concerned with corruption he might devote some of his considerable forensic talents to investigating the affairs of his own party in States such as New South Wales. I say with some confidence that it is unlikely that any member of my party will be found beaten up by factions of his own party-a recent and well-documented happening in the Australian Labor Party in the State of New South Wales. If there is to be concern it would be very good if the ALP members showed concern about their own backyard. I will back my party against theirs in any circumstances.

As far as the question of disfranchisement is concerned, I believe that there is a very deep concern in Western Australia about the attitude of the ALP towards the Aboriginal vote. I think it would be less than honest of me if I did not say that that was a reality. That concern is rooted in an approach of the Labor Party which is pretty ruthless in this area. It reflects a similiar ruthlessness in the Northern Territory, a ruthlessness which has led to an absolutely absurd approach by the ALP which is dividing the community in those areas where black and white Australians need to live together.
