I would suggest that if there were a little more moderation and concern to ensure absolute fair play on the part of the ALP in these areas we might find that these things were a little more relaxed and there were less difficulties.

As far as the requirement that the Commonwealth roll should apply, I would again say that on federalist principles I would support any suggestion that there is no reason why there should not be different qualifications for voting in State and Federal elections. I would like to make the point that the voting age in this country used to be 21. Some governments chose to reduce that age to 18. I do not believe that there is a fundamental democratic principle involved in whether a person gets the vote at 18 or 21 years of age. There is no reason why the Commonwealth, by its Act, should impose, for example, a voting age on a State electoral system. I think that example could be multiplied many times. I do not believe that we are entitled in this Government or in this Parliament to override State electoral laws simply because we believe that we have a view which is superior to that held in some State. On the basis of the federalist principles I mentioned before I would support the maintenance of State freedom in that area. The matters which have been raised before the Senate tonight are matters which are, as I said, irrelevant to this legislation but which raise important issues. I speak in defence of the membership of the party to which I have belonged for 24 years and I speak in defence of the rights of the States to maintain differences from the laws of the Commonwealth.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to enact the excise tariff alterations made by Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1981) and No. 1 (1982).

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1981) were moved in the other place on 25 August 1981. These proposals, which operate from 1 July 1981, increased the excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil from $174.08 to $177.53 per kilolitre and on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas from $36.67 to $37.07 per kilolitre.

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1982) were moved in the other place on 17 February 1982. These proposals, which operate from 1 January 1982, further increase the excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil from $177.53 to $186. 26 per kilolitre but reduce the excise duty on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas from $37.07 to $20.46 per kilolitre.

The alterations accord with the Government's policy of adjusting the price of indigenous crude oil to world parity as determined by the Minister for National Development and Energy, on 1 January and 1 July each year.
This policy is well established and widely understood by the Australian community. It is based upon sound economic and conservation principles.
The crude oil levy is an important aspect of the policy. It ensures that a fair share of the income from import parity price adjustments goes to public revenue.

Without the levy, taxation would need to be significantly higher in order to finance the services demanded of Government and the gains from import parity pricing would go to the oil producers as a windfall profit.

The success of the Government's crude oil pricing policy has been based upon its openness, predictability and equitable sharing of income gains. That policy requires that in the interests of conservation and responsible management of scarce liquid fuel resources prices of petroleum products be set at realistic levels.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill, the Excise Tariff (Petroleum ) Amendment Bill 1982, provides legislative backing for Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 (1981), which was operative from 1 July 1981, and for Excise Tariff Proposal No. 1 (1982), which was operative from 1 January 1982. Those proposals actually increase the levy on crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas produced in Australia. In round figures the effect of the two Bills is to increase the price paid by Australian oil refiners by just over $2 a barrel, which in a full year I estimate would produce something like $300m extra revenue. The increases are part of the Government's crude-oil policy of some four years standing, which the Australian Labor Party has consistently opposed on the grounds that it is inflationary and that it is not an energy policy, but that it is an excuse to increase taxes in a moderately regressive way, disguised as an energy conservation policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Senate this afternoon has been debating Bills relating to road funding, I think it is pertinent to note the irony of these two Bills coming up today, largely as a result of the Government's crude-oil pricing policy. Road making costs have increased at a much faster rate than prices in general. In spite of that Commonwealth Government induced phenomenon it has failed to maintain the real value of road funding expressed as prices generally. In other words, while road making costs have been increasing at around 16 per cent a year largely because of the Government's crude oil pricing policy, Commonwealth funds to the States for road making purposes have been increasing at around 8 per cent a year. Although the Australian Labor party has been consistently opposed to the policy given expression in this Bill, we will not be opposing it because, as my colleague Paul Keating said in the House of Representatives, it is absurd that the tax has been collected for almost 12 months before the Parliament has had an opportunity to pass judgment on it. I estimate that by now the additional tax collected as a result of the two Bills would be somewhere between $160m and $ 180m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pay for Fraser's latest trip.

—There might even be a bit of petty cash left over after it has paid for the latest trip of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). As I understand the legal position, were this Bill to be rejected by the Senate, the tax which has been collected for almost 11 months in the case of Customs Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1981) would be declared illegal and the Government would be legally obliged to return the money-something between $160m and $180m. Of course , the money would be returned principally to the major Australian producer, Esso -BHP. The Labor Party can see no reason why that should happen. As the least undesirable option we will not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Australian Democrats' spokesman, Senator Mason, in a Press release issued on 4 May-I do not know whether this remains the Democrats' policy -the Democrats will oppose the Bill. In that Press release Senator Mason skated over the problem of the legal requirement to repay the tax already collected were this Bill to be rejected with this facile sentence.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not really a problem, Senator.
—I am about to quote the honourable senator. He should not complain. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It should not be beyond the wit of the Government to devise a means of returning the money to consolidated revenue in some form.

I do not know whether it is beyond the wit of the Government to devise such a means, but it is apparently beyond the wit of the Australian Democrats because no such mechanism was suggested in that Press release or, to my knowledge, in any subsequent statement. Senator Mason continued:
But if this proves impossible, the oil companies could very well reduce the price of petrol for a sufficient period to return the additional money to the Australian motorist.

Again, it remains a matter for wide-eyed conjecture how a Commonwealth government could ensure that that could happen, even if it were the best of options. In short, the Government has any aware and responsible member of the Senate over a barrel on this question. We really have no realistic option but to allow the Bill to pass. However, as a protest against government duplicity I now move the following amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time:
At end of the motion, add:
', but the Senate notes that any defeat of the measure would require the Commonwealth to forgo approximately $160m this financial year to the Australian oil producers, and-
This is the more important part of the motion-
condemns the Prime Minister for not honouring his election undertaking to commit any additional oil levy revenue to tax cuts and family allowances'.

The latter part of the second reading amendment that I have moved arises from commitments given by the Prime Minister in the heady atmosphere which preceded the 1980 election. The Prime Minister, with regard to this government policy of adjusting the price of Australian produced oil in accordance with movements in Saudi Arabian prices and exchange rates, said, amongst other things:

If there are any further significant increases (in petrol prices and tax from them) then the first priority of the Government will be to return that to the Australian family through the taxation mechanism or through family allowances. While we don't at the moment expect dramatic increases, the revenue will be returned to Australian families.

That statement was reported by, among other newspapers, the Australian of 16 October 1980 with strake headlines-I think that is the professional jargon-'OPEC increases will fund tax cuts'. Other headlines included 'Fraser pledges to give back petrol price rises as rebates or family allowances', 'Prime Minister says priority to return money to the people' and so on and so on. That, of course, is yet another example of the Fraserian disposable promise issued when there is a perceived electoral need for issuing a promise and disposed of as soon as that need passes. There has, of course, been no attempt by the Government to honour that promise. Indeed, the Bill before the Senate tonight implicitly repudiates that unqualified guarantee which the Prime Minister gave and which was so widely reported just a few days before the last Federal election. So although, as I said earlier, a responsible senator has no realistic option but to allow the Bill to pass, we would be remiss if we failed to move and carry some censure of the Prime Minister for his failure to honour his pre-election promises, a failure which is given legislative effect in the Bill before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will oppose the Excise Tariff (Petroleum) Amendment Bill 1982 to authorise crude oil levy increases because it is our clear duty to do so. It is our clear duty to the electorate to honour an undertaking we made to it that we would not allow Bills to pass here which were in breach of the Government's own promises made during the 1980 election campaign. This Bill is clearly and blatantly in that category. It is a matter of fact, as Senator Walsh said, that in October 1980, while addressing an election rally in Launceston, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made the following promise:

SPEECH.PARA: If there are significant increases in the price of oil, and therefore in the revenue from the levy, it will be returned to Australian families through taxation reductions or through family allowances.

There have been no increases in family allowances or reductions in tax to meet that promise and none is forecast by the Government. Therefore we must oppose this Bill to keep the Australian Democrats promise to the Australian people.

This Bill seeks to validate increases in the crude oil levy and hence in the cost of petrol at the pump to Australian motorists by 0.35c a litre as from 1 July 1981 and a further 0.8c a litre from 2 February 1982. Those increases have already taken well over $100m from the pockets of all Australians and will continue to take more millions of dollars with every week that passes. The Government has in the past tried to claim that there has not been a significant increase in revenue from the levy. That claim must be nailed as evasive and deceitful whenever it is raised. Beyond doubt the Government has the money. This is money which in terms of the Prime Minister's own promise at Launceston should be going back to the Australian people in the form of tax cuts or increased family allowances.

The Government has been canvassing a further red herring which it may well bring forward in this debate, although I doubt it would have the gall to do so. This is something at which Senator Walsh and the Australian Labor Party also connive. It is that if the money that has already been collected from motorists as a result of higher petrol prices imposed in July and February last is not levied by this Bill the additional funds estimated by the Australian Democrats of at least $136m and by the Australian Labor Party at $160m would remain as a sort of bonanza in the hands of the oil companies. This is complete nonsense. If indeed we have members of parliament who merely suggest to us and to the Australian people that a situation like that is beyond the collective wisdom of the Liberal Party, the National Country Party and the Labor Party, what do they think they are doing here? What are they doing here if they cannot do something about it? I will give Senator Walsh his answer. It is something that he knows perfectly well could be done if, indeed, he had taken this debate with any degree of sincerity.

There are many ways in which this money could be retrieved by Consolidated Revenue. Indeed, it could be done by a reduction of the crude oil levy through the introduction of a Bill very similar to this Bill or, indeed, by agreement for a sufficient period in which to return to the community those moneys which we think have been falsely derived in view of the promise of the Prime Minister. In other words, until that money was repaid, Australian motorists would pay substantially less for petrol, as indeed they should. The money should be returned to them in all honesty. When the money already collected had been repaid to Australian motorists because they would be paying less for petrol, they would continue to pay less because this deceitful Bill we are now considering would not have been passed by the Senate. That would have been an option open to the Australian Labor Party, and members of that party know that as well as I do.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they do not; it did not occur to them.
—That is a serious indictment of them, if that is the case.
—Senator Walsh said so.

—Did he? That is interesting. In order to ensure that the Bill was not passed in the Senate, of course, we would need the voting support of the Australian Labor Party and Senator Harradine. To our amazement the Australian Labor Party suddenly went to water over this matter. Earlier it was a different story. Somewhere along the line something happened to the Australian Labor Party which made it decide that it would present us only with an innocuous amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill-an amendment which achieves absolutely nothing. It says that in the opinion of the Senate certain things may happen. I think for the benefit of members of the broadcast audience at least I must say now that the Opposition's amendment means absolutely nothing. It does not mitigate or alter the Bill in any way. It does not really qualify the Australian Labor Party's support for the Bill.
—It is a light tap on the wrist.

—As Senator Chipp says, it is a light tap on the wrist. If the Australian Labor Party persists with its so far declared intention to vote for this Bill it will be supporting and conniving at a Government breach of an important election promise to the people of Australia. It also will be selling out disgracefully the very people the Australian Labor Party pretends to represent-the workers, the battlers, the ordinary people of this nation. I would like to quote from an editorial which appeared in the Canberra Times of 20 November 1981 in relation to this matter because it is very much to the point. I stress the date-20 November 1981. That was some time ago and this matter, of course, was at issue even then. The editorial refers to the Senate situation and then goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The next important battle is to be on the Government's intention to increase the oil levy (and so the price of petrol) from January. There is some justice on the Government's side in some of these imposts-but only if they are accompanied by an appropriate alleviation for lower-income families who are already paying a far higher proportion of their incomes in taxes than the rich, particularly the rich who are outside the clutches of the PAYE taxation system.
I say 'Hear, hear' to that. The editorial continues:
That, of course, is the argument the Democrats have been hammering, and rightly so. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, himself said earlier this year-
That is, earlier in 1981-
that any increase in indirect taxes would be matched with some reduction in direct taxation-but the Government has not made good his assurance.
Now, of course, six or seven months later, it still has not made good its assurance. The editorial goes on to say:

A year ago, in the last week of the election campaign, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, stated that future substantial rises in oil prices would create a top priority for tax cuts or increases in family allowances-and again the Government has not stood by his word.

Considerations of political advantage aside, Labor could agree wholeheartedly with the Democrats on the sales-tax issue, not because they oppose indirect taxes or more tax revenue, but because of the shabby treatment of the poor. Equally, Labor can easily agree on the oil levy, for those same reasons and also because it has a long-standing commitment to a more equitable and nationally beneficial source of revenue from oil, in its proposed resource-rent tax.
That, of course, is a fact. The editorial continues:

Resistance to the oil levy will gain wide support, even from committed conservationists, in view of the Government's disregard for its promise, and the additional burden it is putting on many who are already having a difficult time financially.

We agree with that. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party has decided to sell out the Australian worker and his family, who are not able to write off high petrol costs through tax deductions, as businessmen can. It has decided also, for its own mysterious reasons-which we would dearly like to know and on which we can only speculate at this stage-to condone the absolute and cynical breach of an important election promise by this Government. As I said in the Press release which was quoted in brief by Senator Walsh:

In the words of George Orwell's 'Animal Farm', 'It is now not possible to distinguish between the pigs and the men'. The Labor Party and the Government now seem united in their intent to perpetuate measures in which the Government has broken its word and in effect it is no longer possible to distinguish the Labor view from the Government one.

This is so not only in this matter but also, I might say, in others in which the Labor Party sees possibly a sense of victory in expediency and thinks that it will with expediency buy support which will assist it in the next election.

The Australian Democrats view with contempt the Labor Party's useless amendment to this Bill, which is a mere gush of hot air, and its subsequent failure to honour its commitments to the Australian people. It would seem that, although the Government has renounced its election promise to pass on crude oil levy increases to the people in the form of tax cuts or by increasing the family allowance and has failed to use the levy to guarantee motor spirit alternative research and development, better roads or any other useful purpose that that money could well have been spent on, ironically enough, it has the support of the Australian Labor Party. To put it briefly and to hammer the point well home- I think it is an important one that has to be made again and again-the Labor Party now supports a flat tax on all people using motor transport regardless of their ability to pay, a tax which bears most heavily of all on those people whom the Australian Labor Party pretends to represent and to protect.

I now turn to the Government's attitude in this matter. The Government has not a leg to stand on in this matter. It has had a significant revenue increase; it has not passed this on to the people as it promised. It, too, has used the levy as a flat tax on all Australians regardless of their ability to pay. It has not used the levy for much needed research and development of motor spirit substitutes, such as the conversion of methanol from natural gas, which is already being adopted by the New Zealand Government in its great Mauri natural gas field off the coast of the North Island at Taranaki. This process is possible. I raised in this place three years ago the fact that there was established technology at a cost, then, of $258m and a lead time of five years. We could have established two plants to get 10 per cent of our motor fuel from natural gas as a methanol additive to petrol. This works very well indeed with only minor modifications and adjustments to a car. It can be done by a mechanic in 20 minutes.

If something had been done about it then, if the Government had decided to use some of the crude oil levy-only a tiny fraction of it-for a useful purpose like that that would be of some future assistance to the Australian people those plants would have been coming on stream in about 18 months time. They would have been a permanent and valuable local source to meet the now rapidly falling production from the Bass Strait fields. The Government has failed the Australian people dismally in that regard. The cost of that methanol, on the best figures I can get, would have been less than the landed cost of Middle East crude. This is not an airy fairy, futuristic sort of thing; it uses well established, known technology. We have enormous quantities of natural gas. There is no reason in the world why we should not provide an important bolster to our motor spirit reserves by using it in that way. Indeed, it is quite possible, as has been the case in Brazil, for cars to be designed and built which will run completely on the fuel alcohols. Although there is at present in the world an apparent glut of motor spirit and fuel oil, that is not increasing by one litre the amount of oil in the world. The crunch will come, perhaps sooner than we think.

Of course, the Government may well bring forward its most respectable argument for the crude oil levy in this debate. That is the conservation argument, which the Australian Democrats respect very much, all other things being equal. I stress that-all other things being equal. We would like to see things such as methanol plants established, more fuel efficient cars encouraged and electric cars developed. Electric car technology is quite adequate for commuting in cities. There are no problems with that. Hybrid electric cars which use both petrol and electricity are being developed in a number of countries and they can be used on longer journeys as well as for city commuting. They function as an electric car for commuting in the city and can travel longer distances by the use of another engine. These things can be done in Australia. They are being done elsewhere. They are being done in Japan and in America. Of course, some work on this is going on against great odds in South Australia. We should look towards having more railways. Again, this is possibly an answer to our problem, as I will mention later. We should be improving our roads considerably.

All these things should have stemmed from the great opportunity given to Australia by the crude oil levy. But now the chance has been virtually lost. Every day that passes puts us further and further behind in an eventual race that we will lose if the Government goes on placing all its faith in the prospect that another major oil field may be discovered in Australia. The Australian Democrats would think that was marvellous. We would like to see it. But inquiries we have made so far indicate that the prospects are not good. Off- shore fields have a very minor oil slick on the surface that can be distinguished clearly from the computer enhanced pictures of the Landsat satellite. I have seen these pictures for the Bass Strait field. There is no indication from them of any other major off-shore fields in Australia. That is not to say that we may not find oil. Let us hope that we do. But for a government to pin all its faith on that is not only imprudent but also stupid. Even now if the Government used the levy properly much could be achieved. It could be of vital importance to the Australian people.

The Government could get to work now and see that some of the natural gas in this country is converted to methanol and that plants are commenced as soon as possible. The money is available in the crude oil levy dues. If the Government did that kind of thing, the Australian Democrats would probably take a different view of this whole situation. But we would still not forgive the Government for the breach of its election promise; that is our prime motivation. A few shots fired in Riyadh, the capital of Saudi Arabia, today, next week, next month or next year could put Australia in chaos. We would be without the means to run our motor vehicles. That is the hard truth. We are more dependent on motor spirit than any other developed Western country because of the vast distances on this continent and our relative lack of railways, canal systems or other waterways of commercial importance. The Australian Democrats have put this forward time and again in this place over the years. For three years we have been urging that action on the Government. What do we have? The Government says that it is a great idea and other pious platitudes and then says that it is looking at it. This Government is one that never does anything. It looks at things all the time , contemplates its image and problems and never does anything for the Australian people. We need only to look back over the last few years. We cannot see a single achievement. Not a single thought for the future has the Government given , especially in the vital area of energy. We indict the Government for that and we implore it at this stage not to place this country in further jeopardy by its criminal lack of activity in this regard.

Let us look at the truth of the conservation argument. I stress that the Democrats are very interested in the conservation of fuel. How well is it working out? The Australian Financial Review of 14 May, quite recently, states:
Petrol sales during the first seven months of the financial year were 2.4 per cent higher--
The word is higher--
than for the same period of the previous year.
Figures released yesterday by the Department of National Development and Energy show the increased petrol sales, but an overall fall in consumption of petroleum products of 1 per cent.
The products which recorded significant decreases were industrial and marine diesel fuel (down 25.4 per cent) . . .

Let us look at that a little more closely. I suggest that it is not something for which the Government can praise itself; rather it is another symptom of the chronic and desperate malady which the Government's economic policies have forced Australian industry to suffer. That 25.4 per cent drop in industrial and marine diesel fuel is due to that, not to any conservational effort on the part of the Government, which is purely incidental. The article refers to fuel oil being down 13.6 per cent, and much the same thing applies there. The next item listed is heating oil, which is down 17.6 per cent.

What has been the consequence of the Government bunging up the price and reducing the demand for heating oil? It increased the demand for electricity this winter in our large cities. That increased demand is largely causing blackouts and will cause further blackouts in New South Wales and Victoria. This ill-judged price increase at a time when our other energy resources need it is causing many people to give up oil heaters and to place their reliance suddenly on electric power, and the electric power resources are not adequate to meet the demand. That, I think, is a classic example of the Government's inability to plan or even to think clearly about the energy issues in this country to which it ought to be giving some thought.

The Australian Democrats consider that the crude oil levy and high petrol prices do not reduce demand but merely make things difficult for the ordinary people of Australia. This difficulty is not only that families have to pay more for fuel for the transport necessary to their daily lives. That is an important element that is badly affecting people who are not very well off. It is a serious matter. A young family-a man with a wife and a number of young children- has to use the car. Our society is organised that way. A wife cannot get to shopping centres and buy things unless she uses the car. Perhaps the Government feels she should trot several miles and carry bags home on foot. If that is the sort of life that the Government is planning for Australia, I think it ought to think more about that. Of course it is necessary for people to have that kind of transport. Everything has been done-the Government has connived at this and encouraged it in the past-to make a motor car orientated society, and people cannot evade that fact. Public transport systems in our society are not good enough to be an adequate replacement. But the extra fuel cost becomes more than that; it becomes a part of the extra costs of almost everything that families need and buy, and as a result it has been a powerful fuel to inflation in this country.

The Australian Democrats are opposing this Bill because we believe it is important that we should do so and that we should raise the issues about it which we think are so important and so basic. We think it is time the Government came clean with the Australian people about the crude oil levy. For years it has imposed this massive confidence trick on the people as an enormous flat tax. It has given lip service to energy replacement programs, motor spirit replacement and other things necessary to this country but it has done nothing effective about them. I must mention again the flipness of the arguments put forward by Senator Walsh for the Australian Labor Party. I am not blaming Senator Walsh; I know he is only doing what his masters have decreed and told him to say. Because the House of Representatives voted against it, the Labor Party in the Senate must also vote against it. The Labor Party in the Senate apparently does not have any rights of its own to think about what might be right and what might be wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you think we made the decision? We did not make it in isolation from the House of Representatives members.

—I would like very much to know how the Labor Party made the decision. I would like even more to know why it made the decision. I think the Australian people would like to know very much why it made that decision, too. I have certain ideas about it but I would like to hear what the Labor Party has to say.
—What are your ideas?

—What members of the Labor Party really want to hear is a call from me and from the Australian Democrats to them, and indeed to honourable senators of all political areas who have a shred of conscience or integrity, to vote with us in opposing this dishonest Bill. We will be dividing the Senate on it. The Labor Party will be seen by the people to be combining with the Government to pass through this place this blatant, dishonest Bill which the Labor Party knows full well is a breach of an election promise by the Prime Minister and which it knows is absolutely unjustified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my friend and colleague Senator Mason very strongly in his criticism of both the Government and the Australian Labor Party in their attitudes towards the Excise Tariff (Petroleum) Amendment Bill. This legislation validates two increases in the price of petrol paid by consumers because of the Government's policy of keeping Australian oil prices in line with those of Saudi Arabia. It is commonly known as world import parity policy, under a variety of names, but it is a policy that is generally accepted by the Australian people for two reasons. One of the reasons it is accepted is that motorists-as Senator Mason said, that includes all motorists whether they are workers, pensioners, young people or wealthy people-have seen the price of petrol escalate over the past several years. One reason given, among others, is because of the Government's world import parity pricing policy. The rationale of that is something with which the Australian Democrats do not disagree; at least they do not disagree in part.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government quite properly argues that unless oil companies are forced to sell oil or petrol in Australia at world parity prices or unless oil companies can be guaranteed prices at world parity for their product, what overseas company in its right mind would come to Australia to explore for more oil? Of course none of the companies would come. They would go elsewhere where they would know that, if they discovered oil, because of the very heavy expenditure in exploration they could get a higher price for their product. The logic behind that decision is unassailable and the Democrats do not disagree with it. We agree with world import parity as far as new oil is concerned.

The argument to impose world import parity pricing for old oil is not quite as clear. However, there is a rationale behind it. One of the theories is that it increases the price of petrol-a scarce commodity, a disappearing resource-and the higher the price the more of a deterrent that represents to the motorist meaning that less of this precious resource he or she will use. Therefore he or she will drive a motor car more carefully or more sparingly, substitute some other fuel for petrol or buy a smaller car. Again that logic is quite reasonable although the statistics of savings, because of this device, are not terribly impressive as I understand it. There have been some savings. I would not have thought that the curve down was too steep but it is a respectable argument.

However there is another argument that it would be almost impossible for the Department of the Treasury or the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to resist and that is that there is a windfall revenue to government every time the price of petrol goes up because of world import parity. Money quietly, secretly and painlessly is going into Government revenue every time a motorist pulls up his or her car at a service station to fill it with petrol. That is the significance of world import parity. In light of the Bill, which represents the most flagrant breaking of a promise by a government in my time in this place, one could well ask: What is going to happen if world import parity pricing comes down or brings the price of Australian petrol down? Clearly, it is based on world import parity or in line with the price of Saudi Arabian oil.

I would like the Minister at the table, Senator Chaney, whom I respect in these matters, to give the House a categoric statement of Government policy on this matter because to be fair there have been confusing statements from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), from Senator Sir John Carrick and from the Treasurer, Mr Howard, on this question. It is pertinent, in arguing a Bill such as this, to ask the Government Minister at the table whether, if world import parity prices for oil come down, Australian motorists can expect a reduction in the price they will pay for petrol at the bowser in the same way they have been told by the Government that they can anticipate an increase in the price of petrol if the world import parity price goes up.

However, I will return to the precise subject of the Bill. On 1 July 1981 the price of oil rose from $30.23 a barrel to $30.79 a barrel. In January this year the price rose from $30.79 a barrel to $32.25 a barrel. I apologise to listeners because figures like those are very boring and meaningless, but I want to have them on the record to show that there have been significant increases in the price of oil. The word 'significant' is one to which I will return in a moment. We intend to oppose this legislation because it legitimises the breaking of a categoric election promise. It passes my comprehension why members of the Labor Party-every jack one of them-will go over to that side of the chamber to vote with the Liberal and National Country parties to support the breaking of this promise by Mr Fraser and his Government. On the eve of the 1980 Federal election , the Prime Minister said at a rally in Launceston that any significant-that word again-increases in the oil levy would be returned to the taxpayer through income tax cuts or family allowance payments. I will repeat the Prime Minister's exact words. As I understand it, they were made on 15 October, three days before the last election. At that stage the gallup polls were still showing the Labor Pary in with a chance-a good chance. I think even Senator Button, a man modest in these matters, fancied himself as being a Minister within four days-a distinguished Minister he would have made, indeed. As one of the several, desperate last minute efforts to save the Government at the election the Prime Minister said:
If there are further significant increases--
There is the word 'significant' again-
then the first priority of the Government will be to return that to the Australian family through the taxation mechanism or through family allowances.

I ask people listening to the debate whether there is any explanation or translation of those words of the English language other than to assume that if there were significant increases in the price of petrol as a result of world import parity price increases those increases would be returned to the Australian family through the taxation mechanism or through family allowances. When I made a Press statement to the effect that we would hold the Government to that promise, that we would keep it honest, Mr Howard said:
The promise by the Prime Minister . . . last year to return all price increases to families through tax cuts or higher family allowances, was a once only offer, Mr Howard claimed yesterday.

Mr Howard was responding to a call from the Australian Democrats Leader, Senator Chipp, for the Government to honour Mr Fraser's 1980 pre-election promise or risk Senate rejection of the new price rise.

This was an article in the Sydney Morning Herald. It was written by Russell Barton, one of the most honourable journalists in the place, reporting accurately what Mr Howard said and what Mr Fraser had said beforehand. The article continued:

Speaking to reporters outside Parliament House yesterday, Mr Howard, said: 'I think I ought to say the comments the Prime Minister made before the last election were related to an increase due to occur in January this year, and they were not made to the generality of future (oil) levy increases.'
Mr Barton continued:
A check of Mr Fraser's comments on October 15 last year at a Launceston, Tasmania, public meeting do not show that he was limiting his remarks to the January 1980 increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sound surprised by the Prime Minister's change of mind, but you shouldn't be, should you?

—The surprise that I show at the overt change of mind of the Prime Minister pales into insignificance at the astonishment that I find at the Labor Party supporting him in this broken promise. That is not surprise; that is astonishment. That support has been indicated tonight by Senator Walsh who speaks in this place for Mr Keating. But the Labor Party will not go down without a fight. It says it will really make things uncomfortable for the Government because of its amendment. We sat on the edge of our seats while waiting for this amendment which will add the words: 'While not declining to give the Bill a second reading'; well now, there is something. The Labor Party will give the Bill a second reading. That means it will pass the Bill. That means when we call for a division, all Labor senators will go over to the other side of the chamber and sit with their beloved Liberal friends.
—It is spelt out in the amendment.

—The incongruity of Senator McLaren sitting next to Senator Crichton-Browne is something I look forward to with some relish. I do not know for whom I feel sorrier. While not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Opposition has moved to add the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but the Senate notes that any defeat of the measure would require the Commonwealth to forgo approximately $160 million this financial year to the Australian oil producers, and condemns the Prime Minister for not honouring his election undertaking--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp, I think it might assist the Senate if you directed your remarks through the Chair and ignored the interjections.

—There has not been one remark I have made which has not been directed through the Chair. But I say, with the greatest respect, that there has been a constant barrage of shouting on my right which you have chosen not to correct.
—Only because--
—Order! Senator Chipp has the floor.
—I continue with this wrist tapping Labor amendment.

—Senator Chipp, could I just clarify one point? I have a different amendment from the one that you are reading. I am just questioning whether in actual fact the amendment that you have is the amendment in the Senate to the Excise Tariff (Petroleum) Amendment Bill 1982.
—I believe so. It is word for word, as I see it. Did you have any particular reason-
—I understood that the words that you were reading were not the words that I have in the amendment on my table at the moment.
—The amendment continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and condemns the Prime Minister for not honouring his election undertaking to commit any additional oil levy revenue to tax cuts and family allowances.

This revenue now represents a significant amount of money each year. The Treasurer and other Government speakers have tried to write down the amount collected by saying that the Government cannot really return this amount in tax cuts or increased family allowances because of strikes in Bass Strait or because production is down. I believe that that is totally irrelevant. As far as the motorist, the worker, and the pensioner who drives a motor car are concerned, it is a significant increase to have to pay 1 1/2c to 2c more a litre every time they fill their petrol tank at a service station. That is where the rub is. Those are the people to whom the promise was made. The promise was not made to oil companies. In 1981-82 the total levy raised was $3.1 billion. So we are talking about a significant amount of money that is going into government revenue. As my colleague Senator Mason said this is a perfect example of a flat tax-one that hits everybody. It hits those people who cannot afford it. In 1980- 81 that $3.1 billion represented an amazing increase of 37 per cent on the previous year. In 1981-82 the oil levy was estimated to have raised $3.4 billion -$3,400m. If that does not affect people who are driving motor cars and who do not have the discretionary dollars that wealthy people have, I would like the Australian Labor Party to tell me what does.

I have been invited by several interjectors to say why the Australian Labor Party has gone cold on this. I believe the answer is simple. Every public opinion poll in the country says that the Australian Labor Party will be in government within 18 months, or less if there is to be a double dissolution. The dogs are barking it. Almost every Liberal to whom I speak concedes this. No doubt able, clever people such as Mr Keating-most people in this Parliament have a high regard for his ability-see an opportunity for $3.4 billion to come into the Treasury each year painlessly, without too many Acts of Parliament required to facilitate that sort of income. This is a golden goose. It is a fantastic way for a political party contemplating government to have $3,400m coming into its coffers each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a good government too.

—That matter is not under discussion. This, I think, is the key to why the Australian Labor Party had suddenly gone to water. The important aspect of this matter is that this tax affects everyone. It is impossible for low income earners to escape this tax. The person who is trapped in the pay-as-you- earn system is hit the hardest. The oil levy takes up 40 per cent of the price of petrol at the retail pump. I point out to anybody listening to the broadcast of this debate who intends to fill up his or her car tomorrow, that if the price of petrol is 36c a litre, 14c of that amount goes direct to the Government. Let us look at one of these price rises. The price rise in January this year demonstrates the effect on the consumer. The increase in the levy was $1.46 a barrel, which in turn represents a retail price increase of between 1c and 2c a litre. This means that the Government will reap an extra $100m this financial year between 1 January 1982 and 30 June 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has mounted an irrelevant defence to try to justify the breaking of its election promise. To say that there has been a revenue shortfall this year and thus no money is available to compensate for the hardship imposed on low income earners is nonsense. The levy has increased. People are paying more and the Government is getting more money than it would otherwise have got. Mr Howard has tried desperately to avoid this issue by saying that the Prime Minister's promise was a once only proposition applying only to January 1981. That is absurd. In no way can the Prime Minister's promise be construed to mean that. The Canberra Times, one of the nation's most objective newspapers, in an editorial on the oil levy pledge of 20 November 1981, used an apt phrase for the contortions of the Government over this issue. It said:
Oh, what a tangled web we weave when first we practise to deceive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was from Alexander Pope.
—Well done.
—Not Pope Alexander, Senator.

—I would have imagined that Senator Button would have got in just ahead of his colleague then, but it was an interesting photo finish. The facts of the issue are crystal clear. First, the oil levy has increased; secondly, the Government has raised more money since October 1980; and thirdly, it has not given it back in the form of tax cuts or an increased family allowance. The Australian Democrats will not vote for the legislation, this tap on the wrist amendment, until the Government lives up to its explicit promise. My friend, Senator Mason, has given the formula for how this could have been arranged. I conclude on this note. Senator Walsh-whatever I might think of him as a person; that is irrelevant- is a person who has a high intellectual capacity. Yet he demeaned his own high intellectual capacity tonight by saying that if we defeat this Bill the Government will be forced to give back $160m to the oil producers.
—He is dead right. That is what is happening. That is in our amendment. That is what you were going to give them- $160m.

—Senator McLaren has that deviousness of mind that could probably conjure up the situation of a Minister holding a formal presentation ceremony and saying, for example: 'I hereby present to you, Esso-BHP, this cheque of $ 160m on behalf of the taxpayers petrol users of this country'. That would be fantastic publicity guaranteed, according to Senator McLaren, to win the next election for the Liberal Party on a break. That would be fantastic. Can honourable senators think of the television cameras there? Can they think of the still photographers? Can they think of the Government Information Unit handing out Press releases that state, 'Here we are, a once only; we are giving back $ 160m to a multinational oil company'?
—That is how they do it-by stealth. You are a party to it. That is what happened in 1975. Don't let us forget that.

—I know that Senator McLaren does not always speak for the Labor Party. Those who are listening to the broadcast will recognise his melodious tones as he constantly interjects during my speech. He might think that that is a credible proposition, but if we-when I say we I mean the Labor Party, the Democrats and Senator Harradine-were to defeat this Bill tonight, does any member of this Senate really believe that within 12 to 18 months of an election a Liberal government would hand back a cheque for $160m to a multinational oil company?
—They don't hand it back; they don't collect it.

—I thank the honourable senator for that interjection. That is precisely what we are recommending. That is the way to get over it-to bring in a Bill identical to this so that for the next 12 to 18 months we do not collect that amount of excise or levy equal to $160m.
—Where is your Bill? Why haven't you introduced a Bill or an amendment to this Bill? Of course, you haven't. You have only just thought of it . You change your mind with the weather.

—I say now that the Democrats will bring in such a Bill tomorrow if I now get from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, who is sitting in the chamber, an indication that the Labor Party will unanimously support it. With your indulgence, Madam Acting Deputy President, I wait a second or two to get his acquiescence.
—I understand that you will not be here tomorrow afternoon and I doubt whether you would get it then.
—There is the answer. In conclusion, we express our disappointment at the Labor Party. We will oppose the Bill and the amendment moved by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not envisaged participating in this debate but, listening in my room to Senator Mason's sneering accusatory remarks about the Australian Labor Party, I felt compelled to come into the chamber. He said he thought he knew the reasons why the Labor Party would agree with the Government's proposal in relation to the Excise Tariff (Petroleum) Amendment Bill 1982, but he would not divulge them. He was leaving in the air the imputing of quite improper motives to the Labor Party. Let me say quite clearly--
—Are they improper?

—They are not improper. I say quite clearly that the only reason why the Labor Party finds itself compelled to support the Government on this matter is that it is not prepared to see $160m paid into the coffers of Esso-BHP , the Moonie oil producers-into the treasuries of private companies-rather than in those of the Treasury of Australia where it can be disposed of according to the vote of the elected representatives of the Australian people. The members of the Labor Party prefer to see this form of revenue that is paid by Australian motorists at the petrol pump every time they go to fill their tanks-whether it be for social motoring or for that necessary getting to and from work-going to the Government. As is now the case, the Australian motorists pay this money through the petrol pump attendants to the treasuries of the oil producers. We say that the Government ought to have available to it a mechanism to obtain its fair share of the revenue raised from the Australian motorist.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no use Senator Mason or Senator Chipp saying that the amendment moved by the Labor Party to the second reading motion is merely, I think he said, a wrist tapping measure. It condemns in the strongest possible terms the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) yet again to keep a promise which was essential, as Senator Chipp conceded and with which we all agree, to his electoral success; namely, the promise to make available any significant increases in oil revenue for the further sustenance of Australian families either by way of increased family allowances or tax relief measures. That has not occurred. The Labor Party unreservedly condemns the fraudulent misleading of the Australian public by the Prime Minister in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it reservedly condemns.

—It unreservedly condemns that failure of the Prime Minister to earmark the moneys raised by this revenue raising measure in the way in which he promised. It is a flagrant breach of promise by the Prime Minister. That is not denied by the Labor Party. In fact, it is insisted upon as one of the reasons for our utter condemnation of the moral depravity politically of this Government . But, as I say, to adopt the stand of the Australian Democrats is to assist materially Esso-BHP and the other oil producers. That is the specific impact of the stand taken by the Democrats tonight. If we were to agree to vote with the Democrats tonight we would be benefiting the oil producers and not the Australian Treasury. We would be filling the coffers of company treasuries rather than those of the nation. I am quite sure that if any honourable senator were to stand at the petrol pumps as motorists came to fill their motor vehicles , having to pay the prices which they have to pay and which are not easily acceptable to them, and ask those motorists whether they would prefer to fill the coffers of Esso-BHP or to fill the coffers of the Australian Government, they would unreservedly answer unanimously: 'We would prefer to fill the coffers of the Australian Parliament'.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few days-culminating tonight- we have had some very interesting insights into the vision held by the Democrats of the future for Australia. At Question Time today Senator Mason admitted to this chamber-the Senate, the States' House-that the Democrats have as their objective the abolition, the demolishing of the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Senator Tate persists in this point. I suggest it is not relevant to the matter being discussed.
—There is no point of order.

—I can very easily show that the action of the Democrats in resisting the passage of this Bill tonight gives an indication of the sort of future which they are envisaging for Australia. In that respect, to link it with some other insights we have had into their general strategy for Australia's future is merely to explain to the public who are listening and to those many dozens of people in the public gallery this evening the strategy of the Democrats in resisting the passage of this Bill. To that extent, Madam Acting Deputy President, if you will forbear for only two minutes, you will see the linkages which are only too apparent to me. The Democrats have said that they wish to abolish the States; they want to-

—I take a point of order. Madam Acting Deputy President, are you seriously ruling that Senator Tate will be permitted to discuss a question he asked Senator Mason this morning at Question Time about a private member's Bill on citizens' initiative that Senator Mason has before the chamber with a Bill on world import parity pricing. If you allow that, that is a decision with which you will have to live. I put it to you that you should seriously consider the point of order I have raised.

—I was not going to intervene on the point of order, but I think that was an unfortunate way in which the last contribution was phrased. I understood that the argument that was being put by Senator Tate was that statements made today on the matter of the abolition of the States and the attitudes expressed on this Bill were an indication of the sort of future for Australia that the Democrats were holding out. I submit that that is clearly a line of argument which can be developed in a debate such as this. I suggest that it is a line of argument that could be abused and that it is within the discretion of the Chair to watch that abuse. But I suggest to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that any ruling made by you either way is one that you will not find particularly difficult to live with.

—There are two elements in the point of order. The first is a suggestion that the Democrats might in some way have been misrepresented-an extraordinary allegation to make in this place! It is outrageous to suggest that anybody might be misrepresented! But there is a course provided by the Senate Standing Orders for dealing with misrepresentation.
—We have not said that.

—With the greatest respect, Senator Chipp's colleague Senator Mason, whose ire was aroused by the same point as aroused Senator Chipp, made precisely that point. If the claim is one of misrepresentation the appropriate course is to rise at the end of Senator Tate's speech or at the end of the debate and to claim misrepresentation. If the claim is one of relevance, I agree with the point made by the Minister. If we cannot advance arguments in this place which involve conceptualising the conjuction of two views, as Senator Tate was doing, again it would be an extraordinary debating chamber. There are to elements to the point of order. If the Clerk has been listening, I have no doubt he will agree with the view that has been put and the appropriate course which ought to be taken.

—I would like to speak briefly to the point of order. The point of order raised by myself and by Senator Chipp was on the grounds of irrelevance. I think the points that Senator Tate is making have no relevance whatsoever to the matter we are discussing.
—It is hurting.

—No, it is not hurting. Let us get the record straight. The Australian Democrats have not said, today or at another other time, that we would abolish the States. That is purely in Senator Tate's mind for his own purposes. Let me make that point quite clear at this stage. We would like to feel that we were able to continue this debate-a most interesting one-on whether the Labor Party and the Liberal Party are justified in passing this Bill to rip off this money unjustly from the Australian people. Any red herrings, I suggest, are irrelevant to that extent. I think Senator Tate's comment was the most blatantly irrelevant comment that I have ever heard made in this place. If it were allowed to pass I suggest to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that any area of Government or Labor Party policy-any one at all-could be introduced into any debate. That is what Senator Tate is doing. I am supporting Senator Chipp's call to you to declare Senator Tate out of order on the grounds of irrelevancy.

—Thank you for your participation in the debate. Let me just say to Senator Chipp that I do not respond to threats of the nature he made. I am quite sure that they were unintentional. But I would prefer that they are not made as a reflection on the Chair when points of order are raised. There is some relevancy to Standing Order 419. Might I draw Senator Tate's attention to that and ask that in his continuance of the debate he more closely align himself with the matter under discussion.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I am entirely in your hands as to the parameters within which I conduct myself during the second reading debate. I will, of course, observe any directions you may give me. I was trying to make the point that it is my belief that if this Bill is defeated, as the Democrats intend, $160m will remain or be available to the shareholders and employees of the oil producing companies for disposal according to their wishes. However, if the proposal put forward by the Government and supported by the Labor Party is carried the $160m will be available to the Commonwealth, to the Federal Treasury , for disposal according to the votes of the elected representatives of the Australian people. The point I was trying to make was that included amongst those objectives and matters to which the elected representatives of the Australian people can direct some or all of that $160m, is the sustenance of the States. In fact it may well be that the Prime Minister having breached his promise-we condemn him for it-to make those moneys available for the sustenance of families by way of family allowances or tax relief, having refused to earmark the money in the way he promised, this $160m will nevertheless be available for the vote of the elected representatives of the Australian people for various programs, whether they be programs of social expenditure under the control of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), or whether perhaps by way of general revenue grants to help the States discharge their programs of social expenditure and concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I was making the point that when one looks at the way in which the Democrats are inviting us to vote tonight and recalls the answer given during Question Time today, one can see very plainly that the Democrats certainly have no interest in any of that $160m being devoted to the States because it is the long term objective of the Democrats that the States be abolished and be replaced, as Senator Mason said at Question Time, by something he called French departments. I would suggest that if that proposition were ever put to the Australian people by the Democrats it would be utterly rejected with a resounding-to use a French word which the English speaking Hansard reporter may take up-non. We will not allow ourselves to be diverted into the French system of government by the Australian Democrats. I do not want to labour that point.

My point is that this Bill, if defeated, will leave $160m in the hands of the oil producers and that shows the sort of future that the Democrats are trying to create for us. That shows the masters they ultimately serve. The Democrats ultimately serve the interests of the oil producers-those who are manipulating and using our natural resources and our wonderful Australian talents for their profits. That is the aim of the Australian Democrats in the defeat of this legislation. For Senator Chipp to express astonishment that the Labor Party should take the view that these moneys should be available for the Australian people according to our vote rather than for the shareholders and employees of the oil producing companies, to my mind shows that he has understood nothing in Australia's political life since the inception of the Labor Party. Of course that is our bias and our preference and in that respect we support the Government.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I could go further into the vision of Australia that the Democrats have for us. However, in view of your ruling perhaps I should not do so. However, I feel that I should take up a quotation made by Alexander Pope about the tangled web we weave which, at least, is refreshing because only on Wednesday Senator Mason was quoting a Sir Barton Pope. Another element of the future that the Democrats want for us is to condemn the urban unemployed to digging water wells in the outback.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Senator Tate is at it again, I am afraid. He is right back into irrelevancy. He seems unable tonight to keep his mind on the subject. I suggest the he should be called to order on that point.

—There is no point of order. I understood that Senator Tate was quoting in the context that Senator Mason quoted earlier this week-from the same Mr Pope. In that regard, I was prepared to allow a further quotation. I call Senator Tate.

—I suppose I could conclude by quoting the Pope which would add immeasurably to the force of my arguments. No doubt they would have to do with questions of social justice. Unfortunately, I do not have a quotation immediately to hand. I will conclude my remarks and, Madam Acting Deputy President, with your indulgence I thank you for letting me stray, if I have at all, from the main parameters of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to confine my remarks to the amendment. In doing so, I want to congratulate Senator Tate for the very able manner in which he has exploded the arguments put forward by both Senator Mason and Senator Chipp. Senator Tate hit the nail right on the head with his remarks. That was quite obvious to people listening tonight by the way that both of those honourable senators took points of order and tried to silence him. Senator Mason claimed, in speaking to the amendment that was moved by Senator Walsh, that Senator Walsh moved the amendment at his master's direction. Nothing could be further from the truth. There are no masters in the Federal parliamentary Labor Party. Every decision is arrived at either by consensus or by a majority vote. Senator Walsh is a member of the Federal parliamentary Labor Party caucus resources committee of which I happen to be a member too. Senator Tate is the secretary of that committee. This Bill was discussed in minute detail by that committee. It made a decision in relation to the attitude we would adopt in framing this amendment. The amendment was moved in the other place by Mr Keating who was ridiculed here tonight by the two Australian Democrat senators. I think that at one stage they gave him credit for being a man of great ability. They will learn that in years to come when he is the Minister for Minerals and Energy in an incoming Labor Government. Further to the Caucus resources committee discussing this Bill and proposing this amendment, as is our policy in the Labor Party, the matter went to the full Caucus where it was debated and agreed to by a unanimous vote.

SPEECH.PARA: It ill becomes those two Australian Democrat senators who spoke tonight to accuse Senator Walsh of doing his master's bidding and carrying out a task in this chamber which he did not want to carry out. What Senator Walsh was doing in this chamber tonight was voicing the unanimous opinion of the Federal parliamentary Labor Party. I give him credit for that. Once the Labor Party makes a decision on any legislation which comes before this Parliament it does not change its mind every five minute which is what we find the Australian Democrats doing on many occasions. This has been quite evident at our Caucus meetings when we are discussing legislation. Messages have come in from the Australian Democrats which indicate what they will be doing in relation to particular legislation. We in the Australian Labor Party have a discussion as to whether we will support the position of the Australian Democrats. We find that within five minutes another note is passed under the door which indicates that the Australian Democrats have changed their minds. This has happened on as many as four occasions in relation to one particular matter being discussed by Caucus . That is the way in which the Australian Democrats operate. The amendment moved by Senator Walsh on behalf of the Opposition stated:

At end of motion, add ', but the Senate notes that any defeat of the measure would require the Commonwealth to forgo approximately $160 million this financial year to the Australian oil producers, and condemns the Prime Minister for not honouring his election undertaking to commit any additional oil levy revenue to tax cuts and family allowances'.

What could be more clear than that? How could it be more clearly explained than it was by Senator Tate just a few moments ago? Senator Tate pointed out what the Democrats would achieve if we were to join with them and oppose this legislation ; we would be giving to the oil companies on a plate an amount of $160m. Of course, Senator Chipp tried to circumvent the whole debate by bringing forward a specious argument and saying how nice it would look on television if we saw the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in front of the cameras presenting a cheque for $160m to the oil companies. Nothing like that was said. It is only a figment of Senator Chipp's imagination.

If this legislation were defeated tonight the oil companies would be let off the hook for approximately $160m. The Labor Party has been consistent since the promises made by the Prime Minister (Mr Fraser)-the amendment spells out his promise to do certain things-in arguing for a reduction in income tax. If we were to join with the Democrats to defeat this Bill tonight we could imagine what the Government would say tomorrow. It would say that the Labor Party was not consistent in its argument for a reduction in income tax because it prevented the Government from raising $160m which it might use-I emphasise the word 'might'-to reduce income tax. I do not think the Government will reduce income tax. But it would use that argument against the Labor Party. Members of the Labor Party are not fools. We sit down and deliberate on all the legislation which comes before this Parliament. We do not make up our minds one minute about what we will do and, because we get some pressures from outside-as apparently the Democrats do-then change our minds and try to run with the hare and hunt with the hound. We do not do that. We have a policy and we are proud to stick by it.

The Democrats might be fooling some of the people who are listening in tonight by getting up here, as Senator Mason and Senator Chipp have done, and saying: ' Family allowances will not be increased and taxation will not be reduced because the Labor Party is going to support this Bill'. We are quite convinced that we are doing the right thing on this occasion. Senator Chipp then went on to say that he would introduce a Bill tomorrow to do certain things. But, of course, he did not stop to think before he made the statement. The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) quickly reminded him that he would not be here to introduce the Bill. Of course, if he is not here to introduce the Bill it will not be passed because the Democrats will not have the numbers. Quite obviously, Senator Chipp does not have the Bill printed and ready to introduce. Otherwise, he would have sought leave of the Senate today to introduce the Bill tomorrow. Of course, that is just a red herring thrown across the trail. It is a throw-away.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. It is not. It's a serious suggestion.

—Well, we look forward to seeing the Bill come on tomorrow. As I said by way of interjection, when we see the contents of that Bill the Labor Party will have a look at it. We will not give the Democrats carte blanche on anything that they say they will introduce. We do not trust the Australian Democrats any more than we trust the Fraser Government. The Democrats make all the promises in the world and on most occasions they do not deliver. I think Senator Tate, as I said, explained this matter fully. I do not need to go any further into this. I have said to the Australian Democrats that what Senator Walsh has done tonight is in conformity with the majority decision of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party. We stick by it for the reasons which we have set out in the amendment which Senator Walsh has moved on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not understand the contribution by Senator McLaren to the debate on the Excise Tariff (Petroleum) Amendment Bill 1982. The only thing that has emerged from his contribution is that at least there is one honourable senator in this chamber who does not have a guernsey for the new Ministry in the forthcoming Australian Labor Party government as is being stated by the Opposition. That person is Senator Walsh. Apparently there is some good news after all.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the Excise Tariff (Petroleum) Amendment Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921, to enact excise tariff alterations made by Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 of 1981 and No. 1 of 1982. These measures in effect validate increases in the oil levy. It is necessary to understand the procedure so that one can then determine whether one votes for the proposition or whether one votes against it. The oil levy is imposed and increased by excise tariff Acts. These Acts, of course, impose taxation and are therefore not subject to alteration or amendment by the Senate. Before any increase in the levy comes into effect, an excise tariff proposal is presented to the House of Representatives. This proposal may be debated. Under the provisions of the Excise Act, the collection of the levy cannot be called into question within one year of the commencement of the increase in the levy. Before the period of one year has elapsed after the commencement of the increase in the levy, an excise tariff Bill, such as we are discussing here tonight, to validate the collection of the levy is introduced. If such a Bill is not passed within the period of one year after the commencement of the increase in the levy, the levy would have been illegally collected.

That is the situation with which we are faced tonight. Faced with this situation, it has been put by the Opposition that, if we do not adopt this legislation this evening or tomorrow before we rise for the winter recess, the levy will have been illegally collected. The Opposition states that legally the money collected would have to be handed back to the oil producers. A question has arisen as to how this would be done. Quite obviously, the oil producers would not let it lie there. They are quite competent in getting their hands on money and there are ways and means of doing this, including court action. I see no reason to support the abandonment of this legislation. That would open the way for the oil producers to get their hands on money that is now in the hands of the Treasury and which could be used for disbursements at the will of the elected representatives of the people.

I have a great deal of sympathy for much of what Senator Mason had to say in leading for the Australian Democrats on this matter. He and others have referred to the promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in Launceston two days before the 1980 general election. Let me remind the Senate that I am very well aware of the atmosphere in which this election promise was given in Launceston, in Tasmania. Of course, the atmosphere in that State had been engendered with an expectation that something would be promised by the Government for families. Indeed, 22,000 electors in Tasmania signed a petition seeking increases in family allowances and increased support for the family. The Prime Minister was very well aware of that. He was also aware of a continuing campaign on the mainland which coincided with the collection of those signatures . Immediately after the election I was one of the first to start belting the Government over the head with that election promise. But never did I tie what ought to be done with the family allowance or taxation to what might be in the barrel or in the pool of increased oil levies because to do so would be to tread a path in history which had been found to be wanting.

I remind the Senate of the fact that the old child endowment scheme was in fact tied to payroll tax. This system was used in New South Wales when it had its own child endowment scheme. When the Commonwealth Government introduced the child endowment scheme in 1941 it was linked to payroll tax. The Commonwealth scheme involved two-thirds of the cost of the scheme being borne by employers. However, in 1945 constitutional problems were overcome by making child endowment a charge upon the national welfare fund, which in turn was credited with the payroll tax receipts. The nexus existed between 1941 and 1952 but the rate of increase in child endowment for that period was very slow. For example, the rate was 5s to 7s 6d a week in 1945, 7s 6d to 10s a week in 1948 and 5s a week for the first child in 1950. Furthermore, in the period while the nexus existed the desired two-thirds from the employers exceeded that figure in five of the seven years. For example, in 1948-49 receipts from employers represented 81.4 per cent of the total child endowment payments.

I thought I should mention that point to the Senate as a matter of historical record. That is the reason I deliberately eschewed adopting a policy of tying increases in family allowance payments or decreases in taxes to whatever happens to come out of the barrel. The problem which we face here tonight is this: Do we allow the validation of the increases in the oil levy or do we deny the Treasury that amount of money that it has already collected? My view is that we should adopt the proposition put forward by the Opposition, which condemns the Government for not passing on the increases as promised but enables the Senate to do what it did last week; that is, to adopt the stance that we ought to restore the family allowance to its 1976 value and to index it.

If we tie such increases to increased oil levies there will not be sufficient money in the extra oil levy to make the increases. Tying our policy of increasing the family allowance or reducing taxes to whatever comes out of the oil levy will not in fact satisfy the requirement of the motion I moved last week in the Senate, which was adopted by a majority of the Senate; that is that the family allowance should be restored to its 1976 value and that it should be indexed. That would require and should obtain not only increases in the oil levy but also extra money, as a matter of justice. In my view it is not a wise move to tie a matter of right to what might happen to be in a particular pool which might be affected from time to time by weather, industrial problems and prices of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

I support the amendment moved by the Opposition and ask the Senate to do the same. I clearly understand the situation of the Australian Democrats. I hope that they also understand my position on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly. I wish to raise only one salient point. If the Excise Tariff (Petroleum) Amendment Bill 1982 is passed by the Senate tonight it will validate an increase of 1.15c a litre in the price of petrol. That is not a small amount of money. It represents conservatively $1m a week in revenue to the Government. This Bill validates an increase in a tax on the Australian motorist of $1m a week. We say that the Government is doing this in blatant disregard of an election promise that any increase in the oil price levy would be returned to the people. Clearly the Government has not done that. We have record taxes, there is no suggestion of lowering taxes, and the money is not going back to the people. Therefore, we say that this validating legislation should not be passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate, for whom I have the utmost admiration, raised a complete irrelevancy when he said that $1m a week will be returned to the oil companies- this is essentially what he was saying-if this legislation is not passed by the Senate. It is hot air; I can think of no other expression. There are many simple ways that the Government has open to it to ensure that that money does not finish up in the hands of the oil companies. Senator Tate raised an irrelevancy. The essential point before us tonight is whether we are going to allow the Government to take from the Australian motorist an additional $1m a week in blatant disregard of an election promise. That is the issue, and the only issue, before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to my feet almost in disbelief as the protraction of the debate has been so considerable.
