I have listened with great interest to an extremely discursive debate on a Bill which, I understand, has the support of the majority of honourable senators, although the qualified support of the members of the official Opposition. There has been an air of unreality floating over part of the debate. I think that unreality is best typified by referring to a sentence from Senator Siddons. He put the proposition that money is being collected by the oil levy but is not going back to the people. I would like to know whom it is going to. The fact of the matter is that this Government is still raising less in taxation than it is spending. The Government is still in deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: My Department, which is the largest spending department of state, will this year spend more than $10 billion not of its money but of the taxpayers' money. That will be drawn from the amalgam of taxes, be they indirect taxes such as the oil levy, and from the considerable income taxes which are imposed on the Australian people. All of that money is dispersed by the government to the Australian people. There may be differences between us about the emphasis of some of that spending. Some honourable senators opposite would tell us that we should be spending more. It is totally unreal to suggest that the oil revenue money is going elsewhere than to the Australian people. A large proportion of our expenditure goes to the people via the States. A large proportion goes directly in the form of pensions, benefits and so on. Of course, it is absurd to suggest that any of the money raised by government is other than money expended for the Australian people.

I cannot comment in detail-I do not think the Senate would want me to comment in full detail-on all the speeches made by honourable senators on the subject. I must touch on some. I thank Senator Harradine, for example, for what was a very accurate, or very close to accurate, explanation of how this whole system works. I will not repeat that. He recently put it before us. He explained why this Bill is needed and the techniques that followed. I have to say his speech was a little churlish. For example, he thought Senator McLaren said nothing. I thought there were three significant revelations in Senator McLaren's speech. For example, Senator McLaren confessed that he is a member of the Australian Labor Party, which is something some of us have never been quite sure about. He also explained the working of the Caucus system. Some of us have not understood that when honourable senators opposite go into that Caucus room they all come out singing the same song. I am always pleased to note that the public is being enlightened on these mysteries about the Labor Party.

Senator McLaren also most amazingly expressed the view that members of the Australian Labor Party are not fools. Mr Deputy President, I was pleased to hear that as I am sure you are too. I hope a significant minority of the Australian people will accept Senator McLaren as being truthful on that score. On the other hand, I thought Senator McLaren fell into a hole. He suggested that if the Australian Labor Party did not defend this Bill the Opposition would be accused of not being consistent. I suggest that consistency has not been a curse that has afflicted the Labor Party particularly in these matters. The Australian Labor Party has cheerfully knocked off some indirect taxes in conjunction with the Australian Democrats. It has cheerfully reduced the revenue raising capacity of the Government through indirect taxes; it cheerfully advocates that we should reduce income taxes and it cheerfully advocates that we should increase expenditure. It makes no mention of the level of the deficit or the effect of this on interest rates. I do not regard consistency as a particular malady in this chamber or a particular virtue embraced by many.

I would like to mention other matters raised in the debate. Senator Chipp addressed a serious inquiry. I will say something else about Senator Chipp's speech in a moment but he addressed a serious request to me and demanded an answer. He asked: 'What if the price drops?' I am not the Minister for National Development and Energy but I can quote a statement of the Minister which I think covers the point quite satisfactorily. In the Senate Hansard of 11 March 1982 Senator Sir John Carrick is reported as saying:

I have said repeatedly that we have an import parity pricing device, that we are geared to the benchmark price of Saudi Arabian light market crude and that our practice has been on 1 July and 1 January to look at what has happened to that benchmark and to make adjustments in terms of the price and the exchange rate. That in fact has been the pattern, and we have in the past moved downwards as well as upwards. That remains our policy.
On 22 March the Treasurer (Mr Howard) issued a statement which was in similar terms. In fact it referred to that statement by Senator Sir John Carrick. The statement finished with the sentence:
That in fact has been the pattern, and the Australian price has in the past moved downwards as well as upwards.

I quote those statements as reflecting the attitude of senior Government Ministers to policy in this area. I thought the most revealing part of this debate came in the remarks of Senator Chipp. I like to think of Senator Chipp really as the emperor of the Australian Democrats. He stood in his place, pointed the accusing finger and said to the Australian Labor Party: 'I know why you are supporting this. You think you might be in government'. I think that was a very interesting statement, not so much about the Australian Labor Party, which indeed might think it might be in government; but about the Australian Democrats, who know they never will be. It reflects a freedom to adopt positions which are unreal.

I think that as the emperor lifted his finger and accused the Australian Labor Party his toga fell off and he stood before us exposed. The feature of the Democrats' position on this Bill and in particular the speech of Senator Mason was their unreality-the total lack of concern about where the money would come from, the usual freedom to say that we should spend on things and the lack of concern about where the money would be raised. Quite frankly, I am glad that we have had this debate, long as it has been, because I do not believe that we can consistently expect the Australian people to tolerate a situation in which a political party so happily embraces every easy option and yet holds itself out seriously as a candidate for office. I think that the debate has exposed a very weak position on the part of the Democrats and for that reason I welcome their contribution.

I noted the concern that Senator Chipp expressed about import parity pricing. I would have thought that there was the broadest acceptance in the Australian community that that was a policy which had served this country well. I am surprised that Senator Chipp is unaware of the effects that that policy has contributed to the usage of petroleum products. It is a well known fact that the usage of petroleum products for fixed applications has dropped very sharply. The available competitive fuels are such that there has been a very significant decline of the use of the heavier oil products. That is a very significant plus for Australia and it is something which I think we can attribute in part to the import parity pricing policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage?
—The percentages are in the 20 per cent and 30 per cent range. They are very significant.
—What, petrol has diminished 20 per cent?

—No, I am talking about heavy oils. I thought I made it clear. If people listen with their mouths and not with their ears, one gets a very poor standard of debate. I think all honourable senators who were listening would concede that I was talking about the usages of petroleum products in their fixed applications-heavy oil products and things at that end of the spectrum. I was not talking about petrol. I think honourable senators opposite would confirm what I was talking about. Petrol has gone from a situation in which usage has been annually increasing to a situation in which it has stabilised or declined. There have been very valuable contributions to what is, I understand, a generally accepted goal of reducing our reliance upon petroleum products. That is one aspect of it.
—Has the usage of petrol decreased?
—One per cent.

—I am trying to speak plainly, using the language that I understand we all use in this place. I said that the use of petrol products has either stabilised or, in some cases, declined slightly. I think the sort of percentage figures which are raised by interjection are correct, but that is as against the situation which applied in earlier years where there was a consistent increase year by year in the use of those products. So there has been a significant impact. I thought it was interesting that Senator Chipp conceded that, with respect to new oil, there were good reasons for adopting a policy of world pricing. One reason was that it would attract exploration. There were various reasons why he said he supported it. I would ask the Democrats to ponder upon the extraordinarily complex marketing situation one would have to have if one were trying to impose a situation where Australian producers were expected to sell old oil at some reduced, artificially held down, rate while they were permitted to sell new oil at a world rate. My advisers suggest that it is possible. My reaction was that it would be impossible. But it would certainly require a most complex system of regulation to achieve that result.

SPEECH.PARA: If one could not achieve that result, if in fact we were permitting part of our oil, our imports and our new oil to be sold at the world price, there would be huge market pressures for the producers to be able to sell all oil at that price . If we did away with the policy we have of collecting that additional price by excise we would be giving all that new money to the oil producers instead of to the Australian people who, at the moment, get it through that tax system. I do not as part of this debate make any apology for what I think has been one of the premier successes of this Government, that is, its oil parity pricing policy. I believe that Senator Sir John Carrick has served this country well in his promotion of this policy and gaining the wide acceptance for it which has been gained.

I really suggest that the opposition to this Bill and the terms in which it has been expressed have been insufficiently thought through and have represented an easy and potentially popular option for those who have sought to embrace it. A serious question has been raised as to whether there has been a breach of faith in the measure which is before us and in the fact that certain statements were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) in Launceston in October 1980. There have been slight differences between the quotations which have been read tonight and the quotations which are available to me because all of us are relying upon transcripts or media reports. The media report which I have in front of me is illustrative of the point that I basically would want to make about what was said in October 1980. The report is from the Herald in Melbourne and is headed: 'PM: Tax cut if oil jumps'. It reads as follows:

The Federal Government would return any oil levy revenue from big rises in petrol prices next year to taxpayers through tax cuts or increased family allowances, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, said today.
'If there is significant increase in revenue from the levy, this will be returned to Australian families through taxation reductions or family allowances ', he said.
Then there are quotes from Mr Hayden who said it was all blah. The report goes on:

Mr Fraser, speaking in Launceston said: 'The price rises that would be likely from January 1 following the recent OPEC rises would be less than 1 cent a litre , so the additional revenue for that is pretty minimal'.
His contemporaneous description, according to the Herald is: 'That is pretty minimal'. The report continues:
'But if there were significantly greater increases in the OPEC price we will act as we did last year . . .
'When the Treasurer, John Howard, announced we would give priority to personal tax cuts if there were additional oil revenues, and that is what we did.'

Since that time there has been controversy about what was meant. I think during the debate statements made both by Mr Howard and by the Prime Minister have been quoted. I have a transcript from an interview dated 11 November 1981 where Mr Howard said:

I think I ought to say that the comments the Prime Minister made before the last election were related to an increase that was due to occur in January of this year and was not a statement made as to the generality of future levy increases.
To my mind that is quite consistent with what is reported in the Herald in October 1980. In November 1981, at about the same time, the Prime Minister said:

'The remarks that John Howard and I were using were directed specifically at the allegations at the time that there would be very significant increases in January of this particular year-the January that has passed.'

One can argue about the words used, the semantics and so on. The Government has been on the record now for a considerable period as saying that it was referring to the very real figures which were around in 1980, that there would be continuing, rapid escalation of oil prices on the international sphere. It is history that that has not occurred. Oil prices have substantially stabilised and the price rises to which we have been subjected over the last year and a half are in no way in the same order as the price rises to which we were subjected in previous years. But let us look anyway at the record. Supposing we accepted the argument of the Australian Democrats, which is supported by the Australian Labor Party in its opposition, that there has been a promise which indicates that the Commonwealth should be delivering on tax cuts and the family allowance? Let us look at the position since October 1980. Since that time there has been half indexation of tax rate scale at a cost of $495m to June 1982. In other words, we had another step towards half indexation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another promise.

—I have said previously that I like people who listen with their mouths and not their ears because it means that they do not bother to try to understand what is being said. The point which I am trying to make is that there have been tax reductions since that promise was made. I simply wish to list those reductions. There has been half tax indexation, which has represented a saving of $495m to June 1982. Last year we announced that there would be a rebate for health insurance at an annual cost of $600m each year. Those announcements have been made. There have been tax reductions which of course are very much in excess of any benefit from the additional oil revenue. The family allowance changes represent a cost to revenue of $60m. The Australian Democrats have said that there have been no changes to the family allowance. Of course there were adjustments to the family allowance in the last Budget which cost $ 60m in the current financial year. The full year cost will be $120m. Two lots of tax cuts and one family allowance adjustment can be pointed to since October 1980. The estimate of additional revenue, given to me by my advisers and which is accounted for by increases in the rate of levy since October 1980 is $318m. So if we were in the equity lawyer's business of trying to say exactly what was meant and were asking whether there had been increases in the oil levy, tax cuts and increases in family allowances, I would say to honourable senators that the balance sheet is in favour of the Government. There have been substantially greater tax reductions and payments of family allowances in total than there have been increases accruing to the Government from the crude oil levy because of increases in rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Needless to say, the Government rejects the amendment which was moved by Senator Walsh and it asks the Senate to support this legislation. I believe that any fair thinking Australian looking at the operation of oil parity pricing in this country would say that it has been a benign policy for this country; it has served us well. This annual step in regularising the arrangement which has been in place for so many years is a step which such fair thinking Australians would expect us to take, I think, with a little less fuss and bother than has in fact been displayed.
Question put.
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Walsh's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (The Deputy President-Sentor The Hon. Douglas McClelland)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (The Deputy President-Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill seeks to extend for three years a subsidy of $12 a tonne on phosphatic fertilisers-that is, $12 on phosphorous pentoxide-and $20 a tonne on nitrogenous fertilisers with the nitrogen expressed as n. The Bill originally introduced into the House of Representatives was a Bill to pay a bounty to Australian producers. But, as amended in the House of Representatives, the Bill now seeks to pay a subsidy-that is, a payment which will be available to domestic producers and to importers of fertiliser. The significance of that change will become apparent later in my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: This whole question of fertiliser subsidies and bounties, especially the superphosphate bounty, has been a sacred cow in Australian agriculture for some time. It has preoccupied the thoughts of many people associated with agriculture and, unfortunately, diverted their attention from more constructive thinking. It is apparent that the Government, recognising the sacred cow status of this measure, is not willing to terminate it but is quite happy to let inflation erode its value. The rate of subsidy for phosphatic fertiliser has not been changed since 1969 and therefore two-thirds of its value has been eroded. The rate of subsidy for nitrogenous fertiliser has been progressively reduced over the same period, even in money terms, from $80 to $20 and therefore its real value now stands at one-twelfth of what it was in 1969. So, regardless of all the rhetoric we heard from particularly the National Country Party in the mid- 1970s, it is quite clear that the Government is happy to see the real value and significance of both of these subsidies or bounties eroded by inflation.

The Deputy Leader of the National Country Party, Mr Sinclair, recently lamented what he claimed to be a deficiency with the Australian communications system- that is, that the Government did not get the opportunity properly to explain its policies. I invite Mr Sinclair or any other member of the Government to explain why the Government has proceeded with this measure. According to evidence given before an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry by the Department of Agriculture of Western Australia, which is the heaviest fertiliser using State, the Department of Agriculture of Victoria and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, consumption of phosphatic fertiliser, which is the main measure we are talking about, will not be affected by price changes within a limit of about $20 a tonne above or below its existing level.

In economists' jargon, consumption is totally price inelastic, according to the submissions put forward by these bodies. If that is so, and I leave aside the very limited possible income effect on consumption, this measure will have no effect on the consumption of phosphatic fertiliser. Therefore, inevitably it will have no effect on resource allocation or efficiency. Its effect will be simply to transfer income from taxpayers to overwhelmingly the largest and highest income farmers. The question I put to the Government, and I invite Mr Sinclair or anyone else to explain, is whether the Government rejects that technical and economic assessment by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and by two State departments of agriculture which was not contradicted by any other public body. If the Government does not rejects that assessment, will it explain why it supports the type of income transfer which I have outlined? There is no alternative. Either the Government is rejecting the technical economic assessment of those bodies or it is proposing to the Parliament that it should pass a measure, the only effect of which is to transfer about $50m from taxpayers to farmers far more than proportionately to the highest income farmers .

The measure also demonstrates another serious inconsistency carried to the point of absurdity in the Government's policies even within the agricultural sector. Whilst it is willing to transfer $50m for such fragile reasons as have been advanced, it has refused-it has jacked up on, I might say-requests from the wheat industry to match a higher contribution from grain growers for industry research. The grain growers have offered to lift the levy which they themselves now pay in the expectation that that levy will be matched, as it has been in the past, dollar for dollar from public revenue. The Government has resisted the wheat growers attempts to increase both their levy and the matching government contributions in order to make more funds available for grain industry research. Whilst it is impossible to prove, there would be little dispute in informed quarters that increased expenditure on research in the grain industry would be likely to yield high dividends. On the evidence available there is no reason to believe that the $50m expended in these fertiliser bounties would yield any dividends at all. The increase involved for the Government for wheat research is about $1m.

The difference between a bounty, which these measures have traditionally paid, and a subsidy is this: A subsidy affects prices paid by consumers for both domestic production and imports whereas a bounty paid to local producers affects only the prices paid for local production. In other words, a bounty affects the relative prices of both imports and local production. It has the potential, since it affects the relative prices of imports and domestic production, to be a protective device. The degree to which it would be a protective device is limited, first by the relative smallness of the proposed bounty or subsidy and, secondly, because imports and local production are not directly substitutable for a variety of both cost and technical reasons. The present bounty is now being used to some extent as a protective device, but that has not always been the case. It becomes, to some extent, a protective device when market prices for domestic production are above market prices for imports. That is the situation that prevails now. World prices, however, are notoriously unstable.

I have a table which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has agreed may be incorporated in Hansard. Perhaps I should add that the price of fertiliser in different parts of Australia varies to some extent and therefore these figures will not be accurate in all circumstances. The degree to which they deviate from complete accuracy will not be significant. This table shows that the free on board cost of imports of a triple superphosphate in 1975 was $ 214 a tonne and the price of the local production was $134 a tonne. The f.o.b. price of single superphosphate was $118 a tonne and the price of local production was $56 a tonne-less than half. I might add that a single superphosphate is unlikely to be imported in significant quantities. On the other hand in 1982 to the f.o.b. price of triple superphosphate of about $135 a tonne should be added a freight handling charge of about $28 a tonne giving a total price somewhat in excess of $160 a tonne landed in Australia as against a price of $253 a tonne for domestic production. In other words, domestic production is some 50 per cent above import parity price right now. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows more comprehensively than I have done orally that over the long term Australian prices have been competitive with import prices-in both cases unsubsidised market prices. This industry should not be regarded as analgous to the textiles, clothing and footwear industry or the motor vehicle industry which have required over the long term very high levels of protection to remain competitive with imports. I apologise for not having a comparable table available for nitrogenous or compound fertilisers, that is, fertilisers which include more than one active constituent. The price variations which are shown in that phosphatic fertiliser table are shown to a substantial degree in the prices for nitrogenous and compound fertilisers.

SPEECH.PARA: If domestic production and imports were perfect substitutes, which they are not , at a time when imports are cheaper-given that Australian is a residual market, changes in the quantity imported into Australia would not have a significant effect on world prices-then the local industry would close down completely. If that should happen, when import prices subsequently increase, Australian farmers would then pay the higher world prices. Over the last 20 years, if that situation had applied, if Australian farmers had been paying world prices, they would have paid on average about the same as they have, in fact, paid. There may be some merit in the argument that over the long term Australian market prices, even without bounty or subsidy, have been below import parity prices. Even if that is equal it could still be rationally argued that there is some justification for devices which maintain Australia's productive capacity because prices which are stable but equal on average are to be preferred to prices which are equal but unstable.

Of course, a situation of perfect substitution does not apply. Even if it did, there would still be some validity in protecting in some form the local industry , even possibly from the farmers viewpoint because of the relative stability of prices which the local industry can maintain and because protection of an industry through a period of depressed world prices maintains its capacity to supply the domestic market for that period. If history is any guide-there are other reasons for believing this-that period will recur when world prices are substantially above domestic prices.

That is the position from the farmers' viewpoint. From a general viewpoint, even if at all times the industry fully utilised the potential for protection provided by a bounty of this magnitude, the level of protection would still be light by standards of Australian manufacturing industries. In the case of phosphatic fertilisers it would be of the order of 10 per cent and for nitrogenous fertilisers of the order of 5 per cent. Apart from the effect on the mainland based manufacturers, any significant decline in Australian fertiliser manufacture would have serious implications for the mining operation on Christmas Island, an Australian territory mined by a publicly owned company. If that operation were to close down, there is no serious doubt that at some time in the future the phosphate ore which is available there-at least 8 million tonnes of it-would again be price competitive. But if it were closed down now, it would be very much more expensive to re-open the mining operation and to get a population back on the island at the time when the ore became price competitive.

It is correct that there may be better protective devices other than a bounty- such as anti-dumping duties-to provide whatever degree of protection is decided may be justified for domestic industry. But some people might say that this Government could not be trusted to act promptly or sensibly if that tool were relied upon. I turn to the lobbying in the debate over the last couple of weeks on this issue. It is a long time since so much humbug and ignorance have been displayed by people who have been lobbying members of the Senate. This has come especially from the lobbyists who have been presenting or misrepresenting the case for a bounty, particularly on behalf of local manufacturers. I will say more about that later.

On the other side, the National Farmers Federation claims to be presenting a pure economic rationalist line. This raises the question: At what point does it start to be rational? The NFF starts being rational after the decision to interfere in fertiliser prices has been made and then says that those funds should always go to consumers by way of a subsidy instead of the possibility of their being distributed between consumer and producers by way of a bounty. The NFF has presented very few valid arguments to support that assertion. But it has effectively demolished much of the nonsense which has been presented by the other side. The NFF completely ignores the rationality of the original decision to interfere in market prices. It applies pure economic rationality at a point which is convenient to the case which it chooses to present whereas if pure economic rationality were applied at one stage further back, such questions as I posed earlier would have to be answered. Is the technical advice of the two departments responsible for agriculture and the BAE rejected by the Government? If that technical advice is not rejected by the Government and is accepted as correct, this proposed subsidy will transfer $50m from taxpayers to farmers, and mostly high income farmers. So we are out of the area of pure economic rationality and into the area of value judgments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you would do that only if you were applying the same pure economic rationality to other fields, would you not? If you want to take a pure economic rationalist approach you would want to do that across the board and not merely with respect to this--

—The point is that according to the technical evidence price changes of the magnitude which this Bill makes possible will have no effect on consumption and, therefore, no effect on resource allocation other than a limited income effect which I do not have time to explain. In other words, economic rationality is a selective tool. The true economic rationalist, however -I think this is the point Senator Chaney was trying to make by way of interjection earlier-especially given that certain realities already exist, might say that there is a case for protecting local manufacturers, whereas the case for transferring $50m from taxpayers disproportionately to higher income farmers, apart from moving out of the realm of economic rationality into the area of value judgment is, I suggest, weak to non-existent on either ground. In other words, the case for the bounty, on grounds of economic rationality or on income distribution, provided one leans towards progressive income distribution, is stronger than the case for the original price intervention.

SPEECH.PARA: We will therefore move amendments in the Committee stage the effect of which will be to restore the Bill to what it was when first introduced in the House of Representatives and analogous to those which have preceded it. An additional reason-I do not make too much of this point- for favouring a bounty over a subsidy is that it is administratively simpler. In case it is argued that the present generally depressed level of farm incomes is a case for paying a subsidy , I think it should be said that it would be difficult to conceive-it is a fact that farm incomes are low at the moment-a more inefficient means of coping with a farm welfare problem than the payment of a subsidy on this or, probably, any other input.

The NFF case presented to me and, I think, to all other senators, made valid criticisms of the case presented for the fertiliser manufacturers and particularly of the case presented on behalf of the fertiliser manufacturers by Eric White Associates Pty Ltd. Indeed it would be hard not to make valid criticisms of that case. The submission from Whites incorporates so much sloppy thinking and ignorance that it insults the intelligence of the honourable senators to whom it was addressed-regrettably an insult perhaps justified to some degree by previous senatorial decisions. Whites say that a subsidy-I use that word advisedly in the context in which it is used here as distinct from a bounty-would transfer money from Australian taxpayers to foreign producers of fertilisers and destroy the local industry. If, as Whites suggest, the subsidy were completely appropriated by foreigners, it would have no effect on the relative prices of imports and domestic production. It would therefore have no effect on the relative market shares or on the output of the Australian industry .

In other words, we cannot have it both ways. It is possible, although I suggest highly unlikely, that the subsidy would be appropriated by foreign manufacturers . But if it is to be appropriated by foreign manufacturers it will not have any effect on the output of the local industry. Of course, under any circumstances it is absurd to suggest that price differentials-even of the present quite considerable level-would destroy the local industry in the way that Eric White's submission suggests because products in the domestic industry imports are not perfectly substitutable, for a variety of technical and economical reasons which again I do not have time to explain. It is true that the degree to which a subsidy is not appropriated by foreign suppliers will affect relative prices and will cause some shift towards imports and, therefore, some reduction in the output of local industry and ultimately of its capacity to produce. That would be in the short term good for farmers or other consumers. For the reasons stated , in the long term it would be highly questionable whether phasing out of any part of the local industry's productive capacity would be good for farmers. The White submission hit a nadir of credibility on page 20 when under the emotive heading 'Australia could become Subject to Foreign Cartels' it asserted:
. . . devaluation of the Australian dollar, has made imports of fertilizers from the United States more competitive . . .

The truth, of course, is the reverse. It is sad that gullible clients have paid good money to lobbyists to produce such palpable nonsense. Apparently some people believe that if the amendments to change the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1982 back to a bounty Bill, as distinct from a subsidy Bill, are not carried local suppliers would be better off if the third reading motion were defeated-in other words, if the legislation lapsed entirely. They are mistaken. If the third reading is defeated local suppliers will face world prices just as they would if the Bill is carried in the form in which the Government has presented it, albeit prices to consumers would be at slightly higher levels than if the Bill in its present form is carried. The competitive position of the Australian manufacturer vis-a-vis the foreign supplier will be identical if the Bill is defeated or if it is carried in the form in which the Government has introduced it to the Senate.

There is one more fallacy that I need to demolish and which I have just got time to deal with. Some people believe that if the amendments are carried, and given that the House of Representatives is not sitting, no bounty would be paid after the end of June. In a sense that is correct because under the existing legislation, which authorises the payment of the bounty, no bounty or subsidy would be payable after the end of June. It is partially correct then that the existing legislation does expire at the end of June but the situation can be remedied if the Government wishes. All that would be required if the Senate accepts the amendments which I will move-it looks as though it will be tomorrow and not today-is a simple statement from the Government that it will accept the amendments carried by the Senate when the House of Representatives next sits in August and that the bounty will be paid retrospectively from 1 July this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Fertilizers ( Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1982 which will extend the bounty on phosphate nitrogenous fertilisers from 30 June this year to 30 June 1985. It will also extend the subsidy to imported fertilisers at the same rate as the subsidy on the local product. However, in supporting this legislation I should not like to be cast in the role of an advocate of protectionism but rather as a pragmatist who recognises that this is a short term solution to a problem which will eventually require much more drastic measures. In 1979-80 the Industries Assistance Commission noted that the respective values of the phosphate nitrogenous fertiliser bounties were $51m and $7m or a total of $58m in that year. It is worth noting that in the previous two financial years the values of the same subsidies were $56m and $55m respectively. In other words, while we are considering whether to extend the life of these two bounties or subsidies-as they now should properly be termed-with the inclusion of imported fertilisers it should be remembered that the real value of these subsidies has been decreased in real terms to a rate approximating the level of inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1968-69, when the price of bulk superphosphate was $26.62 a tonne, the superphosphate bounty was paid at $7.87 a tonne, or about 30 per cent of the value of the product. In 1980-81, when the price of superphosphate was $97.30 a tonne, the level of assistance was only $12 a tonne, or about 12 per cent of the value of the product. Over the same period the value of the bounty on nitrogenous fertilisers diminished even more dramatically, from 30 per cent to approximately 6 per cent from the beginning of the period to the end of that period. Again, over the same period the value of exports from the primary sector rose from $1.9 billion to approximately $8.5 billion in current dollar terms. Indeed, in 1979-80 the revenue from primary exports was only $134m less than the combined export value of the manufacturing and mining sectors. Primary industry exports accounted for something like 46 per cent of the total export revenue of Australia.

While we are measuring the contribution of the primary sector to Australian exports I hardly need to remind honourable senators that it was only 25 years ago that the primary industry sector was contributing in excess of 85 per cent of all our export earnings. Having said that, I do not suggest that the fertiliser subsidies which are the subject of this debate are simply some sort of repayment of a debt of gratitude or appreciation by the taxpayers for the contribution that the primary sector has made in the past. Frankly, under the present economic circumstances the subsidy is a form of assistance which is vital to the agricultural community. The important factor to consider is the proportion of overall costs which the cost of fertiliser represents to the farmer. According to the Western Australian Department of Agriculture, on all Australian farms fertiliser accounted for, on average, between 7 and 9 per cent of overall costs between 1972-73 and 1977-78. For all Australian vegetable producers the cost of fertiliser fell in the range of, on average, between 8 and 12 per cent of overall costs; for cereal producers the average cost represented 12 per cent and for dairy farmers it represented between 6 and 12 per cent of the overall costs.

In my State of Western Australia the situation is even more significant. In Western Australia the use of fertiliser for each hectare is the highest in Australia. Moreover, is it worth noting at this point that virtually all the fertiliser is used in the south-west land division of Western Australia. This is an area in which almost all the wheat of Western Australia is grown. The area accounts for 99.8 per cent of all dairy cattle, 51.8 per cent of cattle for meat production and 93.3 per cent of sheep in Western Australia. The use of fertiliser in the south-west land division follows some very interesting trends but the most important is the gradual substitution of superphosphate for crops. Between 38 and 48 per cent of superphosphate was used for crops in the period 1973 and 1979, while between 66 and 86 per cent of other artificial fertilisers were used for cereal production. That trend is a reflection of rural economics, where transport and labour costs encourage the most efficient use of resources in applying fertiliser.

TALK.START.PARA: —By 'crops' did you mean pasture?

—No, I meant crops as distinct from pasture. Perhaps that trend is not strictly relevant to the issue of a phosphate and nitrogenous fertilisers subsidy because honourable senators will be aware that the subsidy is paid on the contained phosphorous or contained nitrogen as designated by the manufacturers' specifications, but I believe it reflects a general rural concern about the rising costs of fertilisers and their application. Over the period from 1970-71 to the present, fertiliser costs represent the second fastest growing farm cost input, second only to fuel prices and then only marginally. As a cost factor, fertiliser prices have risen about 410 per cent since 1970-71. This is only a few percentage points less than fuel prices, while over the same period wages have increased by something like 235 per cent. That is why it is so important to Western Australian farmers to have this bounty in the present economic climate.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the soil types found in Western Australia it has been necessary to use a disproportionately high amount of fertiliser to maintain crop yields. Overall, 30 per cent of Australia's fertiliser is used and consumed in Western Australia, but Western Australia has only 9 per cent of Australia's farms in terms of numbers as distinct from acreages and they account for 16 per cent of the total value of agricultural production. If we examine further the fertiliser intensive agriculture production in Western Australia, we find that 29 per cent of Western Australia's crop land consumes 31 per cent of the fertiliser used for crops to produce only 15 per cent of Australia's crop output on a value basis. Similarly, Western Australia has 27 per cent of Australia's pasture land and uses 30 per cent of the fertiliser applied to pastures in Australia, but, on a value basis, produces only 13 per cent of the livestock production.

That is a reflection of the natural infertility of Western Australian soils compared with those of other parts of Australia and it is indicative of the special soil husbandry which must be practised in my State of Western Australia. In other words, in my view it is a compelling argument in support of the retention of the phosphorous and nitrogenous fertiliser subsidies in the present circumstances. But I do stress the point that the subsidy is necessary in the present circumstances only. Those circumstances, of course, relate very often to the very high artificial costs imposed upon the agricultural producers by tariff levels and quotas granted in favour of certain favoured and often inefficient secondary industries in Australia.

If I may return briefly to the point at which I commenced, the real value of this subsidy is diminishing as the costs of fertilisers rise. If the underlying rationale of this legislation is to assist the agricultural producers in this country-I presume that is the reason for this legislation-as an historic trend it should be noted that the value of that assistance is diminishing under the twin pressures of inflation and the static level of the subsidy itself. A simple answer to the dilemma would be to increase the level of the subsidy. But if the level of the assistance were to be increased once again to 30 per cent of the price of the product, the cost to the Australian taxpayer of the superphosphate subsidy would be in the order of $130m and the nitrogenous fertiliser subsidy would account for a further $35m, based on the 1979-80 costs of these subsidies.

In Australia today there are just so many people who are so quick and keen to fall back on governments for assistance. I would not for a moment suggest that that is the course that ought ultimately to be taken to resolve this question. I am sure that is not the solution that the average farmer in this community would seek. It is within the power and capacity of this Government to take a very positive step to alleviate the problems faced by farmers and, for that matter, other producers and other service industries in Australia. I shall quote from a booklet entitled Farm Focus: The 80s which was produced last year by the National Farmers Federation. It states, quite intelligently and quite properly:

There is an urgent need to achieve a significant reduction in the costs from tariffs on farm inputs. In a situation where farmers are largely unable to pass on these costs but must absorb them, major distortions and inequities are introduced.

On chemical herbicides and pesticides, for example, there is an import tariff of up to 30 per cent plus support duties in some cases. The tariff for tyres for cars and light trucks ranges up to 25 per cent; for harvesting and haymaking machinery, 15 per cent; for fencing and insulators, 37.5 per cent; for working boots and overalls in excess of 40 per cent and 50 per cent respectively; and for rotary and cultivating machinery, 15 per cent. Completely built up motor vehicles attract a 57.5 per cent general tariff. With other forms of assistance, the effective rate of protection has been estimated at closer to 90 per cent. The protection on motor vehicles and such other items as footwear and clothing is obviously excessive, but there are certainly further inequities which also do not bear up to closer examination.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to detain the Senate very long. I wish to raise two matters. I was hoping that the Leader of the Government (Senator Sir John Carrick) might have been here but the remarks which I wish to make I suppose really should be directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) and the Federal Minister for Health (Mr Carlton). The first matter to which I wish to refer reads a little like a comic opera. It is a short story which relates how some people have used others. In this case it happens to be the Premier of Queensland and a gentleman who, in order to protect his identity, shall be called the Batman. In the second case to which I wish to refer a document has been issued by the Queensland Minister for Health in which he points out certain quite erroneous things about high toxicity weed killers.

SPEECH.PARA: Some months ago during the Christmas-New Year period there were a number of disputes in Queensland which led to the abandonment of maintenance work by some members of the Electrical Trades Union of Australia. By technical manipulative actions a partly trained electrical apprentice, known for the purposes of this exercise as the Batman, was able to restore power in some areas. I wish to make two major points. The first is that a partly qualified person should not be handling this sort of thing at all. The second point is that the Premier of a State-even if it is a rather backward State politically, as Queensland is-should not be enticing people who are partly trained in this area to scab, which is the normal word used in the trade union area, and to endanger people's lives further . I know that there are certain offences in relation to tape recordings of telephone conversations. But in this case it appears that both people concerned were involved in taping each other's conversations. I understand that many copies of the transcription of one of those tapes are now circulating. The transcript is 99 per cent accurate. I do not know who transcribed the tape and made the transcript available; nevertheless it is available. John Walsh, a member of the Premier's staff in Queensland, apparently was the go-between for the young fellow known as the Batman and the leading man of the State. The transcript commences with the young apprentice saying:
Well, put it this way . . . you know I just feel the unions were doing the wrong thing at the Christmas time. You could have agreed by the way I put it forward to the Courier-Mail.
It goes on:
PREMIER: That was splendid, Batman, I, truly will. Sometime you have got to come in and say hello . . . and have perhaps a cup of tea with me or something.
BATMAN: Well, I would like to but . . . you know, I have got to look to the future. Where do I stand as far as you know a lot of people in SEQEB--
That is, the South-East Queensland Electricity Board-
I made enemies with by doing.
PREMIER: Oh, well I know that Batman, but don't you ever worry. We'll, you know , don't you ever worry. You, we need people like you, pity there weren't more a few more like you Batman.
PREMIER: . . . will you keep in touch?
BATMAN: I definitely will because I think in the near future around about the mid-May, end of May the unions are going to step up their campaign . . .
PREMIER: What's the reason for it?
BATMAN: 35 hour week.
BATMAN: The usual procedure, more money or something they're never happy in their job now.
PREMIER: No.
BATMAN: . . . a lot of them you know on fairly good conditions.
PREMIER: Yeh, yeh, yeh.
BATMAN: And you know give them more and they will want more . . .
This transcript reads very much like a comic opera. But one has to read in these statements in order to ensure that the matter is taken in its proper context. The transcript continues:
BATMAN: . . . I make a lot of trips out Roma-

Roma has a power station which feeds into a local grid. According to what I have heard from the tape recordings of both of these people it is unlikely that that power station will be interfered with. The transcript continues:
PREMIER: No I didn't.
BATMAN: No, well I've been studying the operation of the power station there and how to operate, now every power station has their own set way
PREMIER: Yeh.
BATMAN: But basically
PREMIER: Could you keep that-
BATMAN: The synchronising procedure is the same.
PREMIER: Is it really, could you, Batman, could you organise a few fellows to, that would be hard to do wouldn't it, that could step in to do-
BATMAN: I've been trying.
PREMIER: Gee, good on ya.
BATMAN: Now I am trying uphill . . .
PREMIER: My goodness me . . . I'll, I'll make sure you go up the ladder well quick smart if you can do that.

In other words, we have a leading personage in the community, a political figure , convincing a half-trained third year apprentice that he should go in and take over power stations. Crossed lines, et cetera, could have burnt out 100 houses in a suburb. The lad himself could have been killed, and yet we hear somebody who holds a responsible position persuading him to continue to do it. The transcript continues:

PREMIER: Now you'll go up the ladder I'll promise you that, if you can get some fellows that can operate the powerhouse, you can do the one at Roma or any of them . . . well Batman if you can, if you can get some of our, - operate some of our powerhouses or get a few fellows together that could . . . gee, you could do that . . . then I--
It was a very disjointed conversation but it was correctly transcribed. The conversation goes on:
BATMAN: It's teamwork effort but ah, where do I go for security I know one bloke's our stumbling block, Keith Zuch in the Q.E.G.B.
That is, the Queensland Electricity Generating Board. The response was:
PREMIER: Who's that?
BATMAN: Keith Zuch, Tennyson system control centre.
Tennyson is one of the very big centres. The transcript continues:

BATMAN: Now if I went into Swanbank for example and tried to start it, got a few people on the coal gang to get the conveyors going 'yes' managed to get a couple of sets synchronised and operating 'yes' he could very easily at the control centre drop us off. That's our only problem.
In other words, they could be dropped out of the grid. The transcript goes on:
PREMIER: And when you say drop off?
BATMAN: Well he'd switch us out of the grid so all the power that we generate wouldn't do any good. That's the only problem we've got.
PREMIER: And how can you overcome that?
BATMAN: That's a bit of a difficulty. Have someone at Tennyson system control making sure he doesn't isolate Swanbank

PREMIER: Now . . . is, is that something that we could do by having somebody there or . . . some supervision yes. It can be done. You know a lot of people . . . could for example could say the State Electricity Commissioner be there if he knew you were going to do the rest?

It is positively dishonest to have the chief of the electricity organisation in Queensland standing by to make sure that that station is not dropped out of the grid while a couple of scabs operate it. The transcript continues further:
BATMAN: Yes.
PREMIER: Could he be there and make sure that he didn't do it?
BATMAN: Well that is possible, I would, you know I wouldn't like to attempt to run the power station on my own that would be ridiculous.
PREMIER: Yeh . . . well, Batman, you do your best MMMMMmmm and see what you can put together to have ready for an emergency will you?
Batman is getting rather cautious by this time, which the transcript indicates as follows:
BATMAN: Tell us one thing. What protection do I have, ah police wise if the union try to get at me?
PREMIER: They give you all the police protection you want.
Apparently following this the line was left open and the following passage was recorded:
BATMAN: Um, you little beauty, you little beauty. I've been talking to Joh, he says if you can organise to run the power stations, you'll go up the ladder- right up the ladder. You little ripper!

I think this is a case in which the Federal Minister ought to be prepared at least to have some sort of inquiry because if this sort of thing can go on in Queensland it can go on anywhere. We have one of the most responsible people in Australia, certainly in Queensland, persuading a half-trained electrician not only to scab, but also to go in under police protection and run some of the major power stations. That sort of thing should not happen.

I refer briefly to my second point. In Queensland, a leaflet is put out by the State Minister for Health listing a number of herbicides. I have spoken on this subject many times in this chamber. The danger guide is worded as follows:

All pesticides are dangerous when swallowed in the concentrate form. However, in the following list, the pesticides in more common use have been graded according to toxicity when used under normal conditions of spraying and mixing.

Then there is listed as having nil toxicity the hormone weed killers 2,4-D and 2 ,4,5-T the brand names of which are Tordon, Five-T, et cetera. It goes on to list a number of others, many of which are almost as dangerous. I think the Premier of Victoria set the pace for trying to overcome the possible problems, and sometimes the parent and positive problems, that are associated with the use of these herbicides. The herbicide 2,4,5-T, with dioxin, is the very basis on which agent orange and some of the other herbicides used in Vietnam were compounded.

I ask that the Minister refer these two matters to the relevant Ministers. In particular, I hope that Mr Macphee will look at the encouragement given to a half trained electrician in Queensland. I have not used his name because I know the company he works for and he will certainly be sacked if this matter comes to the attention of his employer. I think it is unfair that a youngster should be put in this situation by the first citizen of the State. I hope that the matter will be handled with tact and that this sort of practice will cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two matters in the Senate chamber, one by way of mea culpa and the other by way of protest. In regard to the confessional aspect of my remarks tonight--
—Wait until Sunday morning.

—It used to be Saturday night. When the Senate was discussing the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources entitled 'The Development of the Bauxite, Alumina and Aluminium Industries' on 25 February I stated, in the context of explaining the position, why the Committee was totally opposed to the use by Western Australian conservation interests of overseas courts. I was nevertheless explaining what had led to their frustration with the procedures available to put their concerns in a constructive way before major resource projects were undertaken. I stated that we had had some evidence from the Commonwealth Department of Home Affairs and Environment arising out of its assessment reports of proposed bauxite and alumina projects in Western Australia and that in many cases the project developers, whilst full of good intentions, were really at such an early stage of their proposals at the time of seeking the concurrence of the Commonwealth or State departments of environment in their projected development that they could do no more than express pious hopes that their projects would not have a detrimental environmental impact. In fact, some of their strategies for overcoming certain adverse environmental impacts would not be fully tested and one could not be absolutely confident about their utility. In my remarks I said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Darling Ranges there is grave doubt-I certainly have grave doubts after hearing some of the evidence, particularly from the proposals of the Worsley joint venturers-about the impact of the bauxite mining in those ranges on the salinity of Perth's water supply. Those projects are going ahead without those fears being allayed and without the full and complete scientific studies having been completed.

Since I made those remarks it has been drawn to my attention that the Worsley alumina project is being conducted in an area of the Darling Ranges which is not a catchment area for the Perth water supply. I have taken out of the library a booklet entitled 'Forest Focus', published in Western Australia, that shows the various catchment areas on the western seaboard of Australia. As I say, it is quite clear that the Worsley joint venturers' projected operations would be outside the metropolitan catchment area in the northern jarrah forest area. To that extent I wish to correct any impression in the minds of honourable senators , and particularly fellow Committee members, that I do believe that the Worsley joint venturers are in their operations imperilling Perth's water supply by contributing to the salinity of the waters in the catchment area of that water supply.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very responsible attitude.

—I thank Senator Thomas. I still regard it as an extremely important point that bauxite mining in the Darling Range may have severe detrimental impacts on the biological systems. Whether it is the water salinity or the reafforestation of the jarrah areas, of course, it would have to be looked at project by project and area by area. I simply want to put that matter on record.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matters I wish to raise by way of protest are to do with what I believe is an ignoring of senators by authorities around this Parliament in the making of decisions which are of vital concern to senators and which have quite an impact on the environment within which they have to work, either presently or in the future. Firstly, I wish to raise the question of the design of the Senate chamber, or at least the procedures which allow ordinary senators to make some contribution to the final design plans for the Senate chamber in the new Parliament House. On 11 March of this year I raised with, I think, the Deputy President, who was in the chair during the adjournment debate the fact that late in the Budget session last year senators and members were invited to view proposals for the interior of the new Parliament House. I think they were in a room near the private dining room. We were invited to make our suggestions known to the officers in attendance. I certainly went over, and I made the comment to the officers there that the viewing galleries of the new Senate chamber, to my mind, have the same defects as the present ones, that is, they are too high and remote from the floor and the viewing angles are such that much of the chamber is obscured from the view of those people who come into the chamber to view our work in this place.

In a sense I would not mind if there were any evidence that that suggestion had been seriously considered, had been looked at and had been taken into account. I have not to this date had a reply to the point I raised on 11 March and we are one day short of rising for the winter recess. I want a reply. I have had some informal discussions in the corridors with officers of the Senate, but nothing more than that. I have had no evidence that any suggestion made by a member or senator at that time was recorded and taken into account by any authority responsible for the design and construction of the interior of the chambers of the new Parliament House. What I am concerned about is that we were given a snow job-it was just another public relations exercise-and that senators who have to work in this environment and who are concerned about public understanding of our work have been ignored. If my suggestion has no merit, that is one thing. But my objection is that there is no evidence that we were taken seriously at all at any stage. It will be no answer to me to find out that my view was taken into account two or three weeks ago, for example. I want to know what happened to the suggestions made by members and senators at that stage last year when we were invited to make suggestions.

The second matter along the same line by way of protest is that one of the best innovations made in the Library in recent times has been the setting aside during sitting times in the session of the carrels for work at the rear of the Library. It is most conducive to quiet work away from one's office and telephone and the general harassments of people knocking on one's door-including attendants full of good intentions-which are most disruptive. The fact is that a letter we all received early this week dated 20 May 1982 from the Speaker and President advises us that, there being only eight carrels anyway at the back of the Library for the use of senators and members during the session, two of them are to be removed over the winter recess and the space made available for a junior Australian political scientist taking up the fellowship which is offered in this place. I have no objection to some accommodation being found for this person. Indeed, a committee of this Parliament has made some suggestions as to how accommodation could be found in this place if only a certain department were not so obdurate-apparently successfully obdurate-in its occupancy of its premises.

What I am saying is that the decision to remove two of the carrels at the rear of the Library is a wrong decision on at least two grounds. First, I believe the decision to reduce the number of carrels to six is shortsighted and unduly restrictive of future methods of work of senators and members. I use the carrels , I suppose, daily. I could name, but I will not, two or three senators who certainly use them constantly and three or four members who constantly use them. I do not believe the assessment claimed to have been made that only four carrels are in use at any one time. Even if that were true on average I believe that space has to be made available for more or less maximum use. The fact is that quite often one urgently requires 10 minutes or a quarter of an hour in a quiet space to prepare work for a contribution to either this chamber or a committee. It is quite impossible to do that, as I say, in one's office. It may be, of course, that any new intake of senators or members after the next election will include people whose work preparation habits, whose study habits, are quite different; they may find those areas extremely conducive to their work. In that case the average of four carrels which is claimed at present may be unduly restrictive of the way in which senators and members wish to work in the future.

Further, when was this survey undertaken? It could well have been undertaken in a week, for example, when many members or senators did not have their research assistant with them in Canberra. If one has one's research assistant with one in Canberra one can leave that assistant in the room to guard the phone, to receive the messages, to open the mail and to keep abreast of the paper work. One does not need to be in one's room; one can go back to the rear of the Library and work on one's own. As I say, a misleading impression could have been given to the Speaker and the President, and apparently the Library Committee, about the use of these carrels. It is a bad decision not only from that point of view. What I really object to-and this ties in with my previous objection concerning the design of the Senate chamber-is the fact that senators have not been consulted. I can see Senator Janine Haines is nodding in agreement with my concern about this matter. Senators have not been consulted concerning their wants in this regard or--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you have confidence in your representatives?
—I do not-not in this matter. I think they have made a grave error.
—Have you seen the model of the proposed plan of the new chamber?

—I am not talking about that; Senator Evans is about 10 minutes behind my contribution. Senators have not been consulted about this matter nor has this information been circulated in time for discussion by members of the House of Representatives. The letter is dated 20 May 1982. Members of the House of Representatives have left this place and they have no opportunity to make their views known as to the propriety or the worthiness of this proposal. If that is not contemptuous of the members of this Parliament it is certainly totally indifferent to what might be their views and their requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask that you convey to the Speaker and the President the dismay which I feel and which I know from conversations is shared by other honourable senators in respect of this proposal. I say that the fellow can make as much unimpeded use of that area as he or she wishes over the winter recess-for some 10 weeks-because senators and members do not have the privilege of exclusive use of the area during this period. Let that 10 weeks be used to find alternative accommodation. As I say, I believe that accommodation can be and maybe ought to be found, but certainly not at the expense of the need of senators and members at the moment, and certainly not in a way which will unduly restrict the possible use of that area by senators and members in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring before the Senate tonight the case of a woman suffering from childhood-onset diabetes, a problem which, I understand, is faced by a considerable section of the Australian population. This woman wrote recently to South Australian State politicians and Federal politicians of all political parties. She outlined the drastic but apparently quite common predicament that many diabetics suffering from this particular form of diabetes face. She wrote, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Although my plea is for diabetics generally, it is more specifically for the sufferers of childhood onset diabetes. These people can be treated only with daily (sometimes multiple) injections of insulin all their lives. The long-term complication of this type of diabetes is vascular disease affecting the eyes, kidneys, heart, limbs and circulation, and inevitably causing neurological disorders. Each condition is sufficiently distressing in itself, but when grouped together, the resultant distress is enormous. Technology has advanced a great deal to help the diabetic cope with these problems, with home monitoring of blood glucose, blood pressure and possibly renal dialysis.
She goes on to point out that that technology has a price. She cites her own case as an example of the expenses with which this sort of diabetic can become involved. She goes on to say:

I recently purchased (on my doctor's advice) a blood glucose home-monitoring machine at a cost of $230. The strips needed to work the machine are $3.20 per prescription of 25. I must use the machine four times daily to get the most benefit from it and this means a prescription every 6-7 days, at a total cost of $16 per month. The needles needed to obtain the blood become blunt very quickly with this continuous use and have to be purchased every couple of weeks at $3.20 for 10. So, the purchase and maintenance of this one item is excessively expensive. Combined with the costs of five prescribed drugs ($3.20 each), insulin (two types-$3.20 each), swabs and syringes (injections 2-3 times daily), urine testing strips (2 types-$3.20 each) regular medical, podiatry and laser ophthalmology treatment, plus contributions to a health fund ($8.50 per week), the outlay gets almost prohibitive. To try and save some money for the future is also very difficult, as life assurance policies are not available to diabetics.

I therefore make this appeal for financial assistance on behalf of myself and fellow sufferers in the sincere hope that something can be done to ease the situation and would be deeply appreciative if you would be good enough to give the matter your serious consideration.

The woman who wrote this letter is known by a member of my staff, who assures me that the letter does not adequately express the personal suffering that this woman has to endure as a result of her illness. She is apparently a very determined lady and is attempting at the moment to hold down a full time job, fortunately with the somewhat generous assistance of sympathetic employers. In addition to the sheer physical suffering she has to endure as a result of the side effects of her condition she and others like her are forced to pay extremely dearly in order merely to remain alive and in a relative degree of comfort. On her behalf and on behalf of the hundreds of thousands of diabetics in this country, I ask the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) to give some indication of whether the Government plans to do or can do anything to assist this not inconsiderable group of people. I understand that an honourable member in another place raised this matter some time ago. I also understand that the woman has not yet received any reply to her letter to the Government and Opposition senators or as a result of the matter being raised in the adjournment debate in the other place.

The second matter I want bring up very briefly is a matter that I raised in the Senate in October last year. It relates to the consequences of the harassment of a Commonwealth Government employee at the Defence Research Centre at Salisbury in South Australia. I will not go into the details again. They are in Hansard. The problem is that it is now a considerable number of months since I raised the question in the Senate. It is two years since this woman first laid complaints. She is without a job at the moment. No resolution of her case seems to have been reached. She is in a most unfortunate state of limbo, suffering physical and mental illhealth as a result of the stress that she has suffered over the last couple of years. I simply ask the new Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) to give his Department a hurry up if it is somehow, probably inadvertently, holding up a decision. If it is not the Department of Defence-if it is in fact the Public Service Board or some element in the Public Service-which is going slow in the matter, putting it into the too hard basket or hoping that if it ignores her long enough she will go away, will the Minister involved please take some action to satisfy what has been an extremely distressing case for far too long for this woman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I detain the Senate at this unconscionable hour for a few minutes only because the subject matter that I propose to mention concerns the liberty of a subject. It is yet another case history concerning the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the rights of an individual and a record of incompetence, delay and lack of concern for those individual rights on the part of, it seems, both ASIO and the supervising department-the Attorney- General's Department. The matter concerns Mr Stephen Rix, who is employed as an assistant research officer in the Department of Trade and Resources. Mr Rix was offered employment by the Department of Trade and Resources in November 1981, an offer which he immediately accepted. A week later he received a questionnaire from ASIO, in common with other putative employees in the Public Service, which he completed and returned. This was the first indication that he had had of the need for a security clearance but it was a procedure which he was happy to comply with.

SPEECH.PARA: Two months later-in January of this year-Mr Rix contacted the Department of Trade and Resources asking why he had heard no more about the job and when he could start it. He was told that no reply had been received from ASIO and this was the cause of the delay in proceeding to his actual employment. However, the Department of Trade and Resources said that, notwithstanding the failure of the receipt of advice from ASIO, it felt that as the Department had offered him a job which he had accepted it had no choice in all the circumstances but actually to employ him. He was flown to Canberra for discussions about an appropriate slot within the Department, commenced work at the Sydney regional office on 4 February and commenced work in Canberra on 16 February. It happened that on 4 February at the Sydney regional office he was interviewed personally by ASIO, an interview which again was conducted without apparent incident and in the course of which Mr Rix answered all the questions put to him fully and honestly.

What has happened subsequently is that ASIO has not submitted any report, as I understand it, to the Department of Trade and Resources either to confirm or deny that Mr Rix is any kind of security risk. Nearly six months have elapsed since the series of events to which I have referred took place but no word whatsoever has been forthcoming from ASIO as to the granting or denial of a security clearance.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is in a security limbo.
—Exactly. He occupies a kind of Kafkaesque corridor, one might say .
—It is too late at night for that.

—I acknowledge that it is too late at night, so I will not overdo the rhetoric. It is an empty, soulless corridor unaccompanied by any communication with the higher-ups as to whether he is in or out of national security favour. As a result of this failure to clarify his status, Mr Rix has been employed in a section of the Department which does not require a security clearance but which does not provide the work experience normally given to an assistant research officer in Mr Rix's position. At the end of this week there will be a rotation of all assistant research officers within the Department, and indeed in others, but without a security clearance there is no prospect in practice of any improvement in Mr Rix's situation. ASIO's slackness in this matter is clearly having an extremely detrimental effect on this man's Public Service career. I wrote to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on 7 May, apprising him of the situation and asking him to investigate the case as a matter of urgency. As yet, there has been no substantive reply to my letter.

SPEECH.PARA: The points I wish to make about this case are just two. In the first place, there seems to be a manifest denial of justice involved in the non-reply by ASIO . If Rix was ultimately to receive an adverse security report he could at least go to the Security Appeals Tribunal, the machinery set up under the new Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act, to challenge the basis on which that adverse security report had been put down. But in the absence of any report-even after six months of waiting for it-he can do absolutely nothing. He has not been granted a security clearance, nor has he been denied one. He just exists in this limbo-land to which Senator Mulvihill referred. I cannot believe that any justification can be advanced for ASIO's behaviour in this respect. If Mr Rix is perceived by that organisation to be a security risk by virtue of his membership of a particular political party or some other organisation, ASIO should be prepared to say so and to back its judgment before the Security Appeals Tribunal in the event that it is challenged. If Mr Rix is not perceived to be a security risk, grotesque negligence can be the only explanation for a reply not having been forthcoming during the period to which I have referred.

The other point that I feel obliged to make in this case is about the performance of the Attorney-General and his office in this matter. Once again, we seem to have a clear demonstration that the Attorney and those who work for him simply do not understand the concept of urgency. I wrote nearly three weeks ago, as I have said, drawing his attention to the pressing nature of the problem and the way in which this man's career advancement was being manifestly denied or inhibited by the failure to act in this matter. But I have had absolutely no results. The demands of the situation have been ignored and the career prospects of the individual remain quite bleak so long as they are ignored. In conclusion, I simply say that it is this kind of case which seems to me to point to the need for a much greater degree of accountability to this Parliament and in other ways for actions of ASIO than the present practice seems to allow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.
