TALK.START.PARA: —The page outlines the work force at both Garden Island Dockyard and its Victorian counterpart, Williamstown. Between 30 June 1980 and 31 March 1982 there was a decline in the aggregate work force in both dockyards. Nevertheless, representatives from the Royal Australian Navy who came before Senate Estimates Committee D gave the impression that there had been a more or less stabilising effect on the work force, which I think all of us on the Committee, which was chaired by Senator Kilgariff and included others such as Senator Sibraa and myself, accepted. Senator Sibraa questioned Government policy on the cessation of activities to some degree at the Small Arms Factory, Lithgow . It is not hard to understand all the trade unions involved, on either dockyard maintenance or, for that matter, small arms production, being a little concerned about what was ahead for them. This morning when I read page 7 of the Sydney Daily Telegraph I was stunned to discover that a Singaporean firm called Autoblast Singapore Pty Ltd has a contract to indulge in certain sand blasting and painting of several Australian Navy craft.

SPEECH.PARA: The contract involves HMAS Stalwart, and I understand the same treatment is to be given to HMAS Stuart, HMAS Parramatta and HMAS Brisbane. Of course, compounding what to me is, to say the least, an improper action, is that in the article the manager of this establishment boasted that not only is he adhering to Singapore trade union conditions which are inferior to ours-I do not say that with a jingoistic attitude-but also they are even lower. I say at the outset that if someone argues that in order to preserve international relations we must throw a few crumbs to nearby Asian countries, then we are doing that. As a matter of fact, without offending the sensibilities of the Senate, I call this matter two-tiered scabbery because on the one hand we are undercutting Australian naval trade union conditions and on the other hand undercutting the recognised trade union standards of Singapore.

That is the first complaint I wish to make. Job protection means that everyone in an industry is a taxpayer. There is no need for me to refer to certain overseas countries and deflation. Sure, one can make people redundant, but as a result they require social security and represent a minus and not a plus. They are out of the taxation field from which the Government gathers. To take the matter a little further, we face this situation: Garden Island Dockyard had already had a tussle with nearby residents about a sand blasting complex and was successful in having it constructed. It mystifies me why we have to let this work out to firms from a low wage country. Getting away from the syndrome of government enterprise, in the Port of Sydney, Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd employs many painters and dockers. It has a workforce of 150 people who do some of the sand blasting and painting of our various naval craft. They will be sent to industrial Coventry, too. But what is most sinister is that in this article in the Daily Telegraph the manager boasted that his friendship with the United States Navy was important and that it was able-he used the words-to apply pressure to the Royal Australian Navy to see that the company obtained a continuation of this work.

It is not my intention to go into a filibuster, but I spoke today to Mr Terry Gordon, the National Secretary of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia, and his State officials. They are quite adamant that a work force is available there to do this work. From a national point of view, they have a perfect right to do it. I spoke to officials of the Trades and Labour Council. I see no reason why this work has been given to Asian dockyards. I am more concerned because during an Estimates committee hearing-if Senator Kilgariff were in the chamber he would endorse what I am saying-we went on record as saying that we got honest answers from the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. But, believe me, when we got on to the Defence area we got, to say the least, grudging responses. I am being very polite in this matter. I can assure honourable senators that nothing was said to the effect that the unions responsible for naval dockyard maintenance would have to live with this situation. I could say a lot more tonight. I made a pledge to the officials of the union concerned and the matter will not stop here. The next matter will involve workers covered by the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia and then other workers in the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. I took the opportunity, as the Minister would well know, to alert him to the fact that there is considerable resentment in Sydney in regard to this situation. I will await the response of the Minister with interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to take just a few moments of the Senate's time to pay tribute to a lady who has served this Parliament, its senators and members for a long time. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond briefly to Senator Haines's contribution tonight. She raised two matters. Although it does not fall within my portfolio responsibility I will try to follow up the matter of the employee that she mentioned some months ago who was employed at the defence establishment at Salisbury. I do recall her raising that matter and I will undertake to chase up a response for her.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the insulin dependent diabetics, I appreciate the points that she is making. I would not want people to exaggerate the amount of suffering that is associated with diabetes. As the son of a diabetic and the nephew of a diabetic and having several diabetic colleagues in this chamber one could overemphasise the suffering associated with the illness. Most people want to live as normally as they can. Senator Haines's contribution tonight concerned the non-availability, as a subsidised benefit, of certain equipment and certain aids. The Government does make certain things available. Not only does it make insulin available under normal prescription circumstances but also, where a diabetic has particular needs, special arrangements can be made to get insulin in large amounts for prolonged periods. That is something which doctors can and do organise. In the same way other items available on prescription can be obtained by special application to directors of health if there are special needs.

The problem with the matters which she mentioned-syringes, blood glucose monitoring equipment, the special strips for use of that equipment and needles for drawing blood-is that they are not pharmaceuticals. They are not available under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. As things stand there is no scheme available which would allow them to be subsidised. What Senator Haines is seeking is a new form of benefit. That would simply involve a government decision and would be a matter for the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) to take up with the Government. It is therefore appropriate that I refer this concern on to him.

When I was Minister for Health I was aware of a large number of representations which were being made in this area. I believe that the Minister whom I represent in this place would be aware of those representations, would be sensitive to the matters which Senator Haines has raised and would appreciate that there is much concern among the people who have the need to use this quite expensive equipment .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans raised a matter regarding a delay in the provision of a security assessment for a Mr Rix. It is true that Mr Rix has been engaged in the Public Service on work which requires an assessment and the matter has been referred to Australian Security Intelligence Organisation for that purpose. It is also true that Senator Evans wrote to me on 7 May in regard to this matter and my attention and that of my staff was drawn to if I have had a discussion with the Director-General of ASIO in regard to the complaint which Senator Evans has raised in the Senate this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought it was particularly ungracious of Senator Evans to comment as he did about my staff. I think it is a bit unreasonable to complain about a delay in the matter from 7 May, particularly when we are all heavily engaged at this stage in the session of the Senate. However, putting that aside, Senator Evans and his staff have received a good deal of attention from my staff and I do not appreciate the comments he made about them, regardless of what he may say about me.

As I said, I have discussed the matter with the Director-General of ASIO and I am satisfied that there is some justification for what is certainly a delay. A number of assessments requiring care and attention have been necessary during this period. I am sure honourable senators would expect very great attention is required to be given to matters of this kind. I hope that the matter will be finalised in the near future. I will refer the comments that Senator Evans made to the Director-General. I am sure he will expedite the matter in the light of those comments.

I think Senator Mulvihill referred to an article which appeared in today's Sydney Daily Telegraph. I do not think Senator Mulvihill raised all the matters referred to in that article so I do not propose to canvass all of them. The position is that the maintenance work being done on HMAS Stalwart in Singapore is being carried out in accordance with ordinary practice. When ships are on deployment for certain periods it is established practice to carry out preventative maintenance work. The work on the ship in Singapore is being done during what is known as a scheduled self-maintenance period. It was necessary for the Stalwart to depart from Sydney in accordance with the fleet program to meet deployment commitments in South East Asia. Given these constraints the work could not be carried out before departure without disruption to that commitment. As this work is required to be done in accordance with those established practices it has been carried out in Singapore and not in Garden Island Dockyard . Again in accordance with normal procedure the work was offered for tender in Singapore. The firm carrying it out is the only one that responded. Although it has been suggested in the article it is not true that this firm has been given any indication that further work will be placed with it by the Royal Australian Navy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your remarks are related to HMAS Stalwart? They do not encompass the other vessels mentioned in the article?

—The same consideration applies to the other vessels as well. I am sorry but I thought Senator Mulvihill's main concern was in relation to the work on Stalwart. The work on other vessels is repainting work. The chipping and painting of hulls which are not part of the refit are normally performed by sailors and not by dockyard personnel. The work on those ships also comes within the self-maintenance period. Work is certainly being carried out but it is of a limited maintenance kind. Nothing is to be inferred from the work done on these ships that there is any change in policy or there are to be any procedures other than ordinary maintenance procedures.
—You don't see it as creating dismissals in the current dockyard work force?
—That is certainly not the intention of it. It is in accordance with what is regarded as ordinary maintenance. When ships are away on deployment this sort of work is occasionally done on them.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During Senator Tate's speech in the adjournment debate this evening he raised for the consideration of the President, in his capacity as joint parliamentary head of the Parliamentary Library Committee, his comments regarding the use of the carrels in the Library by senators and members. Under a letter dated 20 May the Speaker and the President circularised senators and members to point out that two of the eight carrels in the Library would be converted during the forthcoming winter recess into a small permanent office for the use by a parliamentary science fellow. I should mention to Senator Tate and to the Senate that yesterday Senator Walters and Senator Teague spoke to me about this matter. They mentioned to me that in their capacity as members of the Parliamentary Library Committee they were not able to be present at the meeting of the Committee when the decision to convert the two carrels was taken but that since the letter of the President and the Speaker had been received by honourable senators two or three senators had complained to them personally about the decision that had been taken. Following that notification to me by Senator Walters and Senator Teague, in my capacity as Deputy President, I wrote to the President yesterday and drew the matter of the complaints to the attention of the President.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Tate mentioned also that on 11 March of this year during the adjournment debate he had expressed concern about the positioning of the public galleries in the design for the Senate chamber in the new Parliament House. As I understand his remarks, he complained that apart from a conversation in the corridors he had received no further information. At the time of the adjournment debate on 11 March I was in the chair and at page 771 of Hansard of that date I am recorded as having said:

In response to the remarks of Senator Tate, I note that the President is one of the joint chairmen of the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House. I will ensure that Senator Tate's remarks are brought to the attention of the President and that a reply is made to the honourable senator as soon as possible.
I transmitted to the President the content of Senator Tate's remarks and on 25 March the President of the Senate wrote to Senator Tate in the following terms:
Dear Senator Tate,
During the Adjournment debate on 11 March 1982, you expressed concern about the positioning of the public galleries in the design of the Senate Chamber in the new Parliament House.

The Schematic Design as presented by the Parliament House Construction Authority during the Budget Session last year and viewed by you and many other Senators, complied with the building brief in respect of requirements for the Senate Chamber.

The suggestions made at the time by Senators were not recorded against specific Senators' names. However, as a result of many of the comments made on the Schematic Design, numerous changes have been made and will continue to be made as the design process advances. The Architect has given particular attention to sight-lines in the Senate Chamber.

The Developed Design for the building as a whole is to be presented to the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House in the near future. As co- Chairman of the Committee, I undertake to ensure that the Committee is made aware of your concern.
Yours sincerely, HAROLD YOUNG President of the Senate
In case that letter dated 25 March 1982 directed by the President to Senator Tate was not received by Senator Tate, I shall ensure that a copy of the letter is transmitted to the honourable senator.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.59 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

(2) How large is the complement of the United States Navy ships of this class.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The normal Royal Australian Navy peacetime complement for HMAS Adelaide is 183 comprising 16 officers and 167 sailors. Included in these numbers are three officers and four sailors to man an interim helicopter but these are not presently borne.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the status of the Royal Australian Navy FFG Close-in Weapons System program.
(2) Why will the first two ships not be equipped with such weapons.
(3) Does the Minister for Defence have any reservations about the effectiveness of the Phalanx CIWS.

(4) Is it intended to use the depleted uranium cored ammunition being used in this weapon on USN ships, or some other type of ammunition, if Australia does eventually install the Phalanx CIWS on the FFGs or any other RAN ships.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Both HMAS Sydney and HMAS Darwin will be equipped with Phalanx CIWS during construction.

(2) HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Canberra were completed before CIWS became available for ship installation. Contemporary USN FFG Class ships are not yet equipped with Phalanx CIWS. Space and weight provision was made for future installation of CIWS should it later be decided to fit this system.
(3) The Phalanx is one of the most effective self defence anti-missile systems available.

(4) It is planned to manufacture CIWS ammunition in Australia using a locally designed tungsten penetrator. However, the initial supplies of ammunition for the two FFGs now under construction in the United States will be provided from United States sources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did a study by the American naval architects Gibbs and Cox show that major modifications would have to be made to the FFG-7 design if a five-inch gun was to be carried; if so, when was the study carried out, and when did the Australian Government receive the results, or a copy of the study.
(2) Did the same study show it was not feasible for the guided missile launcher system MK13 to be carried if the FFG was equipped with a five-inch gun.
(3) Did the study show the design would have to be lengthened by 10 feet and that such a design modification would be expensive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The American naval architects Gibbs and Cox undertook a comprehensive study in 1974 covering modifications required to the FFG-7 design to install a five-inch gun and other weapons and engineering changes. The report showed that major modifications would have to be undertaken to the FFG-7 design including lengthening the ship 8 feet forward and 8 feet aft to incorporate all of the proposed changes while retaining the MK13 launcher. Considerable ship redesign costs would be involved in such a modification. The report did not separately address the impact of installing only a five-inch gun. The Gibbs and Cox report was dated 15 February 1974 and was received shortly after.

A further study was undertaken by Gibbs and Cox in 1980 which was limited to consideration of replacing the MK13 launcher with a five-inch gun. This study concluded that such a modification would be feasible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the FFG-7 originally intended as the 'low mix' component of the US Navy for the 1980s and deliberately designed so that major changes to the design would be difficult and/or expensive, to ensure that such additions or alterations could not be made to the design.

(2) What armament options are being considered for the Phase II follow-on- destroyers, and has work subsequent to the Gibbs and Cox study shown that modifications to the armament of the FFGs would be cost effective; if not, what is the basis of the Government's decision to order long lead items for the FFGs. (See answer to Question on Notice No. 1468, Senate Hansard, p. 2753).
(3) Is some kind of stand off anti-submarine weapon being considered, for example the successor to the American ASROC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The FFG-7 was designed as the 'low mix' component of the US Navy for the 1980s to supplement the capabilities of the 'high mix' ships. The FFG-7 was a ' designed-to-price' ship; it was not deliberately designed so that major changes to the design would be difficult and/or expensive.

(2) and (3) A number of studies have been undertaken into possible modifications to the weapons and sensor configuration of the FFGs for the RAN. Gibbs and Cox undertook studies in 1974 and 1980 which were used to determine the cost effectiveness of possible alternative armament options for the follow- on-destroyers. These studies culminated in the Government decision that the first two ships of the follow-on-destroyer project should have the same weapon and sensor fit as FFG 04 (HMAS Darwin) excepting for the possible substitution of the AN/SQS-56 sonar with the Australian designed Mulloka sonar. Preliminary studies have been initiated on possible weapons alternatives for later ships.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Commonwealth spending approximately $25m a year on advertising.
(2) Is it proposed to reduce this to about $20m.
(3) What amount of this budget is spent on informing the public of benefits available to them through government services.
(4) Did the Department of Social Security in November-December last year spend $361,781 on media advertising to promote and defend the position it had taken in a dispute with its employees.
(5) Did the Government, between March and August last year, spend $545,360 on advertising its objection to shorter working hours.

(6) Did the Government earlier this year spend $300,000 trying to persuade people that its new housing policy was useful; if so, was $100,000 of this amount spent in Victoria, on the eve of the election in that State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Expenditure by the Commonwealth for advertising and related activity arranged through the Australian Government Advertising Service in 1980-81 totalled $23,248,375. Advertising accounts due to be paid in the first 10 months of 1981-82 total $16,098,102.

(2) Total Commonwealth expenditure for advertising arranged through the Australian Government Advertising Service results from the aggregation of costs of meeting advertising needs from funding approved within appropriations to the separate ministerial portfolios. No formal decision is made in setting, increasing or decreasing total advertising expenditure for a specific fiscal year in single budget terms. Hence it is not possible to accurately forecast the total annual advertising expenditure. However, based on the current progression of expenditure likely for the first 10 months of 1981-82, total advertising expenditure in 1981-82 can be expected to be below $20m.

(3) There is no single budget for total advertising by the Commonwealth. Furthermore, recording of advertising expenditure by departments or by other Commonwealth organisations using the services of the Australian Government Advertising Service does not include any categorising in terms of 'informing the public of benefits available to them through government services'.
(4) Accounts totalling $361,790 for advertising arranged on behalf of the Department of Social Security in November-December 1981 and dealing with an industrial dispute were paid by that department.
(5) Yes.

(6) The Government allocated $300,000 for advertising in March and April this year to inform the public about its new housing assistance policy. Of this total , an expense of $59,094 for advertising media space and time in Victoria between 24 and 31 March was committed. Further expense of $30,500 for advertising media space and time in Victoria was committed for the period 4-6 April.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria receive funding from the Department of Social Security; if so, will the Minister supply details of such funding since 1974.

(2) Are organisations such as the Epilepsy Foundation of Victoria required to submit details of their funding from other sources in making application for assistance; if so, will the Minister supply these details in respect of the Epilepsy Foundation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Epilepsy Foundation receives financial assistance from my department under the Handicapped Persons Welfare Program for its activity therapy centre at 818-822 Burke Road, Camberwell.

The Foundation received a $4:$1 capital grant in 1977-78 under the Handicapped Persons Welfare Program towards components of the building which related to the activity therapy centre and receives ongoing support in the form of salary subsidy for some staff. Since funding commenced in 1977-78 the Foundation has received the following subsidies under the Program:
Capital-$377,059
Equipment-$23,518
Salary-$352,472

(2) Organisations approaching my department for funding under the Handicapped Persons Welfare Program are obliged to supply details of any funding provided by other Federal or State Government Departments.

One of the criteria for eligibility for a capital project is that the organisation must have its one-fifth share of the capital cost. These funds must be unencumbered and must not be obtained from other government departments.
Similarly with on going costs, my department takes into account any funding organisations receive from other government departments in respect of such costs and reduces subsidy accordingly.

The Epilepsy Foundation receives financial assistance (in the form of deficit financing) from the Victorian Health Commission but this is to assist with its operating costs and not specifically for any particular expenditure item.
My Department is aware of the level of assistance provided by the Health Commission and is satisfied with the current funding arrangement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the names, salaries and location of journalists employed by the Government Information Unit, including the salary of the Director, Mr Vincent Matthews.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What evidence is there that a section of plant breeders may promote varieties needing abnormal support from fertilisers and chemicals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen no such evidence and I do not believe any exists.

From time to time the assertion has been made that once plant variety rights are introduced breeders will breed plants which require abnormally high quantities of fertilizers or chemicals, or require specific chemicals available only through the same plant breeding company.

There is no doubt in my mind that in their breeding programs, breeders will place a high priority on resistance to disease and insect pests. To deliberately adopt the opposite course would be commercially foolish. No company is going to waste time (and breeding is a very costly process) on developing varieties which are less resistant to diseases or insects than varieties already available to the public.
No farmers or gardeners are going to buy varieties which require more fertiliser, or special inputs, unless it pays them to do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are the Plant Diversity Protection Committee's claims that there are thirteen ways of avoiding plant variety rights correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The possibilities proposed by the Plant Diversity Protection Committee for avoiding PVR are extremely limited in providing rewards or protection for plant breeders. None of the alternatives suggested provides the comprehensive protection which will be provided by the PVR Scheme.

The various non-statutory provisions proposed by the Committee, such as the use of hybrids, specialised production techniques and other commercial arrangements, give plant breeders a limited advantage only. Most of these arrangements are already in use today. Clearly they do not meet industry needs, otherwise there would be no demand for a PVR Scheme.

Equally, the proposed statutory provision, such as the use of trademarks, resort to common law and inventor's certificates, are limited in effect and do not provide the comprehensive protection which would be available under PVR.

PVR is the only system which will legally protect the proprietary rights of breeders to new varieties they have developed, and which will also enable Australia to gain commercial access to varieties protected overseas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What levels of royalties and other charges are being made in other countries where plant variety rights is in operation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A plant variety right gives the holder control over the sale of plants and reproductive material of that variety. It also entitles him to license others to sell plants and reproductive material of that variety.

As far as I am aware, this is the basis of the right in all countries where plant variety rights (PVR) schemes exist. It is a matter for the holder of the right to make a commercial judgment as to the premium that he considers the market is prepared to pay because it considers his variety superior to other varieties.
The royalties, or premiums, being made in various countries at any particular time are a function of the market forces existing at that time.

It is important to remember that farmers and gardeners will also make judgments about the seeds and plants they are purchasing and it is highly unlikely that a premium will be paid for a variety if that variety cannot return the investment.

The question referred to 'other charges'. In PVR schemes in other countries there are specific charges related to the granting and maintenance of the right. The level of fees varies from country to country but generally amount to something under $1,000 per variety registered.
In the United States of America, for example, the fees are $US250 application, $US250 search and a further $US250 when the certificate is issued. That is, a total of $US750.

In New Zealand and the United Kingdom there are different levels of fees for different categories of species. In New Zealand, for example, fees for agricultural crops and vegetables amount to a total of $NZ750 and the annual renewal fee is $NZ50.

In the United Kingdom the application fee for cereals and potatoes, for example , is #220. In addition, a test fee in the first year of #385 (slightly less in subsequent years) is charged and an annual renewal fee of #165 the second year ( increasing in subsequent years) is charged.

The training programs have been far more ambitious than anything attempted prior to the introduction of similar legislation in the United States. Lack of training there led to confusion. That should not happen here. The training programs have been designed to acquaint senior officers with the legislation, to enable work to begin within agencies on systems for dealing with FOI requests and to encourage agencies to set up their own internal training programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1027), Senator Colston asked me a question without notice about letters sent to recipients of health care cards regarding income limits. I am now in a position to provide Senator Colston and the Senate with some further information.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Under the health care card arrangements a person whose income is below certain qualifying limits is entitled to a health care card which is valid for a period of 6 months provided his income over any period of four consecutive weeks does not reach 125 per cent of the qualifying limits.
This arrangement is designed so that once eligibility is established it will be continued for 6 months irrespective of minor fluctuations of income.

When a health care card is issued the person is informed of the expiry date of the card and of his obligation to notify if his income reaches 125 per cent of the basic limit (the actual amount represented by the 125 per cent is printed on the card).
At the end of the 6 months period entitlement to the grant of a further card is considered. To be eligible for a further card an applicant must again satisfy the basic income limit.

It has become apparent that some people have gained the impression that they remain eligible for health care card indefinitely provided their income remains below the 125 per cent limit. As I have indicated above this is not correct. Accordingly, I asked my Department to carry out a review of the wording on advices and other literature concerning the income limits. This has now been done and the review advice form specifically referred to by Senator Colston has been redesigned to overcome the problem.
In addition the health care card itself and the initial application form are being redesigned to further clarify the position.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1982, (Hansard, page 1090) Senator Coleman asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, in a supplementary question on tax sharing arrangements with the States, whether the Premier of Western Australia had requested the Commonwealth to change the base for providing tax sharing grants from total Commonwealth tax collections to income tax collections. Senator Coleman also sought the Commonwealth's views on such a proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by the Treasurer that the Commonwealth has not received a request from the Western Australian Premier on the matter. Senator Coleman may have had in mind a Press release by the Premier on 22 March 1982 in which he stated he would prefer tax sharing grants to be based on personal income tax collections rather than total Commonwealth tax collections.

The move to a total tax collection base was decided at the May 1981 Premiers' Conference. There are advantages in the use of total tax collections as a base, including the 'insulation' it would provide the States in the event of any shift in emphasis between personal income tax and other Commonwealth Taxes. This was acknowledged in a statement on tax sharing arrangements made by all Premiers in February 1981. A sharing of total taxation could also be regarded as more equitable in the sense that both the Commonwealth and the States would share equally in movements in all Commonwealth tax receipts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March (Hansard, page 1162) Senator Ryan asked me a question without notice concerning changes in procedures for the lodgment of income statements by Aboriginals receiving unemployment benefit. I am now in a position to provide Senator Ryan and the Senate with additional information.

ANSWER.PARA: As a general rule, all applicants for unemployment benefit are required to complete a fortnightly application for continuation of unemployment benefit ( sometimes known as an income statement) before payment is made.

This is required to be lodged by the date shown on the form but where remoteness of a client's dwelling makes it impracticable for applications for continuation of unemployment benefit to be lodged by the due date, an extension of time is allowed based on the nature and extent of the difficulties involved.

For beneficiaries living in extremely remote areas, who would otherwise have difficulty lodging fortnightly applications for continuation of unemployment benefit on time, special procedures operate which provide for an application for continuation of benefit to cover a 4 week (rather than the usual 2 week) period. As these procedures operate in the Northern Territory the form is due for lodgment at the end of the 4 weekly period and is issued 2 weeks prior to that date. Benefit payments are not interrupted provided the form is received within 2 weeks of the date it is due to be lodged.
In some communities in the Katherine area it was the practice to extend the period allowed for the return of the forms to 6 weeks from the date the forms were due to be lodged.

This arrangement was recently reviewed and it was found that this longer period was not necessary. This was confirmed by an examination of cases over a 3 month period which showed that 85 per cent of forms were lodged within 2 weeks of the due date.

There are also other procedures to ensure that any individual Aboriginal or groups of Aboriginals are not disadvantaged because of difficulties in having forms lodged. For example, if a number of forms are outstanding at the end of the specified period the Aboriginal Liaison Officer looks into the reason for the delay before any action is taken to suspend payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1354) Senator Robert Ray asked Senator Peter Baume as Minister then representing the Minister for Administrative Services the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware that in the compilation of the joint electoral rolls there are different qualifications between State and Commonwealth elections? Is the Minister aware that in Victoria prisoners are entitled to vote in State elections but are not entitled to vote in Federal elections and hence the roll is marked 'not entitled to vote for Federal elections'? Would the Minister agree that this sort of marking on the roll readily identifies, and unfairly so, those who have been prisoners. Could he look at the productions of the rolls in such a way that that marking will no longer occur?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commonwealth produces electoral rolls jointly with New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania. Distinguishing marks are placed on these rolls against the names of those who are enrolled only for Commonwealth or only for State purposes. This marking is not restricted to prisoners.
In Victoria, for example, the names of electors falling into any one of three categories may be marked to indicate State but not Commonwealth enrolment:
persons who are under sentence for an offence punishable by imprisonment for one year or longer;
Aboriginals, for whom State but not Commonwealth enrolment is compulsory; and
parliamentarians, who may be enrolled in different divisions for Commonwealth and State purposes.
The only practical alternative to placing distinguishing marks against the names of such electors would be for the Commonwealth and the State to publish separate rolls.

This would tend to defeat the purpose of joint roll arrangements; it would be expensive; and it would no longer be possible for individual electors to verify both their Commonwealth and their State enrolment by consulting a single roll in a single location.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1570) Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the implications to Australian agriculture of the European Economic Community's (EEC) trade sanctions against Argentina and in particular which Australian industries are likely to benefit most.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information.
The EEC has banned imports from Argentina with effect from 16 April until 24 May 1982 and will decide whether to extend, modify or withdraw its ban before the end of that period
latest seven-day limit (from 18-24 May) imposed by EEC saw Italy, Denmark and Ireland expressing strong reservations.

Because, initially at least, the EEC's ban is in force only for five weeks and does not extend to goods already contracted for, shipped, or for which import licences have been issued, the short-term impact on EEC supplies (and Australian exports) of beef, wool, grains, and fruit is likely to be minimal.

If trade sanctions were significantly extended the Australian industry most likely to benefit would be the wool industry. Australia could not undertake to supply sufficient quantities of processed wool but could probably supply the market within one or two years if processors had assurances of permanency
Argentina supplies around 250,000 bales, greasy in this form each year in the short term.

In respect of the beef industry, the EEC trade sanctions are unlikely to have a direct impact on Australian exports although some benefits may be derived from a subsequent reduction in EEC exports to third world markets.
For wheat, coarse grains and fruit, the likely shortfall in Argentine supplies will have a minimal impact on EEC and world markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1825) Senator McLaren asked me a question without notice seeking some information on the minimum expenditure of $A30m which the Esso company has undertaken to spend over the next three years on a technical and economic feasibility study of the Rundle project. The honourable senator asked:

ANSWER.PARA: How much of this $A30m will be spent in Australia? How much will be spent in the United States of America? How much has already been spent? Did any of the $ A30m include expenditure undertaken or committed in the Exxon Corporation's Colony shale oil project in Colorado?
I undertook to seek that information and I now provide the following answer based on advice from Esso:
Esso estimates that the $A30m three-year commitment will be spent approximately as follows: 52 per cent in the United States of America, 4 per cent in Germany and 44 per cent in Australia.

For accounting purposes the Rundle Joint Venture agreement became effective on 1 January 1982. In the first quarter of 1982 $A1.0m was spent in Australia while $A2.2m was spent in the United States of America. The joint venturers also agreed that a further $A2.0m spent in Australia in the latter half of 1981 on slot cut sampling at the Rundle site and shipping be included as expenditure under the commitment. Thus of the $A5.2m spent under the Rundle Joint Venture Agreement up to the end of March 1982, $A3.0m was spent in Australia and $A2.2m in the United States of America.
None of the $A30m commitment by Esso to the Rundle project is connected in any way to expenditure on or com- mitted to the Exxon Colony shale oil project in Colorado.
